20her%20work.%20Trouble%20arose%20only%20when%20Sean%20announced%20an%20intention%20to%20go%20to%20art%20school%20instead%20of%20a%20liberal-arts%20college.%20Anderson%20saw%20this%20as%20a%20confounding%20unwillingness%20to%20walk%20through%20open%20doors%20of%20opportunity.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CHaving%20a%20kid%20who%20was%20a%20communist%20anarchist%3F%20That%20was%20nothing%20for%20Liz%2C%E2%80%9D%20Jacobi%20said.%20%E2%80%9CHaving%20a%20kid%20who%20was%20lesbian%3F%20That%20took%20Liz%20about%20two%20seconds%20to%20live%20with.%20Transgender%3F%20That%20took%20about%20five%20seconds.%20A%20kid%20who%20didn%E2%80%99t%20want%20to%20go%20to%20college%3F%20Heresy.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20was%20in%20tears%2C%E2%80%9D%20Anderson%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%2C%20like%2C%20%E2%80%98Art%20school%3F%20You%E2%80%99re%20an%20anarchist%2C%20and%20ninety-nine%20per%20cent%20of%20people%20there%20go%20into%20commercial%20art.%20%3Cem%3EReally%3C%2Fem%3E%3F%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EA%20year%20ago%2C%20Anderson%20and%20Jacobi%20became%20empty%20nesters.%20Sean%2C%20who%20no%20longer%20identifies%20as%20an%20anarchist%2C%20wound%20up%20at%20Clark%20University%2C%20en%20route%20to%20a%20career%20in%20public%20health%20or%20social%20work.%20Their%20younger%20child%20is%20at%20Eastern%20Michigan%20University%2C%20and%20is%20thriving%20on%20his%20own.%20Their%20parents%20say%20that%20having%20children%20educated%20them%20away%20from%20the%20idea%20of%20a%20fixed%20plan.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CParents%20of%20autistic%20kids%20are%20always%20struggling%20with%20gluten-free%20diets%20and%20chelation%2C%E2%80%9D%20Jacobi%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThey%E2%80%99re%20desperate%20for%20a%20%E2%80%98normal%E2%80%99%20kid.%20Liz%20and%20I%20see%20eye%20to%20eye%20that%2C%20when%20you%20give%20up%20hoping%20for%20some%20magical%20treatment%2C%20you%20can%20just%20focus%20on%20the%20kid%20in%20front%20of%20you.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Anderson and her husband went to lunch at Zingerman’s, a deli restaurant in downtown Ann Arbor. It was a warm weekend, and Anderson, who had just come from a walk of a few thousand steps in the arboretum, ordered peaches with jalapeño dressing and a bowl of gazpacho. Jacobi, who had come from a four-mile jog, got a brisket sandwich, fruit salad, and a Dr. Brown’s black-cherry soda. “I should never come here after running,” he told the woman at the counter. (He often strikes up small, self-revealing conversations with people at registers.) Outside, they found a table in the shade. Anderson sat, and Jacobi put an arm around her."],["p","“I’ve got my love puppy,” Anderson said."],["p","He stiffened indignantly. “Your love ",["em","dog"],",” he said."],["p","“My nickname for him, depending on my mood, is Hundie or Hound Dog—or Doggie,” Anderson explained."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1d1d1b1fa04b334bab0818%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1d1b1fa04b334bab0818%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1d1d1b1fa04b334bab0818%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d1d1b1fa04b334bab0818"}]],["p","At sixty, Dave Jacobi has a college student’s narrow shoulders, a stubby beard, and glasses that magnify his eyes. He also has a stellar repertoire of doctorly self-deprecating jokes (“As a teen-ager, I wanted to be a moral hero, like Christ or Schweitzer, but now I’m aiming for law-abiding”) and a gregariousness that tends to flatter his wife. Anderson is a genius, he says, while he’s a schmo. (He is actually a respected internist in the Henry Ford Health System, which serves all Detroit.) Their lives",["inline-embed",{"type":"analytics","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22analytics%22%2C%22url%22%3A%226%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}]," today aren’t so much intertwined as subject to a division of labor. Jacobi purports to have no idea what his salary is, because Anderson keeps the family finances. He maintains the social calendar, because it might not otherwise occur to Anderson to leave her desk. At their first meeting, Anderson explained Hegel’s notion of self-alienated spirit. (“The thing is, not only did Liz explain it but it made sense to me for about an hour,” Jacobi says.) On their honeymoon, in the Southwest, they hired a geologist to accompany them and lecture about rocks."],["p","Yet they disagreed while raising their two children. As a toddler, their elder child was given to tantrums. Their younger child was diagnosed as being on the spectrum; Anderson took time off to work with him one-on-one. “Our kids had a certain degree of emotional disregulation, and Liz was unbelievably astute about, and willing to tolerate, being yelled at without escalating the emotion in return,” Jacobi said. “She probably exceeds me in that capacity.”"],["p","“Dave is a sweetie pie, but he does have this Germanic streak,” Anderson said."],["p","Their elder child, Sean, came out as genderqueer in high school, and began work as an activist. During senior year, Sean left home to move in with a partner, a trans woman. Jacobi and Anderson disagreed about the appropriate parental response."],["p","“Liz is very much laissez-faire,” Jacobi said, and took a large bite of his sandwich."],["p","“It’s more that I don’t think you control where your kids’ hearts go,” Anderson replied."],["p","This was, after all, exactly the sort of freedom that she championed in her work. Trouble arose only when Sean announced an intention to go to art school instead of a liberal-arts college. Anderson saw this as a confounding unwillingness to walk through open doors of opportunity."],["p","“Having a kid who was a communist anarchist? That was nothing for Liz,” Jacobi said. “Having a kid who was lesbian? That took Liz about two seconds to live with. Transgender? That took about five seconds. A kid who didn’t want to go to college? Heresy.”"],["p","“I was in tears,” Anderson said. “I’m, like, ‘Art school? You’re an anarchist, and ninety-nine per cent of people there go into commercial art. ",["em","Really"],"?’ ”"],["p","A year ago, Anderson and Jacobi became empty nesters. Sean, who no longer identifies as an anarchist, wound up at Clark University, en route to a career in public health or social work. Their younger child is at Eastern Michigan University, and is thriving on his own. Their parents say that having children educated them away from the idea of a fixed plan."],["p","“Parents of autistic kids are always struggling with gluten-free diets and chelation,” Jacobi said. “They’re desperate for a ‘normal’ kid. Liz and I see eye to eye that, when you give up hoping for some magical treatment, you can just focus on the kid in front of you.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EMotherhood%20coincided%20with%20a%20transformation%20in%20Anderson%E2%80%99s%20methods.%20She%20started%20working%20with%20historians%2C%20trying%20to%20hone%20her%20understanding%20of%20ideas%20by%20studying%20them%20in%20the%20context%20of%20their%20creation.%20Take%20Rousseau%E2%80%99s%20apparent%20support%20of%20direct%20democracy.%20It%E2%80%99s%20rarely%20mentioned%20that%2C%20at%20the%20moment%20when%20he%20made%20that%20argument%2C%20his%20home%20town%20of%20Geneva%20had%20been%20taken%20over%20by%20oligarchs%20who%20claimed%20to%20represent%20the%20public.%20Pragmatism%20said%20that%20an%20idea%20was%20an%20instrument%2C%20which%20naturally%20gave%20rise%20to%20such%20questions%20as%3A%20an%20instrument%20for%20what%2C%20and%20where%2C%20and%20when%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHer%20approach%20broadened%20in%20other%20ways%2C%20too.%20In%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20Is%20the%20Point%20of%20Equality%3F%2C%E2%80%9D%20Anderson%20had%20already%20started%20to%20drift%20away%20from%20what%20philosophers%2C%20following%20Rawls%2C%20call%20ideal%20theory%2C%20based%20on%20an%20end%20vision%20for%20a%20perfectly%20just%20society.%20As%20Anderson%20began%20a%20serious%20study%20of%20race%20in%20America%2C%20though%2C%20she%20found%20herself%20losing%20faith%20in%20that%20approach%20entirely.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBroadly%2C%20there%E2%80%99s%20a%20culturally%20right%20and%20a%20culturally%20left%20ideal%20theory%20for%20race%20and%20society.%20The%20rightist%20version%20calls%20for%20color%20blindness.%20Instead%20of%20making%20a%20fuss%20about%20skin%20and%20ethnicity%2C%20its%20advocates%20say%2C%20society%20should%20treat%20people%20as%20people%2C%20and%20let%20the%20best%20and%20the%20hardest%20working%20rise.%20The%20leftist%20theory%20envisions%20identity%20communities%3A%20for%20once%2C%20give%20black%20people%20(or%20women%2C%20or%20members%20of%20other%20historically%20oppressed%20groups)%20the%20resources%20and%20opportunities%20they%20need%2C%20including%2C%20if%20they%20want%20it%2C%20civil%20infrastructure%20for%20themselves.%20In%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Imperative%20of%20Integration%2C%E2%80%9D%20published%20in%202010%2C%20Anderson%20tore%20apart%20both%20of%20these%20models.%20Sure%2C%20it%20might%20be%20nice%20to%20live%20in%20a%20color-blind%20society%2C%20she%20wrote%2C%20but%20that%E2%80%99s%20nothing%20like%20the%20one%20that%20exists.%20In%20one%20study%20she%20cited%2C%20sixty%20per%20cent%20of%20people%20who%20saw%20a%20crime%20report%20on%20TV%20that%20hadn%E2%80%99t%20identified%20the%20suspect%20thought%20that%20it%20had%3B%20seventy%20per%20cent%20of%20those%20people%20thought%20that%20the%20suspect%20was%20black.%20Other%20research%20found%20that%20when%20white%20people%20pretended%20not%20to%20notice%20race%20they%20often%20acquired%20alienating%20tics%2C%20such%20as%20avoiding%20eye%20contact.%20Color%20blindness%20would%20simply%20lock%20in%20problems%20past%20correction.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBut%20the%20case%20for%20self-segregation%20was%20also%20weak.%20Affinity%20groups%20provided%20welcome%20comfort%2C%20yet%20that%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20the%20same%20as%20power%20or%20equality%2C%20Anderson%20pointed%20out.%20And%20there%20was%20a%20goose-and-gander%20problem.%20Either%20you%20let%20only%20certain%20groups%20self-segregate%20(certifying%20their%20subordinate%20status)%20or%20you%20also%20permitted%2C%20say%2C%20white%20men%20to%20do%20it%2C%20and%E2%80%94well%2C%20we%20have%20a%20lot%20of%20data%20from%20that%20experiment%2C%20and%20they%E2%80%99re%20not%20encouraging.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnderson%E2%80%99s%20solution%20was%20%E2%80%9Cintegration%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20concept%20that%2C%20especially%20in%20progressive%20circles%2C%20had%20been%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22analytics%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522analytics%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%25227%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%20uncool%20since%20the%20late%20sixties.%20Integration%2C%20by%20her%20lights%2C%20meant%20mixing%20on%20the%20basis%20of%20equality.%20It%20was%20not%20assimilation.%20It%20required%20adjustments%20from%20all%20groups.%20Anderson%20laid%20out%20four%20integrative%20stages%3A%20formal%20desegregation%20(no%20legal%20separation)%2C%20spatial%20integration%20(different%20people%20share%20neighborhoods)%2C%20formal%20social%20integration%20(they%20work%20together%2C%20and%20are%20one%20another%E2%80%99s%20bosses)%2C%20and%20informal%20social%20integration%20(they%20become%20buddies%2C%20get%20married%2C%20start%20families).%20Black%20students%20in%20integrated%20high%20schools%2C%20according%20to%20one%20study%2C%20had%20higher%20graduation%20rates%20than%20those%20in%20segregated%20schools%2C%20even%20controlling%20for%20socioeconomic%20background%2C%20parental%20education%2C%20and%20other%20factors.%20Students%E2%80%94black%20%3Cem%3Eand%3C%2Fem%3E%20white%E2%80%94at%20integrated%20schools%20went%20on%20to%20lead%20more%20integrated%20lives.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESome%20philosophers%20of%20color%20welcomed%20the%20book.%20%E2%80%9CShe%E2%80%99s%20taking%20the%20need%20for%20racial%20justice%20seriously%2C%20and%20you%20could%20hardly%20find%20another%20white%20political%20philosopher%20over%20a%20period%20of%20decades%20doing%20that%2C%E2%80%9D%20Charles%20Mills%2C%20a%20philosopher%20at%20the%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ECUNY%3C%2Fem%3E%20Graduate%20Center%2C%20says.%20For%20others%2C%20though%2C%20a%20white%20woman%20making%20recommendations%20on%20race%20policy%20raised%20questions%20of%20perspective.%20She%20was%20engaging%20through%20a%20mostly%20white%20Anglo-American%20tradition.%20She%20worked%20from%20the%20premise%20that%2C%20because%20she%20drew%20on%20folders%20full%20of%20studies%2C%20the%20limits%20of%20her%20own%20perspective%20were%20not%20constraining.%20At%20the%20same%20time%2C%20in%20attending%20to%20these%20empirical%20findings%20over%20doctrine%2C%20she%20announced%20herself%20as%20a%20non-ideal%20theorist%3A%20a%20philosopher%20with%20no%20end%20vision%20of%20society.%20The%20approach%20recalls%20E.%C2%A0L.%20Doctorow%E2%80%99s%20description%20of%20driving%20at%20night%3A%20%E2%80%9CYou%20can%20see%20only%20as%20far%20as%20the%20headlights%2C%20but%20you%20can%20make%20the%20whole%20trip%20that%20way.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAn%20integrative%20project%20also%20makes%20demands%20of%20academic%20practice.%20%E2%80%9CLiz%20has%20a%20genuine%20concern%20for%20fostering%20intellectual%20diversity%2C%E2%80%9D%20Daniel%20Jacobson%2C%20the%20only%20philosopher%20in%20her%20department%20who%20identifies%20as%20conservative%2C%20says.%20(He%20hosts%20a%20symposium%20for%20right-of-center%20thought%3B%20she%20supports%20the%20endeavor%20and%20sometimes%20joins%20in.)%20Recently%2C%20Anderson%20changed%20the%20way%20she%20assigns%20undergraduate%20essays%3A%20instead%20of%20requiring%20students%20to%20argue%20a%20position%20and%20fend%20off%20objections%2C%20doubling%20down%20on%20their%20original%20beliefs%2C%20she%20asks%20them%20to%20discuss%20their%20position%20with%20someone%20who%20disagrees%2C%20and%20to%20explain%20how%20and%20why%2C%20if%20at%20all%2C%20the%20discussion%20changed%20their%20views.%20Michigan%2C%20which%2C%20since%201988%2C%20has%20run%20a%20Program%20on%20Intergroup%20Relations%2C%20has%20avoided%20many%20of%20the%20impasses%20around%20identity%20and%20speech%20that%20have%20unsettled%20campuses%20elsewhere.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20not%20like%20there%E2%80%99s%20no%20racial%20politics%2C%E2%80%9D%20Anderson%20says.%20%E2%80%9CThere%E2%80%99s%20lots%20of%20racial%20politics%2C%20but%20people%20are%20talking%20to%20one%20another.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnderson%E2%80%99s%20closest%20contact%20with%20a%20firestorm%20came%20last%20year%2C%20when%20%3Cem%3EHypatia%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20a%20feminist%20philosophy%20journal%20on%20whose%20board%20she%20sat%2C%20was%20pressured%20to%20retract%20an%20article%20exploring%20similarities%20between%20Caitlyn%20Jenner%E2%80%99s%20gender%20transition%20and%20Rachel%20Dolezal%E2%80%99s%20identification%20as%20a%20black%20woman.%20The%20board%20ultimately%20stood%20by%20its%20publication%2C%20with%20a%20statement%20rich%20in%20Andersonian%20language.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Board%20affirms%20%3Cem%3EHypatia%E2%80%99s%3C%2Fem%3E%20commitment%20to%20pluralist%20inquiry%2C%E2%80%9D%20it%20read.%20The%20suggestion%20was%20that%20%3Cem%3Ehow%3C%2Fem%3E%20you%20are%2C%20not%20who%20you%20are%2C%20supplies%20a%20legitimate%20basis%20for%20social%20action.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20certain%20ways%2C%20this%20style%20of%20thinking%20is%20at%20odds%20with%20current%20modes.%20Derrick%20Darby%2C%20a%20philosopher%20who%20grew%20up%20in%20the%20Queensbridge%20projects%2C%20in%20New%20York%20City%2C%20and%20is%20the%20only%20tenured%20black%20professor%20in%20Anderson%E2%80%99s%20department%2C%20works%20in%20the%20Michigan-school%20mold%2C%20drawing%20heavily%20on%20empirical%20research.%20He%20taught%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Imperative%20of%20Integration%E2%80%9D%20in%20dialogue%20with%20his%20own%20data-based%20critique.%20%E2%80%9CIdeas%20of%20racial%20hierarchy%20will%20play%20out%20in%20different%20ways%20even%20within%20an%20integrated%20context%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says.%20%E2%80%9CBlack%20and%20brown%20kids%20are%20disproportionately%20assigned%20to%20special%20education.%20There%E2%80%99s%20tracking%20that%20still%20goes%20on.%E2%80%9D%20But%20his%20personal%20experience%20made%20him%20chary%2C%20too.%20%E2%80%9CLiz%20has%20a%20view%20that%20you%20pull%20people%20up%20from%20the%20projects%20and%20send%20them%20on%20their%20ways%20into%20the%20%C3%A9lite%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says.%20As%20someone%20who%E2%80%99d%20made%20that%20journey%2C%20he%20thought%20she%20underweighted%20the%20constraints%E2%80%94the%20unfreedom%E2%80%94involved%20in%20being%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20only%20damn%20black%20person%20in%20so%20many%20rooms.%E2%80%9D%20At%20one%20point%2C%20Anderson%20visited%20Darby%E2%80%99s%20class.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20spoke%20about%20our%20experiences%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20recalls%2C%20%E2%80%9Cand%20why%20it%20led%20us%20to%20focus%20our%20work%20as%20we%20did%E2%80%9D%3A%20childhood%20for%20him%20and%20parenting%20for%20her.%20They%20both%20ended%20up%20in%20tears.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Motherhood coincided with a transformation in Anderson’s methods. She started working with historians, trying to hone her understanding of ideas by studying them in the context of their creation. Take Rousseau’s apparent support of direct democracy. It’s rarely mentioned that, at the moment when he made that argument, his home town of Geneva had been taken over by oligarchs who claimed to represent the public. Pragmatism said that an idea was an instrument, which naturally gave rise to such questions as: an instrument for what, and where, and when?"],["p","Her approach broadened in other ways, too. In “What Is the Point of Equality?,” Anderson had already started to drift away from what philosophers, following Rawls, call ideal theory, based on an end vision for a perfectly just society. As Anderson began a serious study of race in America, though, she found herself losing faith in that approach entirely."],["p","Broadly, there’s a culturally right and a culturally left ideal theory for race and society. The rightist version calls for color blindness. Instead of making a fuss about skin and ethnicity, its advocates say, society should treat people as people, and let the best and the hardest working rise. The leftist theory envisions identity communities: for once, give black people (or women, or members of other historically oppressed groups) the resources and opportunities they need, including, if they want it, civil infrastructure for themselves. In “The Imperative of Integration,” published in 2010, Anderson tore apart both of these models. Sure, it might be nice to live in a color-blind society, she wrote, but that’s nothing like the one that exists. In one study she cited, sixty per cent of people who saw a crime report on TV that hadn’t identified the suspect thought that it had; seventy per cent of those people thought that the suspect was black. Other research found that when white people pretended not to notice race they often acquired alienating tics, such as avoiding eye contact. Color blindness would simply lock in problems past correction."],["p","But the case for self-segregation was also weak. Affinity groups provided welcome comfort, yet that wasn’t the same as power or equality, Anderson pointed out. And there was a goose-and-gander problem. Either you let only certain groups self-segregate (certifying their subordinate status) or you also permitted, say, white men to do it, and—well, we have a lot of data from that experiment, and they’re not encouraging."],["p","Anderson’s solution was “integration,” a concept that, especially in progressive circles, had been",["inline-embed",{"type":"analytics","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22analytics%22%2C%22url%22%3A%227%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}]," uncool since the late sixties. Integration, by her lights, meant mixing on the basis of equality. It was not assimilation. It required adjustments from all groups. Anderson laid out four integrative stages: formal desegregation (no legal separation), spatial integration (different people share neighborhoods), formal social integration (they work together, and are one another’s bosses), and informal social integration (they become buddies, get married, start families). Black students in integrated high schools, according to one study, had higher graduation rates than those in segregated schools, even controlling for socioeconomic background, parental education, and other factors. Students—black ",["em","and"]," white—at integrated schools went on to lead more integrated lives."],["p","Some philosophers of color welcomed the book. “She’s taking the need for racial justice seriously, and you could hardly find another white political philosopher over a period of decades doing that,” Charles Mills, a philosopher at the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"CUNY"]," Graduate Center, says. For others, though, a white woman making recommendations on race policy raised questions of perspective. She was engaging through a mostly white Anglo-American tradition. She worked from the premise that, because she drew on folders full of studies, the limits of her own perspective were not constraining. At the same time, in attending to these empirical findings over doctrine, she announced herself as a non-ideal theorist: a philosopher with no end vision of society. The approach recalls E. L. Doctorow’s description of driving at night: “You can see only as far as the headlights, but you can make the whole trip that way.”"],["p","An integrative project also makes demands of academic practice. “Liz has a genuine concern for fostering intellectual diversity,” Daniel Jacobson, the only philosopher in her department who identifies as conservative, says. (He hosts a symposium for right-of-center thought; she supports the endeavor and sometimes joins in.) Recently, Anderson changed the way she assigns undergraduate essays: instead of requiring students to argue a position and fend off objections, doubling down on their original beliefs, she asks them to discuss their position with someone who disagrees, and to explain how and why, if at all, the discussion changed their views. Michigan, which, since 1988, has run a Program on Intergroup Relations, has avoided many of the impasses around identity and speech that have unsettled campuses elsewhere. “It’s not like there’s no racial politics,” Anderson says. “There’s lots of racial politics, but people are talking to one another.”"],["p","Anderson’s closest contact with a firestorm came last year, when ",["em","Hypatia"],", a feminist philosophy journal on whose board she sat, was pressured to retract an article exploring similarities between Caitlyn Jenner’s gender transition and Rachel Dolezal’s identification as a black woman. The board ultimately stood by its publication, with a statement rich in Andersonian language. “The Board affirms ",["em","Hypatia’s"]," commitment to pluralist inquiry,” it read. The suggestion was that ",["em","how"]," you are, not who you are, supplies a legitimate basis for social action."],["p","In certain ways, this style of thinking is at odds with current modes. Derrick Darby, a philosopher who grew up in the Queensbridge projects, in New York City, and is the only tenured black professor in Anderson’s department, works in the Michigan-school mold, drawing heavily on empirical research. He taught “The Imperative of Integration” in dialogue with his own data-based critique. “Ideas of racial hierarchy will play out in different ways even within an integrated context,” he says. “Black and brown kids are disproportionately assigned to special education. There’s tracking that still goes on.” But his personal experience made him chary, too. “Liz has a view that you pull people up from the projects and send them on their ways into the élite,” he says. As someone who’d made that journey, he thought she underweighted the constraints—the unfreedom—involved in being “the only damn black person in so many rooms.” At one point, Anderson visited Darby’s class. “We spoke about our experiences,” he recalls, “and why it led us to focus our work as we did”: childhood for him and parenting for her. They both ended up in tears."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20challenge%20of%20pluralism%20is%20the%20challenge%20of%20modern%20society%3A%20maintaining%20equality%20amid%20difference%20in%20a%20culture%20given%20to%20constant%20and%20unpredictable%20change.%20It%20is%20the%20fashion%20in%20America%20these%20days%20to%20define%20political%20virtue%20by%20position.%20Richard%20is%20on%20the%20side%20of%20history%2C%20we%20might%20say%2C%20because%20he%E2%80%99s%20to%20the%20left%20of%20Irma%20on%20this%20issue%20and%20slightly%20to%20the%20right%20of%20Marco%20on%20that%20one.%20Anderson%20would%20resist%20this%20way%20of%20thinking%2C%20not%20least%20because%20it%20calls%20for%20intellectual%20convergence.%20It%E2%80%99s%20anti-pluralistic%20and%20tribalist.%20It%20celebrates%20ideology%3B%20it%20presumes%20that%20certain%20models%20have%20absolute%2C%20not%20situational%2C%20value.%20Rather%20than%20fighting%20for%20the%20ascendancy%20of%20certain%20positions%2C%20Anderson%20suggests%2C%20citizens%20should%20fight%20to%20bolster%20healthy%20institutions%20and%20systems%E2%80%94those%20which%20insure%20that%20all%20views%20and%20experiences%20will%20be%20heard.%20Today%E2%80%99s%20righteous%20projects%2C%20after%20all%2C%20will%20inevitably%20seem%20fatuous%20and%20blinkered%20from%20the%20vantage%20of%20another%20age.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBy%20some%20measures%2C%20the%20late%20nineteen-sixties%20was%20a%20time%20when%20liberalism%E2%80%99s%20standing%20as%20an%20American%20creed%2C%20while%20appearing%20to%20intensify%2C%20frayed.%20It%20was%2C%20especially%20from%20the%20perspective%20of%20Anderson%E2%80%99s%20childhood%2C%20an%20era%20characterized%20by%20ideological%20aggression%3A%20campus%20uprisings%20and%20urban%20riots%2C%20assassinations%20and%20increasingly%20fruitless%20debates.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20world%20was%20falling%20apart%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20says%2C%20channelling%20her%20parents%E2%80%99%20perception%2 %2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1d1d1b286bc006c37e86c5%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1d1b286bc006c37e86c5%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EWhat%20else%20could%20you%20call%20the%20modern%20workplace%2C%20where%20superiors%20can%20issue%20changing%20orders%2C%20control%20attire%2C%20surveil%20correspondence%2C%20demand%20medical%20testing%2C%20define%20schedules%2C%20and%20monitor%20communication%2C%20such%20as%20social-media%20posts%3F%20The%20decisions%20that%20a%20company%20makes%2C%20like%20the%20installation%20of%20cubicles%20in%20the%20bank%20in%20Harvard%20Square%2C%20are%20presented%20as%20none%20of%20its%20employees%E2%80%99%20business%20(hence%20%E2%80%9Cprivate%E2%80%9D).%20Defenders%20of%20this%20state%20of%20affairs%20often%20counter%20that%20people%20negotiate%20their%20salaries%20and%20can%20always%20leave.%20Anderson%20notes%20that%20low-level%20workers%20can%20rarely%20wrangle%20raises%2C%20and%20that%20real-world%20constraints%20eliminate%20exit%20power.%20(Workers%20are%20sometimes%20bound%20by%20non-compete%20agreements%2C%20and%20usually%20cannot%20get%20unemployment%20insurance%20if%20they%20quit.)%20It%20was%20as%20if%20relational%20equality%20could%20be%20suspended%20between%20nine%20and%20five%E2%80%94a%20habit%20that%2C%20inevitably%2C%20affects%20life%20beyond%20work.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAmerican%20progressivism%20is%20in%20the%20midst%20of%20a%20messy%20reckoning.%20During%20the%20nineties%2C%20upper-tail%20wage%20inequality%20(the%20gap%20between%20the%20middle%20class%20and%20the%20rich)%20exceeded%20lower-tail%20inequality%20(the%20gap%20between%20the%20poor%20and%20the%20middle%20class).%20Since%20then%2C%20upper-tail%20inequality%20has%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22analytics%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522analytics%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%25229%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%20continued%20to%20grow%20while%20lower-tail%20inequality%20has%20remained%20basically%20unchanged.%20The%20unnaturalness%20of%20this%20top-heavy%20arrangement%2C%20combined%20with%20growing%20evidence%20of%20power%20abuses%2C%20has%20given%20many%20people%20reason%20to%20believe%20that%20something%20is%20fishy%20about%20the%20structure%20of%20American%20equality.%20Socialist%20and%20anti-capitalist%20models%20are%20again%20in%20vogue.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnderson%20offers%20a%20different%20corrective%20path.%20She%20thinks%20it%E2%80%99s%20fine%20for%20some%20people%20to%20earn%20more%20than%20others.%20If%20you%E2%80%99re%20a%20brilliant%20potter%2C%20and%20people%20want%20to%20pay%20you%20more%20than%20the%20next%20guy%20for%20your%20pottery%2C%20great!%20(If%20you%E2%80%99re%20just%20O.K.%20but%20want%20to%20work%20extra%20industriously%20for%20the%20difference%2C%20that%E2%80%99s%20fair%2C%20too.)%20The%20problem%20isn%E2%80%99t%20that%20talent%20and%20income%20are%20distributed%20in%20unequal%20parcels.%20The%20problem%20is%20that%20Jeff%20Bezos%20earns%20more%20than%20a%20hundred%20thousand%20dollars%20a%20minute%2C%20while%20Amazon%20warehouse%20employees%2C%20many%20talented%20and%20hardworking%2C%20have%20reportedly%20resorted%20to%20urinating%20in%20bottles%20in%20lieu%20of%20a%20bathroom%20break.%20That%20circumstance%20reflects%20some%20structure%20of%20hierarchical%20oppression.%20It%20is%20a%20rip%20in%20the%20democratic%20fabric%2C%20and%20it%E2%80%99s%20increasingly%20the%20norm.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAndersonism%20holds%20that%20we%20don%E2%80%99t%20have%20to%20give%20up%20on%20market%20society%20if%20we%20can%20recognize%20and%20correct%20for%20its%20limitations%E2%80%94it%20may%20even%20be%20our%20best%20hope%2C%20because%20it%E2%80%99s%20friendlier%20to%20pluralism%20than%20most%20alternatives%20are.%20And%20we%20shouldn%E2%80%99t%20commit%20ourselves%20to%20an%20ideal%20system%20of%20any%20sort%2C%20whether%20socialist%20or%20libertarian%2C%20because%20a%20model%20set%20in%20motion%20like%20a%20Swiss%20watch%20will%20become%20a%20trap%20as%20soon%20as%20circumstances%20change.%20Instead%2C%20we%20must%20be%20flexible.%20We%20must%20remain%20alert.%20We%20must%20solve%20problems%20collaboratively%2C%20in%20the%20moment%2C%20using%20society%E2%80%99s%20ears%20and%20eyes%20and%20the%20best%20tools%20that%20we%20can%20find.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The challenge of pluralism is the challenge of modern society: maintaining equality amid difference in a culture given to constant and unpredictable change. It is the fashion in America these days to define political virtue by position. Richard is on the side of history, we might say, because he’s to the left of Irma on this issue and slightly to the right of Marco on that one. Anderson would resist this way of thinking, not least because it calls for intellectual convergence. It’s anti-pluralistic and tribalist. It celebrates ideology; it presumes that certain models have absolute, not situational, value. Rather than fighting for the ascendancy of certain positions, Anderson suggests, citizens should fight to bolster healthy institutions and systems—those which insure that all views and experiences will be heard. Today’s righteous projects, after all, will inevitably seem fatuous and blinkered from the vantage of another age."],["p","By some measures, the late nineteen-sixties was a time when liberalism’s standing as an American creed, while appearing to intensify, frayed. It was, especially from the perspective of Anderson’s childhood, an era characterized by ideological aggression: campus uprisings and urban riots, assassinations and increasingly fruitless debates. “The world was falling apart,” she says, channelling her parents’ perception at the time. In the home of Eve and Olof Anderson, this mounting chaos and anger became a transformational pressure. After the showdown between protesters and police at the",["inline-embed",{"type":"analytics","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22analytics%22%2C%22url%22%3A%228%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}]," 1968 Democratic National Convention, Olof cast a vote for Nixon. Later, leery of increasingly doctrinal socialist ideas, he and Eve dropped their Democratic affiliation. “I just got fed up with it,” Olof says."],["p","Today, Eve and Olof Anderson support President Donald Trump. They describe themselves as conservative on social matters and libertarian on everything else. “We do come together with Elizabeth on many levels—issues of right and wrong and family,” Eve says. “She’s a wonderful wife and mother.”"],["p","Where there used to be daily discussion of the news between Anderson and her parents, though, dialogue about politics has gone largely dead. Anderson, in her writing, often makes use of conservative vantages, like a painter assessing her canvas from the other side of the room. Her work can seem like a long argument addressed to readers across the aisle: an attempt to make them understand and, maybe, to win them back."],["p","One of Anderson’s premises is that the project of fairness is more shared, across the spectrum, than many people suppose. Some years ago, she began to envisage a comprehensive history of egalitarianism. How did egalitarian ideas emerge, and how had they changed? How did they relate to ideas about the uses and abuses of state power?"],["p","“Originally, I thought, I’ll start mid-seventeenth century,” she said. “But then you realize, well, you can’t really deal with that until you deal with the Protestant radicals of the Reformation, like the Anabaptists. But the Anabaptists are harking back to early Christian egalitarian communities—so maybe I have to start looking at, like, the New Testament. ",["em","Hah-hah-hah!"],"” Eventually, Anderson ended up at the hunter-gatherers. It occurred to her that hundreds of thousands of years might be a lot to cover in one book, so she decided that it would be two books, or three. Possibly five. Regardless, it will take her a while to finish, maybe the rest of her life. But it will be her big project, the unified picture that she leaves behind."],["p","Anderson was invited to deliver the Tanner Lectures at Princeton in 2015, and decided to launch the project there. Many people still believed that market economies were a sound foundation of freedom. Yet, she found, ninety per cent of female restaurant workers reported being sexually harassed. Some poultry-industry employees were said to have worn diapers for lack of breaks. About seven million American workers had been compelled to support political positions under threat from their bosses. Such people could not be called free."],["p","Anderson zeroed in on Adam Smith, whose “The Wealth of Nations,” published in 1776, is taken as a keystone of free-market ideology. At the time, English labor was subject to uncompensated apprenticeships, domestic servitude, and some measure of clerical dominion. Rigid hierarchies, from the king to the pauper, were maintained by an arcane system of debts, favors, and gifts. Smith saw the markets as an escape from that order. Their “most important” function, he explained, was to bring “liberty and security” to those “who had before lived almost in a continual state of war with their neighbours, and of servile dependency upon their superiors.”"],["p","Smith, in other words, was an egalitarian. He had written “The Wealth of Nations” in no small part to be a solution to what we’d now call structural inequality—the intractable, compounding privileges of an arbitrary hierarchy. It was a historical irony that, a century later, writers such as Marx pointed to the market as a structure of dominion over workers; in truth, Smith and Marx had shared a socioeconomic project. And yet Marx had not been wrong to trash Smith’s ideas, because, during the time between them, the world around Smith’s model had changed, and it was no longer a useful tool."],["p","“The Industrial Revolution was a cataclysmic event for egalitarians,” Anderson explains in “Private Government” (2017), a book that she assembled from the Tanner Lectures. Today, people still try to use, variously, both Smith’s and Marx’s tools on a different, postindustrial world:"],["blockquote",["p","Images of free market society that made sense prior to the Industrial Revolution continue to circulate today as ideals, blind to the gross mismatch between the background social assumptions reigning in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, and today’s institutional realities. We are told that our choice is between free markets and state control, when most adults live their working lives under a third thing entirely: ",["em","private government."]]],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1d1d1b286bc006c37e86c5%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1d1b286bc006c37e86c5%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1d1d1b286bc006c37e86c5%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d1d1b286bc006c37e86c5"}]],["p","What else could you call the modern workplace, where superiors can issue changing orders, control attire, surveil correspondence, demand medical testing, define schedules, and monitor communication, such as social-media posts? The decisions that a company makes, like the installation of cubicles in the bank in Harvard Square, are presented as none of its employees’ business (hence “private”). Defenders of this state of affairs often counter that people negotiate their salaries and can always leave. Anderson notes that low-level workers can rarely wrangle raises, and that real-world constraints eliminate exit power. (Workers are sometimes bound by non-compete agreements, and usually cannot get unemployment insurance if they quit.) It was as if relational equality could be suspended between nine and five—a habit that, inevitably, affects life beyond work."],["p","American progressivism is in the midst of a messy reckoning. During the nineties, upper-tail wage inequality (the gap between the middle class and the rich) exceeded lower-tail inequality (the gap between the poor and the middle class). Since then, upper-tail inequality has",["inline-embed",{"type":"analytics","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22analytics%22%2C%22url%22%3A%229%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}]," continued to grow while lower-tail inequality has remained basically unchanged. The unnaturalness of this top-heavy arrangement, combined with growing evidence of power abuses, has given many people reason to believe that something is fishy about the structure of American equality. Socialist and anti-capitalist models are again in vogue."],["p","Anderson offers a different corrective path. She thinks it’s fine for some people to earn more than others. If you’re a brilliant potter, and people want to pay you more than the next guy for your pottery, great! (If you’re just O.K. but want to work extra industriously for the difference, that’s fair, too.) The problem isn’t that talent and income are distributed in unequal parcels. The problem is that Jeff Bezos earns more than a hundred thousand dollars a minute, while Amazon warehouse employees, many talented and hardworking, have reportedly resorted to urinating in bottles in lieu of a bathroom break. That circumstance reflects some structure of hierarchical oppression. It is a rip in the democratic fabric, and it’s increasingly the norm."],["p","Andersonism holds that we don’t have to give up on market society if we can recognize and correct for its limitations—it may even be our best hope, because it’s friendlier to pluralism than most alternatives are. And we shouldn’t commit ourselves to an ideal system of any sort, whether socialist or libertarian, because a model set in motion like a Swiss watch will become a trap as soon as circumstances change. Instead, we must be flexible. We must remain alert. We must solve problems collaboratively, in the moment, using society’s ears and eyes and the best tools that we can find."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EAnderson%E2%80%99s%20lecture%20at%20Ohio%20State%20University%20was%20called%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Great%20Reversal%3A%20How%20Neoliberalism%20Turned%20the%20Economic%20Aspirations%20of%20Liberalism%20Upside%20Down.%E2%80%9D%20The%20three-hundred-seat%20Ohio%20Union%20theatre%20was%20near%20capacity%20that%20afternoon.%20Anderson%20came%20to%20the%20lectern%20in%20her%20flowing%20black%20ensemble%20and%20noisily%20cleared%20her%20throat%20into%20the%20microphone.%20A%20wage-and-productivity%20graph%20appeared%20on%20a%20screen%20behind%20her.%20She%20had%20prepared%20a%20PowerPoint.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%20can%20see%20that%2C%20from%20about%201950%20to%201970%2C%20the%20typical%20American%E2%80%99s%20wages%20kept%20up%20with%20productivity%20growth%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20Then%2C%20around%201974%2C%20she%20went%20on%2C%20hourly%20compensation%20stagnated.%20American%20wages%20have%20been%20effectively%20flat%20for%20the%20past%20few%20decades%2C%20with%20the%20gains%20of%20productivity%20increasingly%20going%20to%20shareholders%20and%20to%20salaries%20for%20big%20bosses.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhat%20changed%3F%20Anderson%20rattled%20off%20a%20constellation%20of%20factors%2C%20from%20strengthened%20intellectual-property%20law%20to%20winnowed%20antitrust%20law.%20Financialization%2C%20deregulation.%20Plummeting%20taxes%20on%20capital%20alongside%20rising%20payroll%20taxes.%20Privatization%2C%20which%20exchanged%20modest%20public-sector%20salaries%20for%20C.E.O.%20paydays.%20She%20gazed%20into%20the%20audience%20and%20blinked.%20%E2%80%9CSo%20now%20we%20have%20to%20ask%3A%20What%20has%20been%20used%20to%20justify%20this%20rather%20dramatic%20shift%20of%20labor-share%20of%20income%3F%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20answer%2C%20of%20course%2C%20was%20classical%20liberal%20philosophers.%20Anderson%20clicked%20forward%20to%20a%20slide%20with%20a%20pair%20of%20unattributed%20quotations%2C%20describing%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20property%20which%20every%20man%20has%20in%20his%20own%20labour%E2%80%9D%20as%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20most%20sacred%20and%20inviolable%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20championing%20good%20conditions%20for%20working%20people.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CSmith!%E2%80%9D%20someone%20cried.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9C%3Cem%3EGood%3C%2Fem%3E%20Adam%20Smith%2C%E2%80%9D%20Anderson%20said.%20The%20classical%20liberals%20had%20been%20anti-monopolistic.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20opposed%20all%20forms%20of%20unfree%20labor%E2%80%94not%20just%20slavery%20but%20serfdom%2C%20peonage%2C%20unpaid%20apprenticeship%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said%2C%20peering%20at%20some%20undergraduates%20in%20front.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhile%20spending%20the%20summer%20researching%20the%20history%20of%20the%20Protestant%20work%20ethic%20for%20her%20Seeley%20Lectures%2C%20at%20Cambridge%2C%20this%20spring%2C%20Anderson%20had%20come%20across%20a%20rarely%20collected%20essay%20by%20Jeremy%20Bentham%2C%20who%20was%20born%20twenty-five%20years%20after%20Smith.%20Bentham%20is%20widely%20known%20for%20coming%20up%20with%20the%20idea%20for%20a%20creepy%20surveillance%20prison%2C%20the%20panopticon%2C%20which%20Michel%20Foucault%20much%20later%20turned%20into%20a%20metaphor%20for%20institutional%20control.%20Anderson%20found%20that%2C%20in%20this%20obscure%20essay%2C%20%E2%80%9CPauper%20Management%20Improved%3A%20Particularly%20by%20Means%20of%20an%20Application%20of%20the%20Panopticon%20Principle%20of%20Construction%2C%E2%80%9D%20Bentham%20had%20himself%20proposed%20that%20panopticons%20be%20used%20to%20manage%20not%20just%20criminals%20but%20also%20the%20poor%2C%20the%20elderly%2C%20and%20the%20disabled.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20projected%20that%20this%20model%20would%20be%20really%20great%20for%20everyone%2C%20but%20especially%20for%20the%20owner%20of%20the%20panopticon%2C%E2%80%9D%20Anderson%20told%20the%20audience%20in%20Ohio.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20had%20detailed%20calculations.%20You%20could%20get%20three-hundred-per-cent%20profits%20from%20an%20adult%20man%20and%20two-hundred-per-cent%20profits%20from%20an%20adult%20woman.%20But%20the%20greatest%20source%20of%20profits%20of%20all%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94she%20paused%E2%80%94%E2%80%9Cwould%20come%20from%20child%20labor.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBehind%20Anderson%2C%20a%20slide%20of%20Bentham%E2%80%99s%20quasi-mummified%20body%20appeared.%20She%20grew%20visibly%20excited.%20%E2%80%9C%C2%A0%E2%80%98Pauper%20Management%20Improved%2C%E2%80%99%20I%20think%2C%20is%20one%20of%20the%20%3Cem%3Eoriginal%3C%2Fem%3E%20sources%20of%20the%20arguments%20for%20the%20privatization%20of%20public%20functions%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20It%20was%20no%20wonder%20that%20industrial-age%20thinking%20was%20riddled%20with%20contradictions%3A%20it%20reflected%20what%20Anderson%20called%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20plutocratic%20reversal%E2%80%9D%20of%20classical%20liberal%20ideas.%20Those%20perversely%20reversed%20ideas%20about%20freedom%20were%20the%20ones%20that%20found%20a%20home%20in%20U.S.%20policy%2C%20and%2C%20well%2C%20here%20we%20were.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnderson%20followed%20up%20with%20an%20ebullient%20Q.%C2%A0%26amp%3B%C2%A0A.%2C%20and%20then%20was%20taken%20to%20the%20faculty%20club%20for%20dinner.%20During%20a%20lull%20in%20the%20conversation%2C%20a%20professor%20leaned%20down%20the%20table%20and%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CSo%2C%20John%20Stuart%20Mill.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9C%3Cem%3EOohhhhhhh!%3C%2Fem%3E%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20the%20other%20philosophers%20cried%20in%20unison%2C%20as%20if%20he%E2%80%99d%20Z-snapped%20in%20her%20face.%20He%20was%20a%20Mill%20scholar%2C%20and%20nitpicking%20was%20expected.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnderson%20laughed%3A%20%3Cem%3EHah-hah-hah!%3C%2Fem%3E%20With%20Mill%2C%20she%20said%2C%20it%20was%20a%20mixed%20bag.%20He%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20a%20complete%20nut%20like%20Bentham%2C%20who%20had%20been%E2%80%94%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CLiz%2C%20just%20let%20me%20know%20when%20you%20think%20it%E2%80%99s%20time%20to%20go%2C%E2%80%9D%20said%20the%20director%20of%20the%20university%E2%80%99s%20ethics%20center%2C%20which%20had%20arranged%20the%20talk.%20He%E2%80%99d%20be%20driving%20her%20back%20to%20the%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22analytics%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522analytics%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522final%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%20hotel.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnderson%20answered%20with%20a%20sober%20nod%2C%20like%20Cinderella%20glancing%20at%20the%20clock%2C%20and%20then%2C%20her%20face%20brightening%2C%20she%20turned%20back%20to%20a%20table%20filled%20with%20strangers%20who%20had%20become%20friends.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EDue%20to%20a%20transcription%20error%2C%20a%20previous%20version%20of%20this%20article%20misquoted%20Elizabeth%20Anderson.%20She%20referred%20to%20the%20types%20of%20labor%20opposed%20by%20classical%20liberals%20as%20%E2%80%9Cunfree%20labor%2C%E2%80%9D%20not%20%E2%80%9Cfree%20labor.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Anderson’s lecture at Ohio State University was called “The Great Reversal: How Neoliberalism Turned the Economic Aspirations of Liberalism Upside Down.” The three-hundred-seat Ohio Union theatre was near capacity that afternoon. Anderson came to the lectern in her flowing black ensemble and noisily cleared her throat into the microphone. A wage-and-productivity graph appeared on a screen behind her. She had prepared a PowerPoint."],["p","“You can see that, from about 1950 to 1970, the typical American’s wages kept up with productivity growth,” she said. Then, around 1974, she went on, hourly compensation stagnated. American wages have been effectively flat for the past few decades, with the gains of productivity increasingly going to shareholders and to salaries for big bosses."],["p","What changed? Anderson rattled off a constellation of factors, from strengthened intellectual-property law to winnowed antitrust law. Financialization, deregulation. Plummeting taxes on capital alongside rising payroll taxes. Privatization, which exchanged modest public-sector salaries for C.E.O. paydays. She gazed into the audience and blinked. “So now we have to ask: What has been used to justify this rather dramatic shift of labor-share of income?” she said."],["p","The answer, of course, was classical liberal philosophers. Anderson clicked forward to a slide with a pair of unattributed quotations, describing “the property which every man has in his own labour” as “the most sacred and inviolable,” and championing good conditions for working people."],["p","“Smith!” someone cried."],["p","“",["em","Good"]," Adam Smith,” Anderson said. The classical liberals had been anti-monopolistic. “They opposed all forms of unfree labor—not just slavery but serfdom, peonage, unpaid apprenticeship,” she said, peering at some undergraduates in front."],["p","While spending the summer researching the history of the Protestant work ethic for her Seeley Lectures, at Cambridge, this spring, Anderson had come across a rarely collected essay by Jeremy Bentham, who was born twenty-five years after Smith. Bentham is widely known for coming up with the idea for a creepy surveillance prison, the panopticon, which Michel Foucault much later turned into a metaphor for institutional control. Anderson found that, in this obscure essay, “Pauper Management Improved: Particularly by Means of an Application of the Panopticon Principle of Construction,” Bentham had himself proposed that panopticons be used to manage not just criminals but also the poor, the elderly, and the disabled. “He projected that this model would be really great for everyone, but especially for the owner of the panopticon,” Anderson told the audience in Ohio. “He had detailed calculations. You could get three-hundred-per-cent profits from an adult man and two-hundred-per-cent profits from an adult woman. But the greatest source of profits of all”—she paused—“would come from child labor.”"],["p","Behind Anderson, a slide of Bentham’s quasi-mummified body appeared. She grew visibly excited. “ ‘Pauper Management Improved,’ I think, is one of the ",["em","original"]," sources of the arguments for the privatization of public functions,” she said. It was no wonder that industrial-age thinking was riddled with contradictions: it reflected what Anderson called “the plutocratic reversal” of classical liberal ideas. Those perversely reversed ideas about freedom were the ones that found a home in U.S. policy, and, well, here we were."],["p","Anderson followed up with an ebullient Q. & A., and then was taken to the faculty club for dinner. During a lull in the conversation, a professor leaned down the table and said, “So, John Stuart Mill.”"],["p","“",["em","Oohhhhhhh!"]," ” the other philosophers cried in unison, as if he’d Z-snapped in her face. He was a Mill scholar, and nitpicking was expected."],["p","Anderson laughed: ",["em","Hah-hah-hah!"]," With Mill, she said, it was a mixed bag. He wasn’t a complete nut like Bentham, who had been—"],["p","“Liz, just let me know when you think it’s time to go,” said the director of the university’s ethics center, which had arranged the talk. He’d be driving her back to the",["inline-embed",{"type":"analytics","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22analytics%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22final%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}]," hotel."],["p","Anderson answered with a sober nod, like Cinderella glancing at the clock, and then, her face brightening, she turned back to a table filled with strangers who had become friends. ♦"],["p","Due to a transcription error, a previous version of this article misquoted Elizabeth Anderson. She referred to the types of labor opposed by classical liberals as “unfree labor,” not “free labor.”"]]],"canonicalUrl":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/01/07/the-philosopher-redefining-equality","categories":{"formatting":{"heroLayouts":{"id":"5904125cf7e7325b97af7970","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5904125cf7e7325b97af7970","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Hero 2%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1ae1366e94e94091466ee9"}]]],["p",["strong","This Mournable Body"],["em",", by Tsitsi Dangarembga (Graywolf)"],". The author’s first novel, the post-colonial classic “Nervous Conditions” (1988), followed Tambu, a woman in nineteen-sixties Rhodesia who is striving for an education in order to transcend a village upbringing. Here, in the third novel of a trilogy, Tambu faces breakdowns and the realization that her hard-won achievements do not guarantee upward mobility in a Zimbabwe beset by poverty, autocracy, and white privilege. Desperate for money, having quit a job where she received “miserly wages for copy white men put their names to,” she works for a tour company that offers wealthy European tourists an authentic African experience. Soon she is guiding them around her old village. The novel brilliantly dramatizes the tragic ironies of life in a country where keeping yourself afloat may mean swallowing your pride."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c1ae13681ab3335f580def6%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1ae13681ab3335f580def6%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1ae13681ab3335f580def6%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1ae13681ab3335f580def6%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1ae13681ab3335f580def6%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1ae13681ab3335f580def6%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1ae13681ab3335f580def6%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1ae13681ab3335f580def6"}]]],["p",["strong","The Lonesome Bodybuilder"],["em",", by Yukiko Motoya, translated from the Japanese by Asa Yoneda (Soft Skull)"],". The mundane and the magical are kneaded into one throughout this collection of stories: a husband made of straw orders a latte, a girl next door grows pink hair and cries tears of blood, a customer goes into a fitting room and doesn’t reëmerge. In this alien yet familiar world, invisible forces assume physical shapes: two lovers become identical to each other; girlfriends develop features desired by their boyfriends. The monstrous plots prompt human queries: Does getting comfortable in a relationship involve a loss of self? Is one’s identity bounded by one’s surroundings? “I’ve only been doing what everyone else was doing already—impersonating me,” one character writes."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1ad94536cecf4019212e2f"}]]],["p",["strong","Tigerland"],["em",", by Wil Haygood (Knopf)"],". At the center of this social history is the championship runs, in 1968 and 1969, of basketball and baseball teams from East High School, in Columbus, Ohio. Haygood’s game-by-game narrative expands to encompass the story of the black residents of Columbus’s East Side, including the poverty and segregation that shaped the players on those teams. No detail seems too small to include—for instance, the number of minutes the school’s principal played for Ohio State’s football team before making a fortuitous interception—but the factoids coalesce to produce a vivid sense of the community’s deep identification with its sports team. “East High represented more than just the school,” Haygood writes. “It was a vibrant part of the black community at ":"5c1ae136d2db9849ec9e4263"}]]],["p",["strong","Hungover"],["em",", by Shaughnessy Bishop-Stall (Penguin Books)"],". This unabashedly droll account of the author’s search for a hangover cure posits a hangover taxonomy (seven kinds, including “the Creeper” and “the Burrower”); assesses hangover literature from Pliny the Elder to Kingsley Amis; and recalls the experience of flying a fighter plane after a boozy night. As Bishop-Stall tests remedies that include intravenous drips and voodoo, his practical quest leads to a kind of metaphysics of the hangover. When he comes across a cure that works, he is unnerved: “I became like a man scared of himself, yet undaunted by the morning.”"]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Books","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"books"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Books","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"books"}]}]},"channel":"","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[],"contentType":"article","contributors":[],"dek":"","formatting":{},"hed":"Briefly 0and%20that%2C%20by%202018%2C%20face-to-face%20communication%20across%20long%20distances%20would%20be%20available%20everywhere%3A%20%E2%80%9CThe%20transmission%20of%20pictures%20and%20texts%20and%20the%20distant%20manipulation%20of%20computers%20and%20other%20machines%20will%20be%20added%20to%20the%20transmission%20of%20the%20human%20voice%20on%20a%20scale%20that%20will%20eventually%20approach%20the%20universality%20of%20telephony.%E2%80%9D%20True!%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20all%20this%20will%20do%20to%20the%20world%20I%20cannot%20guess%2C%E2%80%9D%20Pierce%20admitted%2C%20with%20becoming%20modesty.%20%E2%80%9CIt%20seems%20bound%20to%20affect%20us%20all.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESharp-eyed%20observers%20in%201968%20were%20already%20concerned%20about%20the%20warming%20of%20the%20oceans%20and%20the%20changing%20of%20the%20climate%2C%20but%20the%20atmospheric-science%20contributor%20to%20%E2%80%9CToward%20the%20Year%202018%2C%E2%80%9D%20Thomas%20F.%20Malone%2C%20was%20excited%20by%20new%20technologies%20that%20would%20allow%20scientists%20to%20take%20control%20of%20the%20earth%E2%80%99s%20weather%20and%20climate.%20Malone%20served%20as%20the%20chairman%20of%20the%20Committee%20on%20Atmospheric%20Sciences%20of%20the%20National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%2C%20which%2C%20in%201966%2C%20had%20issued%20a%20report%20endorsing%20%E2%80%9Ca%20long-range%20program%20of%20weather%20control%20and%20climate%20modification%2C%E2%80%9D%20to%20be%20implemented%20by%20way%20of%20manipulating%20fog%2C%20cloud-seeding%2C%20and%20the%20%E2%80%9Csuppression%20of%20lightning.%E2%80%9D%20He%20thought%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20probability%20of%20success%20in%20broad%20climate%20modification%20is%20likely%20to%20exceed%2050%20percent%20by%20the%20year%202018.%E2%80%9D%20Standing%20in%20the%20way%20of%20this%20objective%2C%20he%20warned%2C%20were%20political%20obstacles%E2%80%94the%20international%20co%C3%B6peration%20required%20for%20a%20global%20climate-change%20program%E2%80%94and%20the%20possibility%20that%2C%20before%20such%20a%20thing%20could%20be%20fully%20executed%2C%20%E2%80%9Clarge-scale%20climate%20modification%20will%20be%20effected%20inadvertently%2C%E2%80%9D%20because%2C%20he%20had%20to%20admit%2C%20it%20appeared%20that%20the%20climate%20was%20already%20changing%20all%20on%20its%20own.%20%E2%80%9CCarbon%20dioxide%20in%20the%20atmosphere%20since%201900%20has%20caused%20surface%20temperatures%20to%20rise%200.2%20degrees%20C%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20acknowledged%2C%20hastening%20to%20reassure%20his%20readers%20that%2C%20while%20global%20temperatures%20could%20conceivably%20keep%20rising%20all%20the%20way%20to%202018%2C%20there%20was%20only%20%E2%80%9Ca%20small%20probability%20that%20these%20effects%20will%20not%20be%20tolerable.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20only%20real%20doomsayer%20was%20the%20demographer%20Philip%20M.%20Hauser.%20He%20calculated%20that%2C%20by%202018%2C%20the%20world%E2%80%99s%20population%20would%20reach%209.7%20billion%20(he%20was%20two%20billion%20over)%2C%20with%20the%20steepest%20growth%20in%20Asia%20and%20Latin%20America%2C%20and%20the%20slowest%20in%20Europe.%20Also%2C%20that%20the%20distance%20between%20the%20rich%20and%20the%20poor%2C%20and%20between%20wealthy%20nations%20and%20poor%20nations%2C%20would%20widen.%20%E2%80%9CGiven%20the%20present%20outlook%2C%20only%20the%20faithful%20who%20believe%20in%20miracles%20from%20heaven%2C%20the%20optimistic%20who%20anticipate%20superwonders%20from%20science%2C%20the%20parochial%20fortunate%20who%20think%20they%20can%20continue%20to%20exist%20on%20islands%20of%20affluence%20in%20a%20sea%20of%20world%20poverty%2C%20and%20the%20na%C3%AFve%20who%20anticipate%20nothing%20can%20look%20to%20the%20future%20with%20equanimity%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hauser%20concluded.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBut%20the%20most%20prescient%20contributor%20to%20%E2%80%9CToward%20the%20Year%202018%E2%80%9D%20was%20the%20M.I.T.%20political%20scientist%20Ithiel%20de%20Sola%20Pool%2C%20whose%20research%20interests%20included%20social%20networks%20and%20computer%20simulation.%20%E2%80%9CBy%202018%20it%20will%20be%20cheaper%20to%20store%20information%20in%20a%20computer%20bank%20than%20on%20paper%2C%E2%80%9D%20Pool%20wrote.%20%E2%80%9CTax%20returns%2C%20social%20security%20records%2C%20census%20forms%2C%20military%20records%2C%20perhaps%20a%20criminal%20record%2C%20hospital%20rec-ords%2C%20security%20clearance%20files%2C%20school%20transcripts%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20bank%20statements%2C%20credit%20ratings%2C%20job%20records%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20more%20would%2C%20by%202018%2C%20be%20stored%20on%20computers%20that%20could%20communicate%20with%20one%20another%20over%20a%20vast%20international%20network.%20You%20could%20find%20out%20anything%20about%20anyone%2C%20without%20ever%20leaving%20your%20desk.%20%E2%80%9CBy%202018%20the%20researcher%20sitting%20at%20his%20console%20will%20be%20able%20to%20compile%20a%20cross-tabulation%20of%20consumer%20purchases%20(from%20store%20records)%20by%20people%20of%20low%20IQ%20(from%20school%20records)%20who%20have%20an%20unemployed%20member%20of%20the%20family%20(from%20social%20security%20records).%20That%20is%2C%20he%20will%20have%20the%20technological%20capability%20to%20do%20this.%20Will%20he%20have%20the%20legal%20right%3F%E2%80%9D%20Pool%20declined%20to%20answer%20that%20question.%20%E2%80%9CThis%20is%20not%20the%20place%20to%20speculate%20how%20society%20will%20achieve%20a%20balance%20between%20its%20desire%20for%20knowledge%20and%20its%20desire%20for%20privacy%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20insisted.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnd%20that%20was%20the%20problem%20with%201968.%20People%20went%20ahead%20and%20built%20those%20things%20without%20worrying%20much%20about%20the%20consequences%2C%20because%20they%20figured%20that%2C%20by%202018%2C%20we%E2%80%99d%20have%20come%20up%20with%20all%20the%20answers.%20Toward%202019!%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Prophecy is a mug’s game. But then, lately, most of us are mugs. 2018 was a banner year for the art of prediction, which is not to say the science, because there really is no science of prediction. Predictive algorithms start out as historians: they study historical data to detect patterns. Then they become prophets: they devise mathematical formulas that explain the pattern, test the formulas against historical data withheld for the purpose, and use the formulas to make predictions about the future. That’s why Amazon, Google, Facebook, and everyone else are collecting your data to feed to their algorithms: they want to turn your past into your future."],["p","This task, like most things, used to be done by hand. In 1968, the Foreign Policy Association, formed in 1918 to promote the League of Nations, celebrated its fiftieth anniversary by publishing a book of predictions about what the world would look like, technology-wise, fifty years on. “Toward the Year 2018” was edited by Emmanuel G. Mesthene, who had served in the White House as an adviser on science and technology and who ran Harvard’s Program on Technology and Society. It makes for distressing reading at the end of 2018, a year that, a golden anniversary ago, looked positively thrilling."],["p","Two things are true about “Toward the Year 2018.” First, most of the machines that people expected would be invented have, in fact, been invented. Second, most of those machines have had consequences wildly different from those anticipated in 1968. It’s bad manners to look at past predictions to see if they’ve come true. Still, if history is any guide, today’s futurists have very little credibility. An algorithm would say the same."],["p","Carlos R. DeCarlo, the director of automation research at I.B.M., covered computers in the book, predicting that, in 2018, “machines will do more of man’s work, but will force man to think more logically.” DeCarlo was consistently half right. He correctly anticipated miniature computers (“very small, portable storage units”), but wrongly predicted the coming of a universal language (“very likely a modified and expanded form of English”). One thing he got terribly wrong: he expressed tragically unfounded confidence that “the political and social institutions of the United States will remain flexible enough to ingest the fruits of science and technology without basic damage to its value systems.”"],["p","Reporting on the future of communication, J. R. Pierce, from Bell Labs, explained that “the Bell System is committed to the provision of a Picturephone service commercially in the early 1970s,” and that, by 2018, face-to-face communication across long distances would be available everywhere: “The transmission of pictures and texts and the distant manipulation of computers and other machines will be added to the transmission of the human voice on a scale that will eventually approach the universality of telephony.” True! “What all this will do to the world I cannot guess,” Pierce admitted, with becoming modesty. “It seems bound to affect us all.”"],["p","Sharp-eyed observers in 1968 were already concerned about the warming of the oceans and the changing of the climate, but the atmospheric-science contributor to “Toward the Year 2018,” Thomas F. Malone, was excited by new technologies that would allow scientists to take control of the earth’s weather and climate. Malone served as the chairman of the Committee on Atmospheric Sciences of the National Academy of Sciences, which, in 1966, had issued a report endorsing “a long-range program of weather control and climate modification,” to be implemented by way of manipulating fog, cloud-seeding, and the “suppression of lightning.” He thought “the probability of success in broad climate modification is likely to exceed 50 percent by the year 2018.” Standing in the way of this objective, he warned, were political obstacles—the international coöperation required for a global climate-change program—and the possibility that, before such a thing could be fully executed, “large-scale climate modification will be effected inadvertently,” because, he had to admit, it appeared that the climate was already changing all on its own. “Carbon dioxide in the atmosphere since 1900 has caused surface temperatures to rise 0.2 degrees C,” he acknowledged, hastening to reassure his readers that, while global temperatures could conceivably keep rising all the way to 2018, there was only “a small probability that these effects will not be tolerable.”"],["p","The only real doomsayer was the demographer Philip M. Hauser. He calculated that, by 2018, the world’s population would reach 9.7 billion (he was two billion over), with the steepest growth in Asia and Latin America, and the slowest in Europe. Also, that the distance between the rich and the poor, and between wealthy nations and poor nations, would widen. “Given the present outlook, only the faithful who believe in miracles from heaven, the optimistic who anticipate superwonders from science, the parochial fortunate who think they can continue to exist on islands of affluence in a sea of world poverty, and the naïve who anticipate nothing can look to the future with equanimity,” Hauser concluded."],["p","But the most prescient contributor to “Toward the Year 2018” was the M.I.T. political scientist Ithiel de Sola Pool, whose research interests included social networks and computer simulation. “By 2018 it will be cheaper to store information in a computer bank than on paper,” Pool wrote. “Tax returns, social security records, census forms, military records, perhaps a criminal record, hospital rec-ords, security clearance files, school transcripts . . . bank statements, credit ratings, job records,” and more would, by 2018, be stored on computers that could communicate with one another over a vast international network. You could find out anything about anyone, without ever leaving your desk. “By 2018 the researcher sitting at his console will be able to compile a cross-tabulation of consumer purchases (from store records) by people of low IQ (from school records) who have an unemployed member of the family (from social security records). That is, he will have the technological capability to do this. Will he have the legal right?” Pool declined to answer that question. “This is not the place to speculate how society will achieve a balance between its desire for knowledge and its desire for privacy,” he insisted."],["p","And that was the problem with 1968. People went ahead and built those things without worrying much about the consequences, because they figured that, by 2018, we’d have come up with all the answers. Toward 2019! ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c7741e4c73c088d774c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Predictions","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"predictions"},{"id":"5c2e1c77397f5b30646d05e7","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"2018","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"2018"},{"id":"5c2e1c7841c92e2c9b85da16","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Technology","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"technology"},{"id":"5c2e1c762710c62d10815407","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Politics","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"politics"},{"id":"5c2e1c787e716b454591ada3","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"“Towards is a staff writer at The New Yorker and a professor of history at Harvard University. Her latest book, “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/These-Truths-History-United-States/dp/0393635244\">These Truths: A History of the United States\u003c/a>,” came out in September.","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Jill Lepore, a staff writer, has been contributing to ",["em","The New Yorker"]," since 2005. Her books include “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Name-War-Philips-American-Identity/dp/0375702628"},"The Name of War"],",” which won the Bancroft Prize; ",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/New-York-Burning-Conspiracy-Eighteenth-Century/dp/1400032261"},"“New York Burning"],",” which was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in history; “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Story-America-Essays-Origins/dp/0691159599"},"The Story of America"],",” which was short-listed for the ",["em",{"class":"small"},"PEN"]," Literary Award for the Art of the Essay; “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Book-Ages-Life-Opinions-Franklin/dp/0307948838"},"Book of Ages"],",” a finalist for the National Book Award; and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Secret-History-Wonder-Woman/dp/0804173400"},"The Secret History of Wonder Woman"],".” Her latest book, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/These-Truths-History-United-States/dp/0393635244"},"These Truths: A History of the United States"],",” came out in September, 2018. Lepore received her Ph.D. in American Studies from Yale in 1995 and is the David Woods Kemper ’41 Professor of American History at Harvard University. In 2012, she was named a Harvard College Professor, in recognition of distinction in undergraduate
