%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb68822322ea4b3b6e7%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EFirst%20of%20all%2C%20you%20should%20eat%20there.%20Second%2C%20the%20concept%20is%20%E2%80%9Cpick%20%26amp%3B%20mix%E2%80%9D%3A%20each%20diner%20chooses%20two%20of%20the%20menu%E2%80%99s%20roughly%20two%20dozen%20dishes%2C%20which%20come%20perfectly%20portioned%20in%20small%20ceramic%20bowls%2C%20a%20scoop%20of%20jasmine%20or%20red%20rice%20on%20the%20side.%20Go%20with%20a%20date%20and%20you%E2%80%99re%20a%20sixth%20of%20the%20way%20through%20the%20menu.%20Show%20up%20in%20a%20group%20of%20four%20and%20it%E2%80%99s%20easy%20to%20make%20a%20bowl%20mosaic%20on%20one%20of%20the%20bright-yellow%20communal%20picnic%20tables.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-small%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EIt%E2%80%99s%20a%20very%20Thai%20way%20to%20eat%2C%20which%20you%20don%E2%80%99t%20see%20very%20often%20outside%20of%20Thailand.%20The%20closest%20thi C%2522name%2522%253A%2522feature-small%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522image%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522image%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fphotos%25252F5c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3EBy%20the%20time%20you%20get%20to%20dessert%2C%20the%20choice%20is%20especially%20easy%3A%20there%E2%80%99s%20just%20one%20option%2C%20which%20changes%20each%20night.%20The%20only%20question%20is%20whether%20you%20want%20it.%20Based%20on%20the%20young%20coconut%20braised%20in%20its%20own%20milk%20and%20topped%20with%20wedges%20of%20steamed%20taro%E2%80%94or%20even%20the%20beguilingly%20unusual%20steamed%20coconut%20sticky%20rice%20topped%20with%20flakes%20of%20salty-sweet%20dried%20mackerel%E2%80%94the%20answer%20is%20yes.%20%3Cem%3E(%E2%80%9CPick%20%26amp%3B%20mix%E2%80%9D%20%2416%20at%20lunch%20and%20%2418%20at%20dinner%3B%20full-sized%20entr%C3%A9es%20%2415-%2420.)%3C%2Fem%3E%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","When dining out in New York, the spectre of crippling indecision lurks around every corner. Once you get past the overwhelming question of where to eat, you’re still faced with the menu: what to order? Taladwat, a new Thai restaurant in Hell’s Kitchen—a collaboration between David and Vanida Bank, of the nearby Pure Thai Cookhouse and Land Thai Kitchen, on the Upper West Side, and Brian Ghaw, of Feast, in the East Village, which offers family-style meals—provides an easy answer to both of these questions."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1c1eb68822322ea4b3b6e7%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb68822322ea4b3b6e7%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1c1eb68822322ea4b3b6e7%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1c1eb68822322ea4b3b6e7"}]],["p","First of all, you should eat there. Second, the concept is “pick & mix”: each diner chooses two of the menu’s roughly two dozen dishes, which come perfectly portioned in small ceramic bowls, a scoop of jasmine or red rice on the side. Go with a date and you’re a sixth of the way through the menu. Show up in a group of four and it’s easy to make a bowl mosaic on one of the bright-yellow communal picnic tables."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1c1eb6286bc006c37e8521"}]],["p","It’s a very Thai way to eat, which you don’t see very often outside of Thailand. The closest thing I’ve experienced in New York is the wonderful Khao Kang, in Elmhurst, a tiny, counter-service spot where a daily rotation of dishes is kept in a steam table. Diners choose two or three; the bowls come on a tray and you seat yourself. The tagline of that restaurant is “What we cooked at home, we made them here,” and at Taladwat the guiding principle is similar. The restaurant is full service, but the food is “countryside Thai,” homey and unmodifiable, served “community potluck” style from ceramic crocks in the semi-open kitchen, and meant to evoke Thailand’s temple festivals. (Taladwat means, roughly, “temple market.”)"],["p","Pure Thai and Land have long stood out among Manhattan’s Thai restaurants for their highly accessible but unusually tight, fine-tuned menus. David Bank, their chef, was born and raised in Thailand and, after moving to the U.S., trained with Jean-Georges Vongerichten and Tadashi Ono. At Taladwat, the cooking feels like a purer, less compromised expression of his roots, bolder with traditional ingredients and flavors."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1c1eb68c22f948fa9ba673%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb68c22f948fa9ba673%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1c1eb68c22f948fa9ba673%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1c1eb68c22f948fa9ba673"}]],["p","Even the mildest palates will find solace in the marvellously subtle winter-melon soup, which tastes cleanly and comfortingly of the skinless chicken thigh it contains, nestled with soft wedges of silky melon. The pad ped beef, coins of meat strewn with bamboo shoots, long chilies, sweet basil, and fresh curry paste, will satisfy a spice hound. Diners who seek spice without heat can do no better than the turmeric curry chicken—a hunk of dark meat and some stewed cipollinis in a rich coconut-milk broth—or the crabmeat tom turmeric, also in coconut milk but sparklingly bright with lemongrass and galangal, a citrusy root similar to ginger."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1c1eb63e17f81da2a3b5f2%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb63e17f81da2a3b5f2%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1c1eb63e17f81da2a3b5f2%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1c1eb63e17f81da2a3b5f2"}]],["p","Those un-averse to the funkiest flavors of the sea will be delighted by dishes like the sour curry fish, a pungent mix of skin-on sea bass, braised daikon, and green papaya in a tamarind-chili broth, and the whole fried Thai mackerel, served with an intensely concentrated sesame-soy dipping sauce. To experience the entire spectrum in one bite, order a side of the house-made chili paste, served in a heaping scoop that is hideously ugly but psychedelic on the tongue, a thrilling roller coaster of salt, sugar, fish, funk, and heat. Eat it straight with a spoon, wrap it in lettuce from the basket of leafy greens, herbs, and cucumbers that arrives on every table (there are complimentary pickles, too), or smear it on a side order of pillowy Thai omelette, flecked with cha-om, a Southeast Asian vegetable that looks like dill but tastes milder and sweeter, with a snappier texture."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1c1eb681ab3335f580e038"}]],["p","By the time you get to dessert, the choice is especially easy: there’s just one option, which changes each night. The only question is whether you want it. Based on the young coconut braised in its own milk and topped with wedges of steamed taro—or even the beguilingly unusual steamed coconut sticky rice topped with flakes of salty-sweet dried mackerel—the answer is yes. ",["em","(“Pick & mix” $16 at lunch and $18 at dinner; full-sized entrées $15-$20.)"]," ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2019/01/07/pick-and-mix-boldly-traditional-thai-dishes-at-taladwat","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c79ee7fe02cbd163329","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Food","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"food"},{"id":"5c2e1c7c397f5b30646d05f2","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Restaurants","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"restaurants"}],"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"5909f8e58b51cf59fc4246b4","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5909f8e58b51cf59fc4246b4","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Tables %E2%80%9CHAVEN%E2%80%99T%20WE%2C%20LOU%3F%20HAVEN%E2%80%99T%20WE%20CALLED%20AN%20AMBULANCE%3F!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20that%20moment%2C%20two%20E.M.T.%20workers%20came%20in%2C%20both%20young%20and%20bearded%2C%20like%20lumberjacks.%20Each%20took%20an%20elbow%20and%20helped%20my%20father%20to%20stand.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CAre%20we%20going%20somewhere%3F%E2%80%9D%20he%20asked.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CBACK%20TO%20THE%20HOSPITAL!%E2%80%9D%20the%20woman%20shouted.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CAll%20right%2C%E2%80%9D%20my%20father%20said.%20%E2%80%9CO.K.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThey%20wheeled%20him%20out%2C%20and%20the%20woman%20explained%20that%2C%20while%20the%20staff%20would%20remove%20bloodstains%20from%20the%20carpet%2C%20it%20was%20the%20family%E2%80%99s%20job%20to%20get%20them%20off%20any%20privately%20owned%20furniture.%20%E2%80%9CI%20can%20bring%20you%20some%20towels%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20suggested.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EA%20few%20moments%20later%2C%20another%20aide%20walked%20into%20the%20room.%20%E2%80%9CExcuse%20me%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9Cbut%20are%20you%20the%20famous%20son%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20a%20pretty%20sorry%20excuse%20for%20famous%2C%E2%80%9D%20I%20told%20her.%20%E2%80%9CBut%2C%20yes%2C%20I%E2%80%99m%20his%20son.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CSo%20you%E2%80%99re%20Dave%3F%20Dave%20Chappelle%3F%20Can%20I%20have%20your%20autograph%3F%20Actually%2C%20can%20I%20have%20two%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CUm%2C%20sure%2C%E2%80%9D%20I%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EI%E2%80%99d%20just%20joined%20Hugh%20in%20cleaning%20the%20easy%20chair%20when%20the%20woman%2C%20who%20seemed%20slightly%20nervous%2C%20the%20way%20you%20might%20be%20around%20a%20world-famous%20comedian%20who%20is%20young%20and%20black%20and%20has%20his%20whole%20life%20ahead%20of%20him%2C%20returned%20for%20two%20more%20autographs.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20the%20worst%20son%20in%20the%20world%2C%E2%80%9D%20I%20told%20her%2C%20reaching%20for%20the%20scraps%20of%20paper%20she%20was%20holding%20out.%20%E2%80%9CMy%20father%20fell%20on%20April%207th%2C%20and%20this%20is%20the%20first%20time%20I%E2%80%99ve%20visited%2C%20the%20first%20time%20I%E2%80%99ve%20%3Cem%3Etalked%3C%2Fem%3E%20to%20him%2C%20even.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%20put%20yourself%20down%20too%20much%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20woman%20said.%20%E2%80%9CJust%20pick%20up%20the%20phone%20every%20so%20often%E2%80%94that%E2%80%99s%20what%20I%20do%20with%20my%20mother.%E2%80%9D%20She%20offered%20a%20forgiving%20smile.%20%E2%80%9CYou%20can%20make%20that%20second%20autograph%20to%20my%20supervisor.%E2%80%9D%20And%20she%20gave%20me%20a%20name.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20blood%20on%20our%20wet%20rags%20looked%20even%20faker%20than%20the%20blood%20I%E2%80%99d%20watched%20falling%20from%20my%20father%E2%80%99s%20ear.%20I%20took%20a%20few%20halfhearted%20swipes%20at%20the%20easy%20chair%2C%20but%20it%20was%20Hugh%20who%20did%20most%20of%20the%20work.%20Mainly%2C%20I%20looked%20at%20the%20things%20my%20dad%20had%20decorated%20his%20room%20with%3A%20Father%20Time%2C%20a%20number%20of%20the%20streetscapes%20he%20and%20my%20mother%20bought%20in%20the%20seventies%2C%20rocks%20he%E2%80%99d%20carried%20back%20from%20fishing%20trips%2C%20each%20with%20a%20date%20and%20the%20name%20of%20the%20river%20it%20had%20come%20from%20written%20on%20it.%20All%20of%20it%20was%20so%20depressing%20to%20me.%20Then%20again%2C%20even%20a%20unicorn%20would%20have%20looked%20dingy%20in%20this%20place.%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20know%20if%20it%20was%20the%20lighting%2C%20or%20the%20height%20of%20the%20ceiling.%20Perhaps%20it%20was%20the%20hospital%20bed%20against%20the%20wall%2C%20or%20the%20floor-length%20curtains%20that%20looked%20as%20if%20they%E2%80%99d%20come%20from%20a%20funeral%20parlor.%20Down%20the%20hall%2C%20a%20dozen%20or%20so%20residents%2C%20most%20in%20wheelchairs%20and%20some%20drooling%20onto%20bibs%2C%20were%20watching%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EM*A*S*H%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%9D%20on%20television.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EI%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20help%20but%20think%20of%20Mayview%2C%20the%20nursing%20home%20my%20father%20put%20his%20mother%20in%2C%20back%20in%20the%20mid-seventies.%20It%20seemed%20like%20only%20yesterday%20that%20I%E2%80%99d%20gone%20with%20him%20to%20see%20her.%20If%20now%20here%20%3Cem%3EI%3C%2Fem%3E%20was%2C%20visiting%20him%20in%20a%20similar%20place%2C%20wouldn%E2%80%99t%20it%20be%20me%2C%20in%20the%20blink%20of%20an%20eye%2C%20in%20my%20own%20retirement%20center%2C%20%3Cem%3Eme%3C%2Fem%3E%20the%20frail%20widower%20reduced%20to%20a%20single%20room%3F%20Only%20I%20won%E2%80%99t%20have%20children%20to%20look%20after%20me%2C%20the%20way%20my%20father%20has%20Lisa%2C%20who%20had%20been%20extraordinary%2C%20and%20my%20brother%20Paul%20and%20Amy%20and%20Gretchen.%20My%20sister-in-law%20Kathy%20had%20outdone%20everyone%2C%20stopping%20by%20sometimes%20twice%20a%20day%2C%20taking%20Dad%20to%20lunch%2C%20rubbing%20lotion%20into%20his%20feet.%20I%20was%20the%20only%20exception.%20Me.%20Dave%20Chappelle.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CDo%20you%20think%20we%20can%20get%20a%20few%20pictures%20together%3F%E2%80%9D%20one%20of%20the%20nurses%20asked%20me%20on%20my%20way%20out.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9COh%2C%20wait%2C%20I%20want%20one%2C%20too%2C%E2%80%9D%20another%20woman%20said%2C%20and%20another%20after%20her.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CLook%2C%E2%80%9D%20I%20imagined%20them%20telling%20people%20afterward.%20%E2%80%9CI%20got%20a%20photo%20of%20me%20with%20Dave%20Chappelle.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CNo%2C%20you%20didn%E2%80%99t%2C%E2%80%9D%20they%E2%80%99d%20be%20told.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOf%20course%2C%20I%E2%80%99d%20be%20long%20gone%20by%20then.%20Like%20always.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The night before his ninety-fifth-birthday party, my father fell while turning around in his kitchen. My sister Lisa and her husband, Bob, dropped by hours later to hook up his new TV and discovered him on the floor, disoriented and in pain. He fell again after they righted him, so an ambulance was called. At the hospital, they met up with our sister Gretchen, and with Amy, who’d just flown in from New York to attend the party, which was now cancelled. “It was really weird,” she said when we spoke on the phone the following morning. “Dad thought Lisa was Mom, and when the doctor asked him where he was he answered, ‘Syracuse’—where he went to college. Then he got mad and said, ‘You’re sure asking a lot of questions.’ As if that’s not normal for a doctor. I think he thought this was just ",["em","some guy"]," he was talking to.”"],["p","Fortunately, he was lucid again by the following afternoon. That was the hard part for everyone—seeing him so confused."],["p","On the night that my father fell, I was in Princeton, the fourth of eighty cities I would be travelling to for work. On the morning he was moved from the hospital to a rehabilitation center, I was on my way to Ann Arbor. Over the next week, he had a few little strokes, the sort people don’t notice right away. One affected his peripheral vision, and another his short-term memory. He’d wanted to return home after leaving rehab, but by this point there was no way he could continue to live alone. I wrote him a letter, saying, in part, “It isn’t safe for you at the house anymore, at least not on your own, and this concerns me. I need you to live long enough to see Donald Trump impeached.”"],["p","We’d fought bitterly after the election, and I knew it would be just my luck: my father would die, and the very next day the President would go down, denying me a well-deserved opportunity to gloat."],["p","I’m not sure where I was when my father moved into his retirement home. Springmoor, it’s called. I saw it, finally, four months after his fall, when Hugh and I flew to North Carolina. It was early August, and we arrived to find him in an easy chair, blood flowing from his ear at what seemed to me like a pretty alarming rate. It looked fake, like beet juice, and was being dabbed at by a nurse’s assistant. “Oh, hello,” my father said, his voice soft and weary-sounding."],["p","I thought he didn’t know who I was, but then he added my name and held out his hand. “David.” He looked behind me. “Hugh.” Someone had wrapped his head with gauze, and when he leaned back he resembled the late English poet Edith Sitwell, very distinguished-looking, almost imperious. His eyebrows were thin and barely perceptible. It was the same with his lashes. I guess that, like the hairs on his arms and legs, they just got tired of holding on."],["p","“So what happened?” I asked, though I already knew. Lisa had told me that morning on the phone that his grandfather clock had fallen on him. It was made of walnut and bronze and had an abstract human face on it, surrounded by numbers that were tilted at odd angles. My mother always referred to it as Mr. Creech, after the artist who made it, but my dad calls it Father Time."],["p","I’d said to Hugh after hanging up with Lisa, “When you’re ninety-five, and Father Time ",["em","literally"]," knocks you to the ground, don’t you think he’s maybe trying to tell you something?”"],["p","“He insisted on moving it himself,” the woman attempting to stanch the bleeding said, “and it cut his ear. We sent him to the hospital for stitches, but now it’s started up again, maybe because he’s on blood thinners, so we’ve called an ambulance.” She raised her voice, even though my father is not hard of hearing. “HAVEN’T WE, LOU? HAVEN’T WE CALLED AN AMBULANCE?!”"],["p","At that moment, two E.M.T. workers came in, both young and bearded, like lumberjacks. Each took an elbow and helped my father to stand."],["p","“Are we going somewhere?” he asked."],["p","“BACK TO THE HOSPITAL!” the woman shouted."],["p","“All right,” my father said. “O.K.”"],["p","They wheeled him out, and the woman explained that, while the staff would remove bloodstains from the carpet, it was the family’s job to get them off any privately owned furniture. “I can bring you some towels,” she suggested."],["p","A few moments later, another aide walked into the room. “Excuse me,” she said, “but are you the famous son?”"],["p","“I’m a pretty sorry excuse for famous,” I told her. “But, yes, I’m his son.”"],["p","“So you’re Dave? Dave Chappelle? Can I have your autograph? Actually, can I have two?”"],["p","“Um, sure,” I said."],["p","I’d just joined Hugh in cleaning the easy chair when the woman, who seemed slightly nervous, the way you might be around a world-famous comedian who is young and black and has his whole life ahead of him, returned for two more autographs."],["p","“I’m the worst son in the world,” I told her, reaching for the scraps of paper she was holding out. “My father fell on April 7th, and this is the first time I’ve visited, the first time I’ve ",["em","talked"]," to him, even.”"],["p","“You put yourself down too much,” the woman said. “Just pick up the phone every so often—that’s what I do with my mother.” She offered a forgiving smile. “You can make that second autograph to my supervisor.” And she gave me a name."],["p","The blood on our wet rags looked even faker than the blood I’d watched falling from my father’s ear. I took a few halfhearted swipes at the easy chair, but it was Hugh who did most of the work. Mainly, I looked at the things my dad had decorated his room with: Father Time, a number of the streetscapes he and my mother bought in the seventies, rocks he’d carried back from fishing trips, each with a date and the name of the river it had come from written on it. All of it was so depressing to me. Then again, even a unicorn would have looked dingy in this place. I don’t know if it was the lighting, or the height of the ceiling. Perhaps it was the hospital bed against the wall, or the floor-length curtains that looked as if they’d come from a funeral parlor. Down the hall, a dozen or so residents, most in wheelchairs and some drooling onto bibs, were watching “",["em",{"class":"small"},"M*A*S*H"],"” on television."],["p","I couldn’t help but think of Mayview, the nursing home my father put his mother in, back in the mid-seventies. It seemed like only yesterday that I’d gone with him to see her. If now here ",["em","I"]," was, visiting him in a similar place, wouldn’t it be me, in the blink of an eye, in my own retirement center, ",["em","me"]," the frail widower reduced to a single room? Only I won’t have children to look after me, the way my father has Lisa, who had been extraordinary, and my brother Paul and Amy and Gretchen. My sister-in-law Kathy had outdone everyone, stopping by sometimes twice a day, taking Dad to lunch, rubbing lotion into his feet. I was the only exception. Me. Dave Chappelle."],["p","“Do you think we can get a few pictures together?” one of the nurses asked me on my way out."],["p","“Oh, wait, I want one, too,” another woman said, and another after her."],["p","“Look,” I imagined them telling people afterward. “I got a photo of me with Dave Chappelle.”"],["p","“No, you didn’t,” they’d be told."],["p","Of course, I’d be long gone by then. Like and I drove to our house on Emerald Isle—the Sea Section—after leaving Springmoor, and were joined a few days later by his older brother John, who’d brought two boys: his seven-year-old grandson Harrison and Harrison’s half brother Austin, who was eleven. All three live in a small town on a strait several hours west of Seattle. The kids had never encountered water they could walk into without shrieking from the cold. They’d never seen fine sand or pelicans. I thought they’d be thrilled, but it was hard luring them away from the portable gaming console they’d brought from Washington—a Nintendo Switch."],["p","“What?” Harrison cried, exasperated, after touring the house. “You don’t have a TV we can hook this up to!”"],["p","He was one of those children who’d skipped cute and gone straight to handsome. I supposed this could change over the next few decades: his nose might grow out of proportion to the rest of his face. He could lose his chin or a cheek in some sort of accident, but even then he’d have his eyes, which were cornflower blue, and a pouty, almost feminine mouth, the lower lip slightly larger than the top one. 20out.%20Thus%20she%20was%20spared%20the%20loneliness%20so%20many%20old%20people%20have%20to%20suffer.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20last%20time%20I%20went%20to%20her%20house%2C%20I%20found%20her%20on%20the%20back%20patio.%20It%20was%20one%20in%20the%20afternoon%20and%20she%20was%20having%20a%20Martini.%20%E2%80%9CKarla%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20called%20to%20her%20assistant.%20%E2%80%9CGet%20David%20here%20something%20to%20drink.%20What%20would%20you%20like%2C%20sweetie%2C%20a%20vodka%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CJust%20some%20water%2C%E2%80%9D%20I%20said%2C%20settling%20in%20beside%20her.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWater%20with%20vodka%20in%20it%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CNo%2C%20just%20the%20water.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CBring%20him%20a%20vodka-tonic%2C%E2%80%9D%20Phyllis%20instructed%2C%20forgetting%2C%20I%20guess%2C%20that%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20drink.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20Karla%E2%80%99s%20absence%2C%20she%20pointed%20to%20two%20pigeons%20parading%20across%20her%20beautifully%20landscaped%20lawn.%20%E2%80%9CAll%20those%20two%20do%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said%2C%20lifting%20her%20glass%20with%20her%20blue-veined%20hand%2C%20the%20fingers%20as%20thin%20and%20brittle%20as%20twigs%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20mean%20%3Cem%3Eall%3C%2Fem%3E%20they%20do%2C%20is%20fuck.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Later that afternoon, for the fourth time that week, Hugh saw someone taking pictures of our house. “I think they read your last book,” he said. “See!” I shouted to Harrison in the next room."],["p","He was into his game and didn’t answer."],["p","“They’re most likely just taking pictures of the Sea Section sign,” I said to Hugh. “It ",["em","is"]," a pretty good name for a beach house.” I then told him about a place our neighbor Bermey had mentioned that was farther up the coast and was called You Didn’t Get This, Bitch. “That probably gets photographed as well,” I said, “especially by divorced men.”"],["p","The picture-taking on the street side of our house was nothing compared with what was going on out back. When I was young, sea turtles would lay their eggs on the beach, and no one thought much about it. Now, though, it’s a huge deal."],["p","Loggerheads are on bumper stickers and signs. They’re an attraction, like the wild horses near Ocracoke. The spot where the eggs are laid is marked, and when the time arrives for them to hatch a team of volunteers from the Turtle Patrol is dispatched."],["p","A bright-yellow stake had been driven into the sand near the foot of the wooden staircase that led from our house to the beach, and, the morning after the boys arrived, volunteers dug a trench that would make it easier for the hatchlings to find the ocean. Now it was lined on either side with folding chairs, and the Turtle Patrol nest-sitting. I said to Hugh, “It’s like the red carpet at the Academy Awards.”"],["p","People walking down the beach, seeing the yellow caution tape and the trench watched over by do-gooders in bright Turtle Patrol T-shirts, wandered over to ask questions, and the crowd grew. At night, they’d sit with infrared flashlights, intently staring down, watching for the slightest movement, with their cameras at the ready."],["p","“It’s actually called a ",["em","boil"],",” Kathy told me. “That’s because when the eggs hatch, and the babies claw their way to the surface, the sand churns.”"],["p","“Isn’t that exciting?” I said to the boys."],["p","“Uh-huh,” they answered. “Sure.”"],["p","“Really?” I said. “You’re not interested in nature?” When I was their age, it was pretty much all I cared about—that and stealing and spying on people. I told them about the hideous-looking silver possum that had climbed up the front stairs of the house last Thanksgiving. “We fed her fruit and leftovers, and you should have seen the way her hands grabbed the food, almost like a human. Every night she came.”"],["p","Austin politely but vacantly said, “Wow.”"],["p","The only way to get the boys’ attention was by throwing one of the stink bombs I’d bought a week earlier, on Cape Cod. I’d thought the smell would be negligible—maybe like an old sock—but instead it cleared not just the room where the boys were playing Mario Kart but an entire side of the house. It was sulfur, for the most part, what I imagine Satan’s bathroom would smell like after he’d been on the toilet with the ",["em","National Review"]," for a while."],["p","“Goddammit,” Hugh said, holding his nose and opening the front and back doors, letting the hot, humid air in. “And we have company coming!”"],["p","“Why you . . . book writer,” Harrison scolded. He was wearing Minecraft pajamas and looked like a male model who’d been put into a machine and made small."],["p","Of the two brothers, Austin had the sweeter temperament. He’d ask questions and offer to help out. His voice had an old-fashioned quality to it, like a boy’s in a radio serial. “Gee willikers!” you could imagine him saying, if that were the name of a video game in which things blew up and women got shot in the back of the head."],["p","Compared with other kids I’ve known, the two were actually pretty good. Both liked fish, and they always ate everything on their plates. Rarely did they bicker, and when they did it was over within a minute or two. There was no crying, and, better still, no sulking. That, to me, is unbearable. “Oh, move on, for God’s sake,” my mother used to say when we glared and stewed, vowing to never forget the injustice of egg salad, or potato chips that were from the bottom of the bag, and broken."],["p","The boys weren’t terribly interested in the turtle boil taking place in back of the house, but I thought they might change their minds if they saw the baby loggerheads. The eggs were the size of Ping-Pong balls, and were supposed to hatch on Monday. Then Tuesday. Then Wednesday. At night, we’d walk to the top of our stairway and see if there was any action. “Aren’t we lucky to have a front-row seat!” I’d say."],["p","“If you say so,” Harrison would answer."],["p","My fifteen-year-old niece, Maddy, had the same attitude. She was at the beach as well, though you’d hardly know it. We’d see her briefly at lunch and dinner, but the rest of her time was spent in seclusion, her face six inches from her phone. Was there an equivalent when I was young? I wondered. I don’t recall my parents crying, “You and that goddam transistor radio!”"],["p","The boys slept in what we’d come to think of as my father’s room. It was strange being at the beach without him, but we didn’t yet have the proper equipment: a walk-in shower, bars beside the toilet, and so on. A year earlier, he hadn’t needed those things, but that’s the difference between ninety-four and ninety-five. The day before his fall, he’d driven to the gym, not knowing that it was his last time behind the wheel of a car, his last night in his own bed. There would be a lot of that in his immediate future: the last time he could dress himself, the last time he could walk."],["p","I worried that he had entered a period when it would be one thing after another, death by a thousand cuts: a fall, a stroke, an accident with a grandfather clock. That’s how it was with the other extremely old people I’ve known in my life: the woman across the road from us in Normandy, our next-door neighbor in London. Phyllis Diller. Late in her life, the two of us became friends. She lived in a mansion in Brentwood, and each time I’d visit her there she’d be a bit less able; her eyes wouldn’t stop watering, or she couldn’t get up from a chair without help. Phyllis was lucky in that she could remain at home, and hire round-the-clock help; lucky, too, that she was famous—a legend by any definition. All day, disciples came to pay homage to her, and every night she went out. Thus she was spared the loneliness so many old people have to suffer."],["p","The last time I went to her house, I found her on the back patio. It was one in the afternoon and she was having a Martini. “Karla,” she called to her assistant. “Get David here something to drink. What would you like, sweetie, a vodka?”"],["p","“Just some water,” I said, settling in beside her."],["p","“Water with vodka in it?”"],["p","“No, just the water.”"],["p","“Bring him a vodka-tonic,” Phyllis instructed, forgetting, I guess, that I don’t drink."],["p","In Karla’s absence, she pointed to two pigeons parading across her beautifully landscaped lawn. “All those two do,” she said, lifting her glass with her blue-veined hand, the fingers as thin and brittle as twigs, “I mean ",["em","all"]," they do, is fuck.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EWe%20were%20off%20somewhere%20when%20most%20of%20the%20turtles%20hatched%2C%20some%20sixty-three%20of%20them.%20We%20missed%20the%20six%20that%20clawed%20their%20way%20out%20the%20following%20day%20as%20well.%20Hugh%E2%80%99s%20brother%20left%20with%20the%20boys%20on%20a%20Sunday%2C%20and%20a%20few%20hours%20later%20the%20final%20one%20burst%20forth.%20I%20was%20on%20a%20long%20walk%20when%20it%20happened%2C%20and%20returned%20minutes%20after%20it%20had%20stumbled%20down%20the%20trench%20and%20into%20the%20ocean.%20%E2%80%9CIt%20was%20heartbreaking%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hugh%20reported.%20He%20was%20standing%20in%20his%20bathing%20suit%20on%20the%20beach%20behind%20our%20house%2C%20one%20in%20a%20crowd%20of%20fifty%20or%20so.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWhat%20was%20so%20sad%3F%E2%80%9D%20I%20asked.%20%E2%80%9CI%20mean%2C%20he%20made%20it%2C%20right%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHugh%E2%80%99s%20voice%20cracked.%20%E2%80%9CYes%2C%20but%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20he%20was%20just%20so%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20alone.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","We were off somewhere when most of the turtles hatched, some sixty-three of them. We missed the six that clawed their way out the following day as well. Hugh’s brother left with the boys on a Sunday, and a few hours later the final one burst forth. I was on a long walk when it happened, and returned minutes after it had stumbled down the trench and into the ocean. “It was heartbreaking,” Hugh reported. He was standing in his bathing suit on the beach behind our house, one in a crowd of fifty or so."],["p","“What was so sad?” I asked. “I mean, he made it, right?”"],["p","Hugh’s voice cracked. “Yes, but . . . he was just so . . . alone.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20can%E2%80%99t%20believe%20you%20missed%20it%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said%20as%20we%20were%20going%20to%20bed%20that%20night.%20He%E2%80%99d%20just%20pulled%20his%20shirt%20off%2C%20and%20I%20took%20a%20moment%20to%20admire%20his%20tan.%20It%20was%20nothing%20he%E2%80%99d%20worked%20for%3B%20rather%2C%20it%20just%20came%2C%20the%20result%20of%20all%20the%20hours%20he%E2%80%99d%20spent%20in%20the%20ocean%2C%20occasionally%20with%20the%20boys%20but%20mainly%20on%20his%20own%2C%20swimming%20like%20some%20sort%20of%20creature%2C%20one%20moment%20on%20his%20back%20and%20the%20next%20on%20his%20stomach%2C%20turning%20like%20a%20chicken%20on%20a%20spit.%20He%E2%80%99s%20done%20this%20since%20childhood%2C%20and%20as%20a%20result%20his%20shoulders%20are%20so%20broad%20I%20can%20barely%20get%20my%20arms%20around%20them.%20Still%20I%20try.%20He%20slips%20beneath%20the%20covers%20and%20I%20cleave%20to%20him%20like%20a%20barnacle%2C%20thinking%20of%20all%20the%20couples%20I%20know%20who%20no%20longer%20share%20a%20bed.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20snores!%E2%80%9D%20the%20wife%20will%20tell%20me%2C%20or%20%E2%80%9CI%20need%20my%20own%20space.%E2%80%9D%20I%E2%80%99d%20hate%20separate%20rooms%2C%20though%20a%20sleep-apnea%20machine%20might%20be%20a%20deal%20breaker%2C%20or%20incontinence.%20Definitely%20incontinence.%20I%20can%E2%80%99t%20predict%20what%E2%80%99s%20waiting%20for%20us%2C%20lurking%20on%20the%20other%20side%20of%20our%20late%20middle%20age%2C%20but%20I%20know%20it%20can%E2%80%99t%20be%20good.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","“I can’t believe you missed it,” he said as we were going to bed that night. He’d just pulled his shirt off, and I took a moment to admire his tan. It was nothing he’d worked for; rather, it just came, the result of all the hours he’d spent in the ocean, occasionally with the boys but mainly on his own, swimming like some sort of creature, one moment on his back and the next on his stomach, turning like a chicken on a spit. He’s done this since childhood, and as a result his shoulders are so broad I can barely get my arms around them. Still I try. He slips beneath the covers and I cleave to him like a barnacle, thinking of all the couples I know who no longer share a bed. “He snores!” the wife will tell me, or “I need my own space.” I’d hate separate rooms, though a sleep-apnea machine might be a deal breaker, or incontinence. Definitely incontinence. I can’t predict what’s waiting for us, lurking on the other side of our late middle age, but I know it can’t be good."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EBefore%20returning%20to%20England%2C%20we%20drove%20back%20to%20Raleigh%2C%20and%20ate%20lunch%20with%20my%20father%2C%20who%20had%20a%20biscuit-size%20bandage%20on%20his%20ear%20and%20was%20relying%20on%20a%20walker%20that%20had%20his%20name%20and%20room%20number%20written%20on%20it%20in%20Magic%20Marker.%20I%20didn%E2%80%99t%20want%20to%20meet%20at%20Springmoor%E2%80%94%E2%80%9CYou%20told%20us%20you%20were%20Dave%20Chappelle!%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94so%20Lisa%20and%20Bob%20drove%20him%20to%20a%20caf%C3%A9%20that%20we%E2%80%99d%20all%20agreed%20on.%20Watching%20from%20a%20distance%20as%20he%20slowly%20advanced%20toward%20the%20table%2C%20I%20was%20struck%20by%20how%20breakable%20he%20seemed.%20Still%2C%20his%20spirits%20were%20high%2C%20and%20he%20was%20engaging%2C%20funny%20even%2C%20especially%20when%20talking%20about%20Springmoor%2C%20and%20the%20way%20the%20staff%20will%20walk%20in%20whenever%20they%20feel%20like%20it%3A%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20a%20problem%2C%20because%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20always%20feel%20like%20wearing%20clothes%2C%20if%20you%20catch%20my%20drift.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CSure%2C%E2%80%9D%20I%20said%2C%20thinking%2C%20What%E2%80%99s%20wrong%20with%20underpants%2C%20at%20least%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EKathy%20met%20us%20at%20the%20restaurant%20as%20well%2C%20and%20midway%20through%20our%20meal%20she%20told%20my%20father%20about%20the%20baby%20loggerheads%20she%E2%80%99d%20seen%20hatching%20a%20few%20days%20earlier%20on%20Emerald%20Isle.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9COh%2C%20right%2C%E2%80%9D%20my%20father%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThey%E2%80%99ve%20laid%20their%20eggs%20there%20for%20centuries.%20For%20even%20longer%2C%20I%20imagine.%20Aeons.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CAnd%20the%20last%20one%20to%20pop%20up%20out%20of%20the%20sand%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20reported%2C%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20very%20last%20one%2C%20the%20Turtle%20Patrol%20people%20named%20Lou.%20Isn%E2%80%99t%20that%20something!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EA%20more%20sentimental%20audience%20might%20have%20moved%20their%20hands%20to%20their%20hearts%20and%20cooed.%20Eyes%20might%20have%20misted%2C%20or%20filled%20with%20actual%20tears.%20Had%20someone%20named%20a%20human%20baby%20after%20my%20father%E2%80%94called%20it%2C%20say%2C%20Lou%20Sedaris%20Kwitchoff%2C%20or%2C%20better%20yet%2C%20Louis%20Harry%20Sedaris%20Kwitchoff%E2%80%94my%20family%20might%20have%20shared%20a%20moment%2C%20over%20our%20salads%20and%20sandwiches%20there%20at%20the%20Belted%20Goat.%20But%20this%20was%20an%20endangered%20turtle%20with%20only%20a%20tiny%20chance%20of%20living%20until%20the%20end%20of%20the%20week%2C%20and%20so%20it%20was%20more%20like%20naming%20a%20bar%20of%20soap%20after%20someone%2C%20if%20soap%20could%20paddle%20around%20briefly.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWhat%20can%20I%20tell%20you%2C%E2%80%9D%20my%20father%20said%2C%20his%20voice%20soft%20and%20dry%2C%20like%20corn%20husks%20being%20rubbed%20together.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20notorious.%20I%E2%80%99m%20legendary.%20I%E2%80%99m%20a%20survivor.%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Before returning to England, we drove back to Raleigh, and ate lunch with my father, who had a biscuit-size bandage on his ear and was relying on a walker that had his name and room number written on it in Magic Marker. I didn’t want to meet at Springmoor—“You told us you were Dave Chappelle!”—so Lisa and Bob drove him to a café that we’d all agreed on. Watching from a distance as he slowly advanced toward the table, I was struck by how breakable he seemed. Still, his spirits were high, and he was engaging, funny even, especially when talking about Springmoor, and the way the staff will walk in whenever they feel like it: “It’s a problem, because I don’t always feel like wearing clothes, if you catch my drift.”"],["p","“Sure,” I said, thinking, What’s wrong with underpants, at least?"],["p","Kathy met us at the restaurant as well, and midway through our meal she told my father about the baby loggerheads she’d seen hatching a few days earlier on Emerald Isle."],["p","“Oh, right,” my father said. “They’ve laid their eggs there for centuries. For even longer, I imagine. Aeons.”"],["p","“And the last one to pop up out of the sand,” she reported, “the very last one, the Turtle Patrol people named Lou. Isn’t that something!”"],["p","A more sentimental audience might have moved their hands to their hearts and cooed. Eyes might have misted, or filled with actual tears. Had someone named a human baby after my father—called it, say, Lou Sedaris Kwitchoff, or, better yet, Louis Harry Sedaris Kwitchoff—my family might have shared a moment, over our salads and sandwiches there at the Belted Goat. But this was an endangered turtle with only a tiny chance of living until the end of the week, and so it was more like naming a bar of soap after someone, if soap could paddle around briefly."],["p","“What can I tell you,” my father said, his voice soft and dry, like corn husks being rubbed together. “I’m notorious. I’m legendary. I’m a survivor.” ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"59111e90df652b705f4ab89d","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59111e90df652b705f4ab89d","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Personal History","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"personal-history"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Personal History","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"personal-history"}]}]},"channel":"","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[],"contentType":"article","contributors":[{"name":"David Sedaris","type":"author","title":"David Sedaris contributes frequently to The New Yorker. He is the author of, most recently, “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Calypso-David-Sedaris/dp/0316392383\">Calypso\u003c/a>.”","email":"","bio":["div",["p","David Sedaris contributes frequently to ",["em","The New Yorker"],". He is the author of “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Barrel-Fever-Stories-David-Sedaris/dp/0316779423"},"Barrel Fever"],"” (1994) and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Holidays-Ice-David-Sedaris/dp/0316078913"},"Holidays on Ice"],"” (1997), as well as four collections of personal essays: “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Naked-David-Sedaris/dp/0316777730"},"Naked"],"” (1997), “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Me-Talk-Pretty-One-Day/dp/0316776963"},"Me Talk Pretty One Day"],"” (2000), “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Dress-Your-Family-Corduroy-Denim/dp/0316010790"},"Dress Your Family in Corduroy and Denim"],"” (2004), “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/When-You-Are-Engulfed-Flames/dp/0316154687"},"When You Are Engulfed in Flames"],"” (2008), “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Lets-Explore-Diabetes-David-Sedaris/dp/0316154709"},"Let’s Explore Diabetes with Owls"],"” (2013), and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Theft-Finding-1977-2002-David-Sedaris/dp/0316154725"},"Theft by Finding: Diaries (1977-2002)"],"” (2017), and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Calypso-David-Sedaris/dp/0316392383"},"Calypso"],"” (2018). In 2005, he edited an anthology of stories, “Children Playing Before a Statue of Hercules.” He has also regularly contributed personal essays to ",["em","Esquire"],". Sedaris and his sister, Amy Sedaris, have collaborated under the name The Talent Family and have written several plays, including “Stump the Host”; “Stitches”; “One Woman Shoe,” which received an Obie Award; “Incident at Cobbler’s Knob”; and “The Book of Liz,” which was published in book form by the Dramatists Play Service."],["p","Sedaris made his comic début on National Public Radio’s Morning Edition, reading “SantaLand Diaries,” which recounted his strange but true experience working as a Macy’s elf clad in green tights. His original radio pieces can often be heard on the show “This American Life.” In 2001, Sedaris became the third recipient of the Thurber Prize for American Humor. In 2001, he was named “Humorist of the Year” by ",["em","Time"],". In 2005, he was nominated for two Grammy Awards for Best Spoken Word Album (“Dress Your Family in Corduroy and Denim”) and Best Comedy Album (“David Sedaris: Live at Carnegie Hall”)."]],"social":[],"url":"/contributors/david-sedaris","image":null}],"dek":"Life at every age.","formatting":{},"hed":"Father {"type":"iframe","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22iframe%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22http%3A%2F%2Faudm.herokuapp.com%2Fplayer-embed%3Fpub%3Dnewyorker%26articleID%3D5c1abbc36e94e94091466eca%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22100%25%22%2C%22height%22%3A%2290%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}]]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EAt%20the%20beginning%20of%201962%2C%20a%20tall%2C%20thin-lipped%20thirty-three-year-old%20named%20James%20Ivory%20and%20a%20charming%2C%20cleft-chinned%20twenty-five-year-old%20named%20Ismail%20Merchant%20turned%20up%20on%20the%20doorstep%20of%20a%20bungalow%20on%20Delhi%E2%80%99s%20Alipur%20Road.%20Ivory%20was%20a%20budding%20film%20director%2C%20Merchant%20a%20budding%20film%20producer.%20Together%2C%20they%20were%20hoping%20to%20adapt%20a%20novel%20called%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FHouseholder-Novel-Norton-Library%2Fdp%2F0393008517%2Fref%3Dsr_1_fkmr1_1%3Fie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416046%26amp%3Bsr%3D8-1-fkmr1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Dthe%2Bhouse%2Bholder%2Bjhabvala%5C%22%3EThe%20Householder%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20social%20satire%20of%20contemporary%20Delhi%2C%20and%20had%20decided%20to%20approach%20the%20author%20to%20ask%20if%20she%20would%20help%20them%20turn%20it%20into%20a%20film.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fcontributors%2Fruth-prawer-jhabvala%5C%22%3ERuth%20Prawer%20Jhabvala%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%20diminutive%20and%20dark-haired%2C%20did%20not%20imagine%20herself%20to%20be%20a%20budding%20screenwriter.%20When%20they%20first%20telephoned%20her%2C%20she%20pretended%20to%20be%20her%20mother-in-law%20to%20put%20them%20off.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20told%20them%20I%E2%80%99ve%20never%20done%20anything%20like%20this%20before%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20later%20recalled.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20they%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98It%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20matter.%20We%20haven%E2%80%99t%2C%20either.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20The%20film%20made%20from%20her%20screenplay%2C%20which%20appeared%20the%20following%20year%2C%20was%20the%20first%20feature%20for%20all%20three%2C%20but%20far%20from%20the%20last.%20In%20a%20partnership%20spanning%20more%20than%20forty%20years%2C%20Merchant%20Ivory%20Productions%20made%20more%20than%20twenty%20films%20written%20by%20Jhabvala%2C%20who%20won%20Oscars%20for%20her%20adaptations%20of%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FRoom-View-Maggie-Smith%2Fdp%2FB015IVLA2M%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dmovies-tv%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416087%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Da%2Broom%2Bwith%2Ba%2Bview%5C%22%3EA%20Room%20with%20a%20View%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fdp%2FB01N2POC6H%3Fref%3Dsr_1_3_acs_kn_imdb_pa_dp%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416125%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-3-acs%26amp%3Bautoplay%3D0%5C%22%3EHowards%20End%3C%2Fa%3E.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThere%E2%80%99s%20some%20poignancy%20in%20the%20fact%20that%20Jhabvala%2C%20who%20died%20in%202013%2C%20is%20best%20known%20today%20as%20the%20third%20member%20of%20the%20Merchant%20Ivory%20team.%20She%20considered%20%E2%80%9Cwriting%20film%20scripts%E2%80%9D%20to%20be%20a%20hobby%20alongside%20the%20real%20work%20of%20prose.%20In%20her%20lifetime%2C%20she%20published%20twelve%20novels%20and%20eight%20short-story%20collections.%20She%20excelled%20at%20concealing%20herself%2C%20most%20famously%20behind%20her%20own%20name.%20In%201957%2C%20the%20%3Cem%3ETimes%3C%2Fem%3E%20book%20critic%20Orville%20Prescott%20wrote%20of%20her%20novels%20that%20readers%20%E2%80%9Cwould%20naturally%20suppose%20that%20their%20author%20was%20an%20Indian%2C%20probably%20a%20high-caste%20Hindu%20educated%20at%20Wellesley.%E2%80%9D%20But%20Jhabvala%20was%20her%20married%20name%3B%20Ruth%20was%20not%20Indian%2C%20a%20point%20she%20later%20took%20pains%20to%20stress.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FAt-End-Century-Stories-Jhabvala-ebook%2Fdp%2FB07DFJ6F5B%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416204%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DAt%2Bthe%2BEnd%2Bof%2Bthe%2BCentury%5C%22%3EAt%20the%20End%20of%20the%20Century%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20(Counterpoint)%20gathers%20seventeen%20stories%2C%20dating%20from%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20first%20collection%2C%20in%201963%2C%20to%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Judge%E2%80%99s%20Will%2C%E2%80%9D%20published%20in%20this%20magazine%20two%20weeks%20before%20her%20death.%20They%20invite%20a%20face-to-face%20meeting%20with%20a%20literary%20figure%20who%20deserves%20to%20be%20reckoned%20with%20on%20her%20own%20terms.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","At the beginning of 1962, a tall, thin-lipped thirty-three-year-old named James Ivory and a charming, cleft-chinned twenty-five-year-old named Ismail Merchant turned up on the doorstep of a bungalow on Delhi’s Alipur Road. Ivory was a budding film director, Merchant a budding film producer. Together, they were hoping to adapt a novel called “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Householder-Novel-Norton-Library/dp/0393008517/ref=sr_1_fkmr1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1545416046&sr=8-1-fkmr1&keywords=the+house+holder+jhabvala"},"The Householder"],",” a social satire of contemporary Delhi, and had decided to approach the author to ask if she would help them turn it into a film. ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/contributors/ruth-prawer-jhabvala"},"Ruth Prawer Jhabvala"],", diminutive and dark-haired, did not imagine herself to be a budding screenwriter. When they first telephoned her, she pretended to be her mother-in-law to put them off."],["p","“I told them I’ve never done anything like this before,” she later recalled. “But they said, ‘It doesn’t matter. We haven’t, either.’ ” The film made from her screenplay, which appeared the following year, was the first feature for all three, but far from the last. In a partnership spanning more than forty years, Merchant Ivory Productions made more than twenty films written by Jhabvala, who won Oscars for her adaptations of “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Room-View-Maggie-Smith/dp/B015IVLA2M/ref=sr_1_1?s=movies-tv&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416087&sr=1-1&keywords=a+room+with+a+view"},"A Room with a View"],"” and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01N2POC6H?ref=sr_1_3_acs_kn_imdb_pa_dp&qid=1545416125&sr=1-3-acs&autoplay=0"},"Howards End"],".”"],["p","There’s some poignancy in the fact that Jhabvala, who died in 2013, is best known today as the third member of the Merchant Ivory team. She considered “writing film scripts” to be a hobby alongside the real work of prose. In her lifetime, she published twelve novels and eight short-story collections. She excelled at concealing herself, most famously behind her own name. In 1957, the ",["em","Times"]," book critic Orville Prescott wrote of her novels that readers “would naturally suppose that their author was an Indian, probably a high-caste Hindu educated at Wellesley.” But Jhabvala was her married name; Ruth was not Indian, a point she later took pains to stress."],["p","“",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/At-End-Century-Stories-Jhabvala-ebook/dp/B07DFJ6F5B/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416204&sr=1-1&keywords=At+the+End+of+the+Century"},"At the End of the Century"],"” (Counterpoint) gathers seventeen stories, dating from Jhabvala’s first collection, in 1963, to “The Judge’s Will,” published in this magazine two weeks before her death. They invite a face-to-face meeting with a literary figure who deserves to be reckoned with on her own terms."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3ERuth%20Prawer%20was%20born%20in%20Cologne%20in%201927%20into%20a%20bourgeois%2C%20assimilated%20Jewish%20family.%20Her%20maternal%20grandfather%20was%20a%20cantor%20at%20a%20prominent%20Cologne%20synagogue%3B%20her%20father%2C%20Marcus%2C%20a%20lawyer%2C%20had%20emigrated%20from%20Poland%20during%20the%20Great%20War.%20Ruth%20entered%20school%20the%20year%20Hitler%20came%20to%20power%3B%20she%20walked%20there%20to%20taunts%20of%20%E2%80%9CJew%2C%20Jew%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20had%20things%20thrown%20at%20her.%20In%201934%2C%20her%20father%20looked%20into%20emigrating%20to%20Palestine%2C%20but%20her%20mother%20resisted%2C%20certain%20that%20conditions%20in%20Germany%20would%20improve.%20It%20was%20only%20in%20April%2C%201939%2C%20that%20the%20family%20escaped%20to%20England.%20At%20the%20end%20of%20the%20war%2C%20they%20learned%20that%20more%20than%20forty%20relatives%20had%20been%20murdered%20in%20the%20camps.%20To%20those%20losses%20would%20be%20added%20one%20more%3A%20her%20father%2C%20broken%20by%20the%20news%2C%20killed%20himself%20in%201948.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ERuth%20was%20by%20then%20a%20student%20of%20English%20literature%20at%20Queen%20Mary%20College%2C%20in%20London.%20When%20she%20was%20just%20six%2C%20she%20had%20had%20an%20epiphany%20after%20being%20asked%20to%20write%20a%20composition%20in%20school%20about%20a%20rabbit.%20%E2%80%9CI%20wrote%20the%20title%2C%20%3Cem%3EDer%20Hase%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20recounted%20in%20a%20lecture.%20%E2%80%9CAt%20once%20I%20was%20flooded%20with%20my%20destiny%3B%20only%20I%20didn%E2%80%99t%20know%20that%E2%80%99s%20what%20it%20was.%20I%20only%20remember%20my%20entire%20absorption%2C%20delight%2C%20in%20writing%20about%E2%80%94giving%20my%20impression%20of%E2%80%94%3Cem%3Eder%20Hase.%3C%2Fem%3E%20To%20think%20that%20such%20happiness%20could%20be!%E2%80%9D%20After%20that%2C%20she%20wrote%20ceaselessly%2C%20stuffing%20cupboards%20%E2%80%9Cfull%20with%20unfinished%20novels%2C%20plays%2C%20stories%E2%80%9D%3B%20from%20her%20teens%2C%20she%20wrote%20in%20English%2C%20which%20she%20came%20to%20consider%20her%20%E2%80%9Cfirst%20language.%E2%80%9D%20While%20her%20elder%20brother%2C%20Siegbert%2C%20studied%20Modern%20Languages%20at%20Cambridge%20(he%20went%20on%20to%20become%20a%20distinguished%20scholar%20of%20German%20literature)%2C%20she%20produced%20an%20M.A.%20thesis%20on%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Short%20Story%20in%20England%2C%201700-1750.%E2%80%9D%20It%E2%80%99s%20a%20telling%20sign%20of%20affinity%20for%20a%20form%20she%20would%20come%20to%20excel%20at.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20a%20party%20in%201949%2C%20Ruth%20met%20Cyrus%20Jhabvala%2C%20an%20Indian%20Parsi%20architect%20who%20had%20come%20to%20England%20a%20few%20years%20earlier%20to%20study.%20Jhabvala%20had%20already%20bought%20his%20ticket%20home%2C%20but%20by%20the%20time%20he%20set%20sail%20for%20India%20he%20and%20Ruth%20were%20engaged.%20Two%20years%20later%2C%20having%20secured%20a%20job%20lecturing%20on%20architecture%20at%20Delhi%20Polytechnic%2C%20he%20came%20back%20to%20England%20to%20marry%20her%2C%20and%20the%20couple%20settled%20in%20Delhi.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFrom%20Austerity%20Britain%2C%20where%20%E2%80%9Ceverything%20was%20pretty%20basic%20and%20grim%20and%20grey%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20new%20Mrs.%20Jhabvala%20found%20herself%20transported%20to%20a%20%E2%80%9Cgrand%20fairy%20land%2C%20full%20of%20sights%20and%20sounds%20and%20colors%2C%E2%80%9D%20as%20she%20related%20in%20a%20later%20interview.%20There%20were%20exotic%20flowers%2C%20birds%2C%20and%20smells%3B%20captivating%20music%20performed%20by%20female%20vocalists%20%E2%80%9Cwho%20for%20me%20were%20somehow%20an%20expression%20of%20everything%20a%20woman%20artist%20does%E2%80%9D%3B%20and%20sweets%20that%20she%20consumed%20by%20the%20pound%2C%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20essence%20of%20all%20sweetness%20that%20there%20ever%20could%20be.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EJhabvala%E2%80%99s%20early%20fiction%20sauntered%20into%20middle-class%20Hindu%20households%20and%20wryly%20took%20the%20measure%20of%20their%20dramatic%20capacity%3A%20shy%20newlyweds%20and%20demanding%20mothers-in-law%2C%20pompous%20patresfamilias%2C%20feckless%20sons%2C%20and%20snooping%20aunties.%20The%20opening%20stories%20of%20%E2%80%9CAt%20the%20End%20of%20the%20Century%E2%80%9D%20introduce%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20remarkable%20economy%20of%20expression%2C%20devoid%20of%20sandalwood-scented%2C%20curry-flavored%2C%20bangle-clanging%20exoticism.%20Jhabvala%20sketches%20character%2C%20and%20by%20implication%20plot%2C%20in%20a%20few%20quick%20flicks%2C%20as%20in%20a%20tale%20of%20two%20rivalrous%20brothers%2C%20the%20elder%20%E2%80%9Cwith%20his%20silk%20suit%2C%20his%20big%20ring%2C%20his%20oiled%20and%20scented%20hair%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20the%20younger%20%E2%80%9Cpuny%20and%20insignificant%2C%E2%80%9D%20who%20works%20as%20a%20shop%20attendant%20%E2%80%9Cwith%20just%20the%20right%20mixture%20of%20dignity%20and%20obsequiousness.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIf%20Jhabvala%20has%20an%20anthropologist%E2%80%99s%20curiosity%20about%20how%20society%20functions%2C%20she%E2%80%99s%20a%20decidedly%20nonparticipant%20observer%3B%20her%20narrative%20stance%20brings%20together%20candor%20and%20detachment.%20She%E2%80%99s%20unsparing%20about%20the%20constraints%20and%20the%20tedium%20of%20women%E2%80%99s%20lives%2C%20for%20instance%2C%20but%20also%20about%20the%20women%20who%20are%20leading%20them.%20The%20wife%20of%20a%20devoted%20elderly%20aristocrat%2C%20trapped%20among%20%E2%80%9Cprovincial%2C%20dreary%2C%20unrefined%20people%2C%E2%80%9D%20seeks%20diversion%20in%20the%20arms%20of%20an%20abusive%20local%20policeman.%20A%20young%20widow%20manages%20to%20resist%20the%20gestures%20of%20self-abnegation%20expected%20by%20her%20late%20husband%E2%80%99s%20family%2C%20and%20pursues%20corporeal%20indulgences%20%E2%80%9Cnot%20for%20pleasure%2C%20but%20compulsively%2C%20sunk%20in%20sloth%20and%20greed%20because%20soft%20beds%20and%20foods%20were%20all%20that%20life%20had%20given%20to%20her.%E2%80%9D%20In%20%E2%80%9CA%20Course%20of%20English%20Studies%2C%E2%80%9D%20Jhabvala%20delivers%20an%20astute%20portrait%20of%20an%20upper-class%20Indian%20woman%20in%20England%20whose%20feeling%20of%20cultural%20dislocation%20hinges%20as%20much%20on%20her%20own%20sense%20of%20entitlement%20as%20on%20her%20loneliness%20and%20unfamiliarity.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAnita%20Desai%20notes%20in%20the%20introduction%20to%20this%20collection%20that%20it%20was%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9Cfate%20to%20be%20presented%20to%20Western%20readers%20as%20a%20Jane%20Austen.%E2%80%9D%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20prose%20does%20share%20Austen%E2%80%99s%20acerbic%20wit%20and%20a%20well-cadenced%20fluency%2C%20confident%20in%20the%20strength%20of%20syntax%20to%20sustain%20explication%E2%80%94and%20comedy%E2%80%94without%20flashy%20language.%20As%20a%20screenwriter%2C%20Jhabvala%20learned%20to%20write%20with%20still%20greater%20economy.%20(%E2%80%9COne%20sentence%20in%20a%20film%20is%20like%2C%20you%20know%2C%20fifteen%20or%20twenty%20sentences%20in%20a%20book%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20once%20said.)%20Her%20best%20novels%20are%20short%2C%20and%20her%20short%20stories%20are%20often%20better.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhat%20the%20Austen%20analogy%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20capture%20is%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20role%20as%20a%20pre%C3%ABminent%20social%20historian%20of%20newly%20independent%20India.%20Neither%20English%20nor%20Indian%20(nor%20even%20truly%20Anglophone%20before%20adolescence)%2C%20Jhabvala%20came%20to%20her%20subjects%20without%20being%20trailed%20by%20the%20shadow%20of%20empire.%20Her%20ability%20to%20make%20fiction%20out%20of%20the%20bourgeois%20Indian%20everyday%20was%20revelatory%20to%20younger%20post-colonial%20writers%20such%20as%20Desai%2C%20for%20whom%20Jhabvala%20was%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20first%20one%20who%20was%20writing%20about%20my%20world%2C%20our%20world.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EJhabvala%20also%20chronicled%20a%20distinctive%20phase%20in%20encounters%20between%20Indians%20and%20Westerners%2C%20as%20a%20last%20generation%20of%20imperial%20Britons%20trickled%20away%20and%20new%20customs%2C%20new%20tastes%2C%20and%20new%20people%20(increasingly%20American)%20stepped%20in.%20This%20is%20movingly%20captured%20in%20the%201965%20Merchant%20Ivory%20film%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FShakespeare-Wallah-Shashi-Kapoor%2Fdp%2FB07BTCS5ZT%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dinstant-video%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416269%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DShakespeare%2BWallah%5C%22%3EShakespeare%20Wallah%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20first%20original%20screenplay.%20The%20movie%20follows%20a%20British%20family%E2%80%99s%20acting%20company%20as%20it%20tours%20India%20performing%20Shakespeare%20to%20dwindling%20audiences.%20Early%20in%20the%20film%2C%20the%20troupe%20encounters%20an%20itinerant%20monkey%20trainer%20who%20laments%20that%20people%20no%20longer%20care%20for%20his%20art.%20%E2%80%9COur%20story%20exactly%2C%E2%80%9D%20one%20of%20the%20actors%20murmurs.%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20script%20was%20inspired%20by%20the%201947%20diaries%20of%20a%20real-life%20actor-manager%2C%20Geoffrey%20Kendal%2C%20but%20its%20brilliance%20lies%20in%20her%20turning%20what%20could%20have%20been%20a%20nostalgic%20period%20piece%20about%20the%20end%20of%20empire%20into%20a%20coming-of-age%20tale%20centered%20on%20the%20family%E2%80%99s%20teen-age%20daughter.%20(Kendal%E2%80%99s%20younger%20daughter%2C%20Felicity%2C%20made%20her%20screen%20d%C3%A9but%20in%20the%20film%2C%20starring%20opposite%20her%20brother-in-law%2C%20Shashi%20Kapoor.)%20The%20Raj%2C%20for%20Jhabvala%2C%20was%20a%20closed%20chapter.%20She%20preferred%20to%20turn%20the%20page.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Ruth Prawer was born in Cologne in 1927 into a bourgeois, assimilated Jewish family. Her maternal grandfather was a cantor at a prominent Cologne synagogue; her father, Marcus, a lawyer, had emigrated from Poland during the Great War. Ruth entered school the year Hitler came to power; she walked there to taunts of “Jew, Jew,” and had things thrown at her. In 1934, her father looked into emigrating to Palestine, but her mother resisted, certain that conditions in Germany would improve. It was only in April, 1939, that the family escaped to England. At the end of the war, they learned that more than forty relatives had been murdered in the camps. To those losses would be added one more: her father, broken by the news, killed himself in 1948."],["p","Ruth was by then a student of English literature at Queen Mary College, in London. When she was just six, she had had an epiphany after being asked to write a composition in school about a rabbit. “I wrote the title, ",["em","Der Hase"],",” she recounted in a lecture. “At once I was flooded with my destiny; only I didn’t know that’s what it was. I only remember my entire absorption, delight, in writing about—giving my impression of—",["em","der Hase."]," To think that such happiness could be!” After that, she wrote ceaselessly, stuffing cupboards “full with unfinished novels, plays, stories”; from her teens, she wrote in English, which she came to consider her “first language.” While her elder brother, Siegbert, studied Modern Languages at Cambridge (he went on to become a distinguished scholar of German literature), she produced an M.A. thesis on “The Short Story in England, 1700-1750.” It’s a telling sign of affinity for a form she would come to excel at."],["p","At a party in 1949, Ruth met Cyrus Jhabvala, an Indian Parsi architect who had come to England a few years earlier to study. Jhabvala had already bought his ticket home, but by the time he set sail for India he and Ruth were engaged. Two years later, having secured a job lecturing on architecture at Delhi Polytechnic, he came back to England to marry her, and the couple settled in Delhi."],["p","From Austerity Britain, where “everything was pretty basic and grim and grey,” the new Mrs. Jhabvala found herself transported to a “grand fairy land, full of sights and sounds and colors,” as she related in a later interview. There were exotic flowers, birds, and smells; captivating music performed by female vocalists “who for me were somehow an expression of everything a woman artist does”; and sweets that she consumed by the pound, “the essence of all sweetness that there ever could be.”"],["p","Jhabvala’s early fiction sauntered into middle-class Hindu households and wryly took the measure of their dramatic capacity: shy newlyweds and demanding mothers-in-law, pompous patresfamilias, feckless sons, and snooping aunties. The opening stories of “At the End of the Century” introduce Jhabvala’s remarkable economy of expression, devoid of sandalwood-scented, curry-flavored, bangle-clanging exoticism. Jhabvala sketches character, and by implication plot, in a few quick flicks, as in a tale of two rivalrous brothers, the elder “with his silk suit, his big ring, his oiled and scented hair,” and the younger “puny and insignificant,” who works as a shop attendant “with just the right mixture of dignity and obsequiousness.”"],["p","If Jhabvala has an anthropologist’s curiosity about how society functions, she’s a decidedly nonparticipant observer; her narrative stance brings together candor and detachment. She’s unsparing about the constraints and the tedium of women’s lives, for instance, but also about the women who are leading them. The wife of a devoted elderly aristocrat, trapped among “provincial, dreary, unrefined people,” seeks diversion in the arms of an abusive local policeman. A young widow manages to resist the gestures of self-abnegation expected by her late husband’s family, and pursues corporeal indulgences “not for pleasure, but compulsively, sunk in sloth and greed because soft beds and foods were all that life had given to her.” In “A Course of English Studies,” Jhabvala delivers an astute portrait of an upper-class Indian woman in England whose feeling of cultural dislocation hinges as much on her own sense of entitlement as on her loneliness and unfamiliarity."],["p","Anita Desai notes in the introduction to this collection that it was Jhabvala’s “fate to be presented to Western readers as a Jane Austen.” Jhabvala’s prose does share Austen’s acerbic wit and a well-cadenced fluency, confident in the strength of syntax to sustain explication—and comedy—without flashy language. As a screenwriter, Jhabvala learned to write with still greater economy. (“One sentence in a film is like, you know, fifteen or twenty sentences in a book,” she once said.) Her best novels are short, and her short stories are often better."],["p","What the Austen analogy doesn’t capture is Jhabvala’s role as a preëminent social historian of newly independent India. Neither English nor Indian (nor even truly Anglophone before adolescence), Jhabvala came to her subjects without being trailed by the shadow of empire. Her ability to make fiction out of the bourgeois Indian everyday was revelatory to younger post-colonial writers such as Desai, for whom Jhabvala was “the first one who was writing about my world, our world.”"],["p","Jhabvala also chronicled a distinctive phase in encounters between Indians and Westerners, as a last generation of imperial Britons trickled away and new customs, new tastes, and new people (increasingly American) stepped in. This is movingly captured in the 1965 Merchant Ivory film “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Shakespeare-Wallah-Shashi-Kapoor/dp/B07BTCS5ZT/ref=sr_1_1?s=instant-video&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416269&sr=1-1&keywords=Shakespeare+Wallah"},"Shakespeare Wallah"],",” Jhabvala’s first original screenplay. The movie follows a British family’s acting company as it tours India performing Shakespeare to dwindling audiences. Early in the film, the troupe encounters an itinerant monkey trainer who laments that people no longer care for his art. “Our story exactly,” one of the actors murmurs. Jhabvala’s script was inspired by the 1947 diaries of a real-life actor-manager, Geoffrey Kendal, but its brilliance lies in her turning what could have been a nostalgic period piece about the end of empire into a coming-of-age tale centered on the family’s teen-age daughter. (Kendal’s younger daughter, Felicity, made her screen début in the film, starring opposite her brother-in-law, Shashi Kapoor.) The Raj, for Jhabvala, was a closed chapter. She preferred to turn the page."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20nineteen-sixties%20brought%20a%20new%20wave%20of%20ebullient%20Westerners%20to%20India%20to%20%E2%80%9Cfind%20themselves%2C%E2%80%9D%20and%20Jhabvala%20was%20waiting%20with%20a%20skewer.%20%E2%80%9CWhich%20Yoga%20do%20you%20do%3F%20Hatha%20Yoga%20or%20Bhakti%20Yoga%20or%20what%3F%E2%80%9D%20a%20European%20seeker%20asks%20the%20Indian%20hero%20of%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Householder.%E2%80%9D%20None%2C%20he%20confesses.%20%E2%80%9CWell%20you%20should%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20chides.%20%E2%80%9CHow%20do%20you%20think%20you%E2%80%99ll%20meet%20the%20Eternal%20and%20the%20Infinite%20if%20you%20don%E2%80%99t%3F%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMany%20of%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20novels%20and%20stories%20feature%20credulous%20Westerners%20(usually%20female)%20in%20thrall%20to%20charismatic%20Indian%20gurus%20(invariably%20male).%20Jhabvala%20generally%20musters%20a%20flicker%20of%20sympathy%20for%20those%20who%20know%20not%20what%20they%20do.%20In%20the%20story%20%E2%80%9CA%20Spiritual%20Call%2C%E2%80%9D%20we%20learn%20that%20Daphne%20%E2%80%9Chad%20always%20been%20known%20as%20straightforward%20and%20sensible%2C%20good%20at%20sickbeds%2C%20had%20done%20history%20at%20Oxford%2C%20wore%20tasteful%2C%20unobtrusive%2C%20English%20clothes.%20Yet%20when%20she%20met%20Swamiji%20she%20knew%20without%20a%20word%20being%20spoken%20that%20he%20meant%20her%20to%20follow%20him%20back%20to%20India.%E2%80%9D%20This%20will%20not%20end%20well%20for%20her.%20In%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20fiction%2C%20gurus%20are%2C%20to%20a%20man%2C%20grifting%2C%20lecherous%2C%20manipulative%E2%80%94and%20successful.%20%E2%80%9C%C2%A0%E2%80%98I%20have%20many%20warm%20invitations%20from%20America%2C%E2%80%99%20Swamiji%20said.%20%E2%80%98From%20California%20especially.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EJhabvala%20made%20a%20comedy%20out%20of%20these%20encounters%20in%20her%201969%20screenplay%20for%20%E2%80%9C
