d%20by%20the%20TV%20miniseries%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Jewel%20in%20the%20Crown%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Far%20Pavilions.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBut%20by%20then%20the%20Booker%20Prize%20had%20been%20awarded%20to%20Salman%20Rushdie%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FMidnights-Children-Modern-Library-Novels%2Fdp%2F0812976533%2Fref%3Dsr_1_2%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416611%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-2%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DMidnight%25E2%2580%2599s%2BChildren%5C%22%3EMidnight%E2%80%99s%20Children%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20(1981)%2C%20marking%20a%20new%20era%20in%20literary%20portrayals%20of%20the%20subcontinent.%20And%20Jhabvala%20had%20quit%20India.%20She%20used%20the%20Booker%20Prize%20money%20to%20move%20to%20New%20York%2C%20buying%20an%20apartment%20in%20the%20Upper%20East%20Side%20building%20where%20Ivory%20and%20Merchant%20resided.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The nineteen-sixties brought a new wave of ebullient Westerners to India to “find themselves,” and Jhabvala was waiting with a skewer. “Which Yoga do you do? Hatha Yoga or Bhakti Yoga or what?” a European seeker asks the Indian hero of “The Householder.” None, he confesses. “Well you should,” she chides. “How do you think you’ll meet the Eternal and the Infinite if you don’t?”"],["p","Many of Jhabvala’s novels and stories feature credulous Westerners (usually female) in thrall to charismatic Indian gurus (invariably male). Jhabvala generally musters a flicker of sympathy for those who know not what they do. In the story “A Spiritual Call,” we learn that Daphne “had always been known as straightforward and sensible, good at sickbeds, had done history at Oxford, wore tasteful, unobtrusive, English clothes. Yet when she met Swamiji she knew without a word being spoken that he meant her to follow him back to India.” This will not end well for her. In Jhabvala’s fiction, gurus are, to a man, grifting, lecherous, manipulative—and successful. “ ‘I have many warm invitations from America,’ Swamiji said. ‘From California especially.’ ”"],["p","Jhabvala made a comedy out of these encounters in her 1969 screenplay for “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Guru-Rita-Tushingham/dp/B01BL1FD4E/ref=sr_1_1?s=instant-video&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416303&sr=1-1&keywords=The+Guru+merchant+ivory"},"The Guru"],",” about an English rock star who, like George Harrison, comes to India to study sitar. But in her prose the figure of the dangerous seducer sometimes swells to take on the dimensions of India itself. “I had come to India to ",["em","be"]," in India,” the narrator of “An Experience of India” says. “I wanted to be changed.” Leaving her journalist husband in Delhi, the woman sets off on a series of sexual and spiritual adventures, exulting in the sense of freedom and discovery. Eventually, she becomes jaundiced, literally and figuratively: “Everything I had once liked so much—people, places, crowds, smells—I now feared and hated.” Like many Jhabvala heroines, she ends up longing to escape from India but finds herself incapable of doing so, an addict drugged by experience."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1ae11d286bc006c37e8297%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1ae11d286bc006c37e8297%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1ae11d286bc006c37e8297%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1ae11d286bc006c37e8297"}]],["p","“",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/experience-India-Prawer-Jhabvala-1972-01-01/dp/B01A0C94CC/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416353&sr=1-3&keywords=An+Experience+of+India+jhabvala"},"An Experience of India"],"” was the title story of a 1971 collection, which Jhabvala prefaced with an autobiographical essay, “Myself in India.” In it, Jhabvala describes being spun around a wheel of Western reactions to India, writing, “First stage: tremendous enthusiasm—everything Indian is marvelous; second stage, everything Indian not so marvelous; third stage, everything Indian abominable.” She can no longer shake an awareness that “the most salient fact about India is that it is very poor and very backward.” She shuts the blinds, cranks up the air-conditioning, and buries herself in literature in an effort to avoid the deprivation around her, but “all the time I know myself to be on the back of this great animal of poverty and backwardness.”"],["p","The piece presents Jhabvala at her acid best, in a viciously observed sketch of Delhi high society: the Oxbridge-educated hostess is attired in “handloom saris and traditional jewelry,” “trays of iced drinks are carried around by servants in uniform, and there is intelligent conversation, and then there is a superbly arranged buffet supper and more intelligent conversation.” The hostess and her guests “know modern India to be an important subject,” Jhabvala goes on, “but though they themselves ",["em","are"]," modern India, they don’t look at themselves . . . except with the eyes of foreign experts whom they have been taught to respect.” Candid to a fault, “Myself in India” loses its pungency when Jhabvala posits that “most Indians” ignore poverty because of “their belief in reincarnation,” and lapses into tired, if deliberately hyperbolic, characterizations of India as a “bog of passive, intuitive being,” oppressive heat, and fervent paganism. In a later interview, she likened living in India to being in Biblical times, “when there were beggars and lepers.” “Well,” she tutted, “you don’t want to be in Biblical times.” Jane Austen, meet V. S. Naipaul."],["p","Indian critics turned on her. It’s one thing to criticize a society from within; it’s another to do so as a foreigner—and a woman. “If you don’t say that India is simply paradise on earth, and the extended Hindu family the most perfect way of organizing society, you’re anti-Indian,” she told a ",["em","Times"]," interviewer in 1983. “I don’t have many readers there.” Pankaj Mishra has suggested that Jhabvala may have grown so bitter because she lacked “the wide range of experience that V. S. Naipaul and E. M. Forster attested to.” Never mind that she lived in India for decades, unlike either man, and raised three daughters there, and learned to write Hindi. These are essentially the terms Naipaul himself applied to, yes, Jane Austen, whom he disdained as a writer of “sentimental ambitions” with a “narrow view of the world.”"],["p","Aspects of “An Experience of India” recur in Jhabvala’s 1975 novel, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Heat-Dust-Ruth-Prawer-Jhabvala-ebook/dp/B01D22Z8JK/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416483&sr=1-1&keywords=Heat+and+Dust++jhabvala"},"Heat and Dust"],",” which tells the parallel stories of a British woman in India in 1923 and her husband’s granddaughter, who travels to the same town fifty years later. A mashup of Jhabvala’s earlier fiction and Forster’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Hill-Devi-M-Forster/dp/0156402653/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416514&sr=1-1&keywords=The+Hill+of+Devi"},"The Hill of Devi"],",” about his visits to a small princely state, the book feels both warmed over and overwrought. But “Heat and Dust,” the only one of Jhabvala’s novels to portray India under the Raj, also became her most successful when it won the Booker Prize—which two years earlier had been awarded to J. G. Farrell’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Siege-Krishnapur-Empire-Trilogy/dp/159017092X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416501&sr=1-1&keywords=The+Siege+of+Krishnapur"},"The Siege of Krishnapur"],",” set during the Indian Rebellion of 1857, and two years later went to Paul Scott’s “Staying On,” about a retired British couple who continue living in India after independence. The Merchant Ivory adaptation of “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Heat-Dust-Greta-Scacchi/dp/B077ZZJXG9/ref=sr_1_1?s=instant-video&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416543&sr=1-1&keywords=Heat+and+Dust+merchant+ivory"},"Heat and Dust"],"” came out in 1983 amid a flurry of Raj nostalgia, flanked on the big screen by “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00190N4E4?ref=sr_1_1_acs_kn_imdb_pa_dp&qid=1545416558&sr=1-1-acs&autoplay=0"},"Gandhi"],"” and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003EYDTWA?ref=sr_1_1_acs_kn_imdb_pa_dp&qid=1545416585&sr=1-1-acs&autoplay=0"},"A Passage to India"],",” and joined by the TV miniseries “The Jewel in the Crown” and “The Far Pavilions.”"],["p","But by then the Booker Prize had been awarded to Salman Rushdie’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Midnights-Children-Modern-Library-Novels/dp/0812976533/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416611&sr=1-2&keywords=Midnight%E2%80%99s+Children"},"Midnight’s Children"],"” (1981), marking a new era in literary portrayals of the subcontinent. And Jhabvala had quit India. She used the Booker Prize money to move to New York, buying an apartment in the Upper East Side building where Ivory and Merchant resided."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EJhabvala%20felt%20instantly%20at%20home%20in%20the%20city.%20While%20Europe%20would%20forever%20%E2%80%9Csmell%20of%20blood%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94she%20never%20returned%20to%20Germany%E2%80%94New%20York%20was%2C%20she%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20most%20European%20place%20on%20earth%20I%20know.%E2%80%9D%20She%20rediscovered%20the%20Old%20World%20of%20her%20youth%20in%20jars%20of%20pickled%20cucumbers%20and%20herring%20on%20deli%20counters%3B%20at%20ballets%20and%20concerts%3B%20among%20the%20furnishings%20and%20the%20accents%20of%20her%20past.%20She%20spent%20the%20rest%20of%20her%20life%20based%20in%20New%20York%2C%20albeit%20with%20a%20strong%20tie%20to%20India%20through%20her%20beloved%20husband%2C%20whom%20she%20called%20Jhab.%20Cyrus%20Jhabvala%20maintained%20his%20architecture%20practice%20in%20Delhi%20and%20Ruth%20spent%20winters%20with%20him%20there%3B%20Cyrus%20visited%20New%20York%20regularly%20until%20he%20retired%20and%20joined%20her%20in%20the%20United%20States%20full%20time.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EJhabvala%20spoke%20little%20about%20her%20particular%20writing%20choices%2C%20but%20she%20often%20described%20herself%20as%20a%20chameleon%2C%20writing%20about%20whatever%20milieu%20she%20inhabited.%20Henceforth%20she%20set%20her%20fiction%20largely%20in%20America%2C%20often%20among%20European%20migrants.%20The%20later%20stories%20in%20%E2%80%9CAt%20the%20End%20of%20the%20Century%E2%80%9D%20introduce%20readers%20to%20%E2%80%9Cprosperous%20%C3%A9migr%C3%A9s%20from%20various%20Central%20European%20countries%2C%E2%80%9D%20who%20%E2%80%9Cspoke%20only%20in%20English%2C%20though%20their%20heavy%20accents%20made%20it%20sound%20not%20unlike%20their%20native%20German%E2%80%9D%3B%20and%20wan%2C%20wealthy%20women%20equally%20at%20home%20in%20New%20York%2C%20London%2C%20or%20Los%20Angeles.%20In%20some%20ways%2C%20it%20must%20have%20helped%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20literary%20reputation%20to%20move%20to%20New%20York%20at%20this%20transitional%20moment%20for%20Indians%20writing%20in%20English.%20Quite%20aside%20from%20the%20politics%20of%20nationality%20(when%20Arundhati%20Roy%20won%20the%20Booker%2C%20in%201997%2C%20she%20was%20celebrated%20as%20the%20first%20%E2%80%9Ctrue%20Indian%E2%80%9D%20to%20do%20so)%2C%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20clipped%20social%20satire%20belongs%20to%20a%20world%20entirely%20different%20from%20the%20sprawling%20canvases%20and%20the%20linguistic%20innovation%20of%20Roy%2C%20Rushdie%2C%20Amitav%20Ghosh%2C%20and%20Vikram%20Seth.%20Then%2C%20too%2C%20India%20had%20little%20traction%20among%20American%20readers%3B%20even%20James%20Ivory%20confessed%20that%20he%20didn%E2%80%99t%20read%20her%20early%20%3Cem%3ENew%20Yorker%3C%2Fem%3E%20stories%2C%20%E2%80%9Cbecause%20at%20that%20point%20I%20didn%E2%80%99t%20have%20much%20interest%20in%20India%2C%20and%20they%20were%20Indian%20stories.%E2%80%9D%20So%20a%20shift%20in%20setting%20anchored%20her%20in%20an%20American%20literary%20marketplace.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20focus%20of%20her%20screenwriting%20changed%2C%20too.%20In%20the%20late%20seventies%2C%20Jhabvala%20proposed%20an%20adaptation%20of%20Henry%20James%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FEuropeans-Sketch-Penguin-Classics%2Fdp%2F0141441402%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416672%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3Dthe%2Beuropeans%2Bhenry%2Bjames%5C%22%3EThe%20Europeans%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20to%20Merchant%20and%20Ivory%2C%20anticipating%20that%20the%20book%20would%20be%20a%20good%20match%20for%20Ivory%E2%80%99s%20sensibility.%20The%20ensuing%20series%20of%20classic%20adaptations%20and%20historical%20dramas%20completed%20the%20team%E2%80%99s%20transformation%20from%20makers%20of%20lighthearted%20India-themed%20films%20into%20an%20Oscar-winning%20Hollywood%20brand.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EJhabvala%E2%80%99s%20fiction%20does%20not%20seem%20to%20have%20benefitted%20similarly.%20She%20published%20less%20during%20her%20decades%20in%20the%20United%20States%20than%20she%20had%20in%20India%2C%20and%20fewer%20novels%20in%20particular.%20Judging%20from%20their%20quality%2C%20that%20was%20perhaps%20no%20bad%20thing.%20In%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FThree-Continents-Ruth-Prawer-Jhabvala-ebook%2Fdp%2FB01FCLM7NO%2Fref%3Dsr_1_2%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416690%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-2%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DThree%2BContinents%2Bjhabvala%5C%22%3EThree%20Continents%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20(1987)%2C%20a%20novel%20about%20American%20na%C3%AFfs%20caught%20up%20in%20a%20Bhagwan%20Shree%20Rajneesh-style%20cult%2C%20the%20characters%20get%20crushed%20under%20a%20tediously%20overextended%20plot.%20The%20book%20seems%20to%20have%20originated%20in%20an%20idea%20for%20a%20screenplay%2C%20and%20its%20failure%20as%20a%20novel%20underscores%20the%20sense%20that%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20irony%20and%20restraint%20flourished%20better%20in%20compact%20frames.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThough%20some%20of%20the%20American%20stories%20deliver%20flashes%20of%20the%20Jhabvala%20economy%E2%80%94New%20York%20captured%20in%20snatches%20of%20%E2%80%9Cstreet%20smells%2C%20petrol%20fumes%2C%20leaking%20gas%20pipes%2C%20newly%20poured%20tar%2C%20pretzels%2C%20mangoes%20from%20Mexico%2C%20Chinese%20noodles%2C%20overblown%20flowers%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94her%20satirical%20edge%2C%20so%20keen%20in%20the%20Indian%20fiction%2C%20is%20dulled.%20Maybe%20it%E2%80%99s%20harder%20to%20convey%20ironic%20detachment%20when%20you%20feel%20more%20at%20home.%20There%E2%80%99s%20an%20evanescence%20to%20many%20of%20these%20Western%20tales%2C%20as%20if%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20writing%20turned%20its%20face%20away%20from%20the%20sun%20and%20grew%20obscure.%20Two%20of%20the%20central%20characters%20in%20the%20collection%E2%80%99s%20title%20story%20fade%20entirely%20by%20the%20time%20it%20ends%3B%20in%20the%20parting%20scene%2C%20they%20appear%20only%20in%20a%20photograph%2C%20%E2%80%9Ca%20shimmer%20of%20two%20figures%20in%20light-coloured%20clothes%20on%20the%20verge%20of%20disappearing%20from%20sight.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%E2%80%99s%20in%20the%20later%20stories%20in%20this%20volume%20that%20one%20becomes%20aware%20of%20how%20much%20triangulation%20pervades%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20work.%20It%E2%80%99s%20not%20just%20classic%20love%20triangles%2C%20though%20there%20are%20many%20of%20those%E2%80%94best%20portrayed%20in%20the%20collection%E2%80%99s%20final%20story%2C%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fmagazine%2F2013%2F03%2F25%2Fthe-judges-will%5C%22%3EThe%20Judge%E2%80%99s%20Will%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20in%20which%20a%20widow%20discovers%20the%20existence%20of%20her%20husband%E2%80%99s%20longtime%20mistress.%20Jhabvala%20is%20an%20artful%20geometer%2C%20and%20she%20skews%20her%20angles%20boldly.%20Consider%20%E2%80%9CM%C3%A9nage%2C%E2%80%9D%20in%20which%20a%20daughter%20finds%20out%20that%20her%20mother%20and%20aunt%20share%20a%20lover%2C%20before%20sleeping%20with%20him%20herself.%20Or%20%E2%80%9CPagans%2C%E2%80%9D%20in%20which%20two%20sisters%20sleep%20with%20the%20husband%20of%20one%2C%20and%20take%20up%20the%20same%20young%20Indian%20prot%C3%A9g%C3%A9.%20Or%20%E2%80%9CGreat%20Expectations%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20puzzling%20account%20of%20an%20American%20woman%20who%20becomes%20a%20surrogate%20mother%20qua%20partner%20to%20a%20self-involved%20divorc%C3%A9e%20and%20her%20adolescent%20daughter.%20These%20stories%2C%20set%20primarily%20in%20New%20York%2C%20are%20among%20the%20weakest%20in%20the%20collection%E2%80%94or%20maybe%20it%E2%80%99s%20that%20by%20the%20time%20one%20gets%20to%20them%20the%20pattern%20appears%20formulaic.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Jhabvala felt instantly at home in the city. While Europe would forever “smell of blood”—she never returned to Germany—New York was, she said, “the most European place on earth I know.” She rediscovered the Old World of her youth in jars of pickled cucumbers and herring on deli counters; at ballets and concerts; among the furnishings and the accents of her past. She spent the rest of her life based in New York, albeit with a strong tie to India through her beloved husband, whom she called Jhab. Cyrus Jhabvala maintained his architecture practice in Delhi and Ruth spent winters with him there; Cyrus visited New York regularly until he retired and joined her in the United States full time."],["p","Jhabvala spoke little about her particular writing choices, but she often described herself as a chameleon, writing about whatever milieu she inhabited. Henceforth she set her fiction largely in America, often among European migrants. The later stories in “At the End of the Century” introduce readers to “prosperous émigrés from various Central European countries,” who “spoke only in English, though their heavy accents made it sound not unlike their native German”; and wan, wealthy women equally at home in New York, London, or Los Angeles. In some ways, it must have helped Jhabvala’s literary reputation to move to New York at this transitional moment for Indians writing in English. Quite aside from the politics of nationality (when Arundhati Roy won the Booker, in 1997, she was celebrated as the first “true Indian” to do so), Jhabvala’s clipped social satire belongs to a world entirely different from the sprawling canvases and the linguistic innovation of Roy, Rushdie, Amitav Ghosh, and Vikram Seth. Then, too, India had little traction among American readers; even James Ivory confessed that he didn’t read her early ",["em","New Yorker"]," stories, “because at that point I didn’t have much interest in India, and they were Indian stories.” So a shift in setting anchored her in an American literary marketplace."],["p","The focus of her screenwriting changed, too. In the late seventies, Jhabvala proposed an adaptation of Henry James’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Europeans-Sketch-Penguin-Classics/dp/0141441402/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416672&sr=1-1&keywords=the+europeans+henry+james"},"The Europeans"],"” to Merchant and Ivory, anticipating that the book would be a good match for Ivory’s sensibility. The ensuing series of classic adaptations and historical dramas completed the team’s transformation from makers of lighthearted India-themed films into an Oscar-winning Hollywood brand."],["p","Jhabvala’s fiction does not seem to have benefitted similarly. She published less during her decades in the United States than she had in India, and fewer novels in particular. Judging from their quality, that was perhaps no bad thing. In “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Three-Continents-Ruth-Prawer-Jhabvala-ebook/dp/B01FCLM7NO/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416690&sr=1-2&keywords=Three+Continents+jhabvala"},"Three Continents"],"” (1987), a novel about American naïfs caught up in a Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh-style cult, the characters get crushed under a tediously overextended plot. The book seems to have originated in an idea for a screenplay, and its failure as a novel underscores the sense that Jhabvala’s irony and restraint flourished better in compact frames."],["p","Though some of the American stories deliver flashes of the Jhabvala economy—New York captured in snatches of “street smells, petrol fumes, leaking gas pipes, newly poured tar, pretzels, mangoes from Mexico, Chinese noodles, overblown flowers”—her satirical edge, so keen in the Indian fiction, is dulled. Maybe it’s harder to convey ironic detachment when you feel more at home. There’s an evanescence to many of these Western tales, as if Jhabvala’s writing turned its face away from the sun and grew obscure. Two of the central characters in the collection’s title story fade entirely by the time it ends; in the parting scene, they appear only in a photograph, “a shimmer of two figures in light-coloured clothes on the verge of disappearing from sight.”"],["p","It’s in the later stories in this volume that one becomes aware of how much triangulation pervades Jhabvala’s work. It’s not just classic love triangles, though there are many of those—best portrayed in the collection’s final story, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/03/25/the-judges-will"},"The Judge’s Will"],",” in which a widow discovers the existence of her husband’s longtime mistress. Jhabvala is an artful geometer, and she skews her angles boldly. Consider “Ménage,” in which a daughter finds out that her mother and aunt share a lover, before sleeping with him herself. Or “Pagans,” in which two sisters sleep with the husband of one, and take up the same young Indian protégé. Or “Great Expectations,” the puzzling account of an American woman who becomes a surrogate mother qua partner to a self-involved divorcée and her adolescent daughter. These stories, set primarily in New York, are among the weakest in the collection—or maybe it’s that by the time one gets to them the pattern appears formulaic."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20obvious%20analogy%20is%20with%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20own%20triangulated%20life%E2%80%94Europe%2C%20India%2C%20America%E2%80%94and%20it%20prompts%20the%20perennial%20question%20posed%20of%20diasporic%2C%20post-colonial%2C%20mixed-up%2C%20or%20migrant%20writers.%20Where%20does%20she%20fit%3F%20The%20Library%20of%20Congress%20classification%20system%20places%20Jhabvala%20alongside%20Indian-origin%20writers%20in%20English%2C%20but%20as%20a%20Continental%20European%20writing%20in%20English%20she%20could%20just%20as%20well%20have%20been%20shelved%20with%20Joseph%20Conrad%20and%20%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.newyorker.com%2Fcontributors%2Fvladimir-nabokov%5C%22%3EVladimir%20Nabokov%3C%2Fa%3E.%20It%E2%80%99s%20equally%20tricky%20to%20situate%20Jhabvala%20in%20the%20binary%20of%20power%20and%20powerlessness%20favored%20by%20much%20post-colonial%20criticism.%20As%20Salman%20Rushdie%20once%20pointed%20out%2C%20%E2%80%9CLooked%20at%20from%20the%20point%20of%20view%20that%20literature%20must%20be%20nationally%20connected%20and%20even%20committed%2C%20it%20becomes%20simply%20impossible%20to%20understand%20the%20cast%20of%20mind%20and%20vision%20of%20a%20rootless%20intellect%20like%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s.%E2%80%9D%20No%20intellect%20can%20be%20truly%20rootless%3B%20it%20always%20takes%20hold%20in%20the%20soil%20of%20influence%20and%20experience.%20But%20it%E2%80%99s%20useless%20to%20expect%20writers%20to%20be%20pine%20trees%2C%20lined%20up%20neatly%20in%20a%20forest%2C%20when%20many%20are%20more%20like%20banyans%2C%20whose%20dangling%20aerial%20roots%20can%20make%20them%20into%20a%20forest%20of%20one.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20quintessential%20outsider%E2%80%94%E2%80%9COnce%20you%E2%80%99re%20a%20refugee%2C%20I%20guess%20you%E2%80%99re%20always%20a%20refugee%2C%E2%80%9D%20Jhabvala%20said%E2%80%94she%20sometimes%20leaves%20the%20reader%20of%20these%20stories%20craving%20interiority.%20She%20is%20a%20relentless%20externalizer%2C%20which%20infuses%20her%20plots%20with%20a%20certain%20energy%3B%20but%20many%20of%20her%20characters%20do%20things%20for%20reasons%20they%20don%E2%80%99t%20seem%20to%20understand%20themselves%2C%20and%20the%20reader%20ends%20up%20little%20wiser.%20It%E2%80%99s%20tempting%20to%20relate%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20emotional%20reticence%20to%20the%20great%20silencing%20of%20the%20Holocaust.%20%E2%80%9CYou%E2%80%99ve%20never%20used%20any%20of%20that%20as%20material%20for%20your%20writing%2C%20have%20you%3F%E2%80%9D%20a%20radio%20interviewer%20asked%20Jhabvala%20in%201999.%20%E2%80%9CEffectively%2C%20you%E2%80%99ve%20wiped%20it%20out.%E2%80%9D%20%E2%80%9CYou%20can%E2%80%99t%20wipe%20it%20out%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20replied%2C%20flicking%20away%20the%20inquiry.%20%E2%80%9CYou%20just%20wish%20so%20much%20it%20hadn%E2%80%99t%20happened.%E2%80%9D%20You%20also%20imagine%20there%E2%80%99s%20a%20lot%20to%20be%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20screenwriting%2C%20though%2C%20externalization%20is%20everything%2C%20and%20her%20characteristic%20restraint%20was%20her%20signal%20contribution%20to%20the%20other%20great%20triangle%20of%20her%20life%3A%20Jhabvala%2C%20Merchant%2C%20Ivory.%20Actors%20can%20supply%20explanation%20without%20words%2C%20and%2C%20in%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20surgically%20rendered%20adaptations%20of%20Forster%2C%20James%2C%20and%20Kazuo%20Ishiguro%2C%20the%20strangled%20emotion%20that%20plays%20across%20the%20face%20of%20an%20Emma%20Thompson%20or%20an%20Anthony%20Hopkins%20can%20be%20exquisitely%20painful%20to%20watch.%20The%20distinctive%20magic%20of%20the%20Merchant%20Ivory%20world%20comes%20from%20the%20juxtaposition%20of%20Jhabvala%E2%80%99s%20verbal%20austerity%20and%20the%20sumptuous%2C%20almost%20unforgivably%20stylish%20scenes%20laid%20by%20Ivory%2C%20where%20every%20precisely%20delivered%20word%2C%20wink%2C%20or%20wince%20finds%20its%20material%20counterpart%20in%20the%20polished%20salt%20cellar%2C%20the%20floppy%20lock%2C%20and%20the%20sun-saturated%20Tuscan%20earth.%20Jhabvala%20populated%20the%20rooms%3B%20Ivory%20created%20the%20view.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOne%20of%20Ivory%E2%80%99s%20favorite%20film%20sets%20appears%20in%20the%201970%20movie%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FBombay-Talkies-Rani-Mukerji%2Fdp%2FB078851MHV%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dinstant-video%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416815%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DBombay%2BTalkie%5C%22%3EBombay%20Talkie%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20trio%E2%80%99s%20fourth%20film%20together.%20%E2%80%9CBombay%20Talkie%E2%80%9D%20is%20a%20meta-narrative%20about%20writing%20and%20filmmaking%2C%20folded%20around%20a%20love%20triangle%20involving%20a%20British%20novelist%2C%20a%20movie%20star%2C%20and%20a%20screenwriter.%20In%20the%20opening%20scene%2C%20the%20author%20gets%20a%20tour%20of%20a%20Bombay%20movie%20studio.%20She%20pauses%20in%20front%20of%20a%20giant%20typewriter%2C%20on%20which%20dancing%20girls%20spring%20from%20key%20to%20key.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20call%20it%20the%20Fate%20Machine%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20director%20tells%20her%20sombrely.%20%E2%80%9CTypewriter%20keys%20represent%20the%20keys%20of%20life.%20And%20we%20human%20beings%20dance%20on%20them.%20And%20then%20when%20we%20dance%2C%20as%20we%20press%20down%20the%20keys%20of%20the%20machine%2C%20the%20story%20that%E2%80%99s%20written%20is%20the%20story%20of%20our%20fate.%E2%80%9D%20It%E2%80%99s%20as%20clear%20a%20statement%20about%20the%20value%20of%20writing%20as%20the%20reticent%20Jhabvala%20would%20ever%20deliver%E2%80%94and%2C%20like%20much%20of%20her%20best%20work%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20a%20satire.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The obvious analogy is with Jhabvala’s own triangulated life—Europe, India, America—and it prompts the perennial question posed of diasporic, post-colonial, mixed-up, or migrant writers. Where does she fit? The Library of Congress classification system places Jhabvala alongside Indian-origin writers in English, but as a Continental European writing in English she could just as well have been shelved with Joseph Conrad and ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/contributors/vladimir-nabokov"},"Vladimir Nabokov"],". It’s equally tricky to situate Jhabvala in the binary of power and powerlessness favored by much post-colonial criticism. As Salman Rushdie once pointed out, “Looked at from the point of view that literature must be nationally connected and even committed, it becomes simply impossible to understand the cast of mind and vision of a rootless intellect like Jhabvala’s.” No intellect can be truly rootless; it always takes hold in the soil of influence and experience. But it’s useless to expect writers to be pine trees, lined up neatly in a forest, when many are more like banyans, whose dangling aerial roots can make them into a forest of one."],["p","The quintessential outsider—“Once you’re a refugee, I guess you’re always a refugee,” Jhabvala said—she sometimes leaves the reader of these stories craving interiority. She is a relentless externalizer, which infuses her plots with a certain energy; but many of her characters do things for reasons they don’t seem to understand themselves, and the reader ends up little wiser. It’s tempting to relate Jhabvala’s emotional reticence to the great silencing of the Holocaust. “You’ve never used any of that as material for your writing, have you?” a radio interviewer asked Jhabvala in 1999. “Effectively, you’ve wiped it out.” “You can’t wipe it out,” she replied, flicking away the inquiry. “You just wish so much it hadn’t happened.” You also imagine there’s a lot to be said."],["p","In screenwriting, though, externalization is everything, and her characteristic restraint was her signal contribution to the other great triangle of her life: Jhabvala, Merchant, Ivory. Actors can supply explanation without words, and, in Jhabvala’s surgically rendered adaptations of Forster, James, and Kazuo Ishiguro, the strangled emotion that plays across the face of an Emma Thompson or an Anthony Hopkins can be exquisitely painful to watch. The distinctive magic of the Merchant Ivory world comes from the juxtaposition of Jhabvala’s verbal austerity and the sumptuous, almost unforgivably stylish scenes laid by Ivory, where every precisely delivered word, wink, or wince finds its material counterpart in the polished salt cellar, the floppy lock, and the sun-saturated Tuscan earth. Jhabvala populated the rooms; Ivory created the view."],["p","One of Ivory’s favorite film sets appears in the 1970 movie “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Bombay-Talkies-Rani-Mukerji/dp/B078851MHV/ref=sr_1_1?s=instant-video&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416815&sr=1-1&keywords=Bombay+Talkie"},"Bombay Talkie"],",” the trio’s fourth film together. “Bombay Talkie” is a meta-narrative about writing and filmmaking, folded around a love triangle involving a British novelist, a movie star, and a screenwriter. In the opening scene, the author gets a tour of a Bombay movie studio. She pauses in front of a giant typewriter, on which dancing girls spring from key to key. “We call it the Fate Machine,” a director tells her sombrely. “Typewriter keys represent the keys of life. And we human beings dance on them. And then when we dance, as we press down the keys of the machine, the story that’s written is the story of our fate.” It’s as clear a statement about the value of writing as the reticent Jhabvala would ever deliver—and, like much of her best work, it’s a satire. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"592e2a57980e951c27678628","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"592e2a57980e951c27678628","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"A 20in%20red.%20A%20half-dozen%20children%20scampered%20around%20on%20the%20floor.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFowler%2C%20asked%20how%20he%20and%20Bradley%20had%20met%2C%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CThere%20was%20a%20party%E2%80%94do%20you%20know%20Gina%20Lollobrigida%3F%E2%80%9D%20The%20Italian%20actress.%20Of%20course.%20%E2%80%9CShe%20asked%20me%20to%20come%20to%20Africa%20with%20her%20to%20look%20for%20an%20endangered%20species.%20I%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20married%20at%20the%20time%2C%20and%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20%E2%80%9D%20Carrie%20began%20to%20roll%20him%20away.%20It%20was%20time%20for%20a%20speech.%20The%20men%20assembled%20beneath%20a%20screen%20showing%20photos%20of%20their%20younger%2C%20haler%20selves.%20Apparently%20under%20siege%2C%20a%20bartender%2C%20who%E2%80%99d%20set%20up%20his%20wares%20by%20a%20pair%20of%20giant%20elephant%20tusks%2C%20fled%20his%20post%2C%20and%20a%20phalanx%20of%20guests%20moved%20in%20to%20serve%20themselves.%20The%20mission%20of%20humanity%20is%20to%20drink%20gin.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20picked%20up%20John%20Bradley%20off%20the%20streets%20of%20New%20York%2C%E2%80%9D%20Fowler%20said%20into%20a%20microphone.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20was%20wandering%20around%2C%20on%20dog%20food.%E2%80%9D%20He%20added%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20approve%20of%20the%20hat%20he%20wears.%20It%20dates%20him.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFowler%20went%20on%3A%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99ve%20had%20a%20few%20close%20calls.%20In%20the%20Amazon%2C%20I%20made%20a%20mistake.%20I%20was%20approaching%20an%20eighteen-foot%20anaconda%2C%20and%20I%20slipped.%20It%20grabbed%20me%20by%20the%20hand%20and%20swallowed%20my%20arm%20up%20to%20the%20shoulder.%E2%80%9D%20Most%20of%20the%20guests%20had%20heard%20this%20one%2C%20but%20he%20kept%20on%2C%20in%20the%20ingenuous%20manner%20that%20had%20made%20him%20a%20regular%20guest%20of%20Johnny%20Carson%2C%20who%E2%80%99d%20dubbed%20him%20Jim%20Foul-Up.%20%E2%80%9CAnaconda%20have%20half-inch%20teeth%2C%20so%20I%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20pull%20it%20out.%20Sorry%2C%20getting%20gory.%E2%80%9D%20Bradley%20jumped%20in%20with%20another%20anaconda%20anecdote%2C%20in%20which%20he%20rescued%20Fowler%20by%20jabbing%20the%20serpent%20between%20the%20eyes%20with%20a%20needle.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBradley%20then%20segued%20into%20one%20of%20his%20go-to%20yarns%2C%20about%20being%20kidnapped%2C%20en%20route%20from%20the%20Jordanian%20royal%20palace%20to%20see%20the%20Syrian%20Prime%20Minister%20in%20Damascus.%20He%20was%20strung%20up%20with%20barbed%20wire%20from%20the%20limb%20of%20a%20fig%20tree.%20His%20interpreter%2C%20luckily%2C%20was%20the%20niece%20of%20the%20leader%20of%20the%20Druze.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20got%20us%20released%20and%20sent%20us%20a%20fast%20donkey.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESomebody%E2%80%99s%20grandson%2C%20in%20green%20pants%20and%20a%20bowl%20cut%2C%20crawled%20by%20on%20the%20carpet%20and%20nearly%20clipped%20Bradley%20in%20the%20calves.%20Another%20close%20call.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Out on Madison Avenue, a woman parked an S.U.V. and then hurried half a block east, into the doorway of a Jacobean mansion. In the foyer, a few people were struggling to get an elderly gentleman in a wheelchair up a ramp. The woman assessed the geometrics and helped ease him up and into an old elevator."],["p","The man was Jim Fowler, the zoologist and the former host of “Mutual of Omaha’s Wild Kingdom,” the pioneering nature procedural; the woman was his daughter, Carrie. They’d arrived here, at the headquarters of the Explorers Club, for a party celebrating the half-century-long friendship between Fowler and John Atwater Bradley, a retired management consultant, Shawangunk squire, adventurer, raconteur, and exuberant dropper of names."],["p","Bradley, who is eighty-seven, was already upstairs, in the club’s vast, panelled Map Room. He had on yellow slacks, a salmon-colored Princeton reunion blazer (class of 1954), a bawdy-Santa tie, and a straw boater with a black-and-orange band and a pin in the shape of a Thompson submachine gun. He greeted a guest with a forearm clasp: “I’m a Quaker, not a shaker.” It didn’t take much to get him going: Happy Rockefeller, Albert Einstein, the Bouvier girls—“I took Jackie out before she met Jack.”"],["p","As Fowler rolled in (a recent health scare had required the temporary use of a wheelchair), Bradley handed him a jumbo shrimp on a paper napkin and said, “Merry Christmas.” Fowler, who was wearing Ugg boots, a safari jacket, and a Citroën ball cap, looked at Bradley and said, “I’m embarrassed to have this affair with a guy dressed like that.”"],["p","Fowler retreated to one end of the room. Guests took turns in the chair beside him. “I’ve gone around the sun eighty-eight times, and I have evolved into thinking a lot about the universe,” he said, to one. “I keep hitting barriers. I have never heard the philosophers talk about the mission of humanity. What the heck is it?”"],["p","“To ravage the earth?”"],["p","“No, I’ve figured it out,” he went on. “It’s to create a quality of life for all the people on the planet. The world of nature is not a very pleasant place. Most living things are fighting and killing and eating each other. I was with some cannibals in Africa years ago, and I asked one of them what his name meant, and he said, ‘It means, I’m strong and my axe is sharp, so no one can kill me or eat me.’ ” Fowler’s wife, Betsey, came by with another shrimp."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1d35fd41e4c73c088d6b93%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d35fd41e4c73c088d6b93%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1d35fd41e4c73c088d6b93%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d35fd41e4c73c088d6b93"}]],["p","The Fowlers live in Rowayton, Connecticut, but maintain a wildlife ranch (zebras, elands, and ostriches running free) in Jim’s native town of Albany, Georgia, where his father, an Indiana Quaker and a soil scientist, settled after the First World War to grow pecans."],["p","As incorrigible explorers and networkers, Bradley and Fowler—J.B. and Jungle Jim—had developed a deep kinship over the years, seasoned with competitive spunk. Their families were close. Carrie Fowler had grown up with Bradley’s daughter, Camilla, the founder of the clothing company CK Bradley, who was also present, and, like Carrie, tall, blond, and dressed all in red. A half-dozen children scampered around on the floor."],["p","Fowler, asked how he and Bradley had met, said, “There was a party—do you know Gina Lollobrigida?” The Italian actress. Of course. “She asked me to come to Africa with her to look for an endangered species. I wasn’t married at the time, and . . . ” Carrie began to roll him away. It was time for a speech. The men assembled beneath a screen showing photos of their younger, haler selves. Apparently under siege, a bartender, who’d set up his wares by a pair of giant elephant tusks, fled his post, and a phalanx of guests moved in to serve themselves. The mission of humanity is to drink gin."],["p","“I picked up John Bradley off the streets of New York,” Fowler said into a microphone. “He was wandering around, on dog food.” He added, “I don’t approve of the hat he wears. It dates him.”"],["p","Fowler went on: “I’ve had a few close calls. In the Amazon, I made a mistake. I was approaching an eighteen-foot anaconda, and I slipped. It grabbed me by the hand and swallowed my arm up to the shoulder.” Most of the guests had heard this one, but he kept on, in the ingenuous manner that had made him a regular guest of Johnny Carson, who’d dubbed him Jim Foul-Up. “Anaconda have half-inch teeth, so I couldn’t pull it out. Sorry, getting gory.” Bradley jumped in with another anaconda anecdote, in which he rescued Fowler by jabbing the serpent between the eyes with a needle."],["p","Bradley then segued into one of his go-to yarns, about being kidnapped, en route from the Jordanian royal palace to see the Syrian Prime Minister in Damascus. He was strung up with barbed wire from the limb of a fig tree. His interpreter, luckily, was the niece of the leader of the Druze. “He got us released and sent us a fast donkey.”"],["p","Somebody’s grandson, in green pants and a bowl cut, crawled by on the carpet and nearly clipped Bradley in the calves. Another close call. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c7d2bc86f2c9a2449a7","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Explorers 0his%20hand.%20%E2%80%9CYours.%E2%80%9D%20He%20flattens%20the%20hand.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CHe%20stood%20very%20straight%2C%E2%80%9D%20Amer%20agrees%2C%20and%20stands%20up%20to%20demonstrate.%20%E2%80%9CVery%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94he%20pushes%20his%20shoulders%20back%E2%80%94%E2%80%9Cimpressive.%E2%80%9D%20He%20sits%20down%20again.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20boy%20turns%20to%20the%20sheeting%20of%20the%20stall%20behind%20him%2C%20where%20he%20has%20pinned%20up%20a%20page%20torn%20out%20of%20a%20magazine.%20It%20shows%20a%20marble%20foot%20on%20a%20plinth%2C%20jagged%20where%20the%20leg%20should%20continue.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20most%20beautiful%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says%20to%20Amer%2C%20and%20traces%20the%20foot%E2%80%99s%20arch.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAmer%20leans%20in%20and%20their%20knees%20touch.%20His%20head%20dips%20toward%20the%20boy%E2%80%99s.%20He%20smells%20hay%20and%20frying%20oil%20and%20dark%20corners.%20%E2%80%9CHow%20funny%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20boy%20says.%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20like%20shoes.%20In%20the%20village%2C%20I%20was%20barefoot.%20The%20foot%20should%20be%20free.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETheir%20tea%20arrives%20clattering%20on%20a%20tray.%20Amer%20asks%20him%20about%20his%20village.%20%E2%80%9CThere%20was%20fighting%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20boy%20says%2C%20blowing%20hard%20across%20the%20cup%2C%20wrinkling%20the%20tan%20skin%20that%20has%20formed%20on%20the%20surface%20of%20the%20tea.%20%E2%80%9CAnd%20they%20moved%20us%20to%20a%20camp.%20An%20uncle%20called%20me%20here%20and%20gave%20me%20this.%E2%80%9D%20He%20waves%20at%20the%20stall%20behind%20him.%20%E2%80%9CFirst%20in%20Gizri%2C%20then%20Phase%205%2C%20now%20here.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAmer%20leaves%20his%20father%E2%80%99s%20shoes%20with%20the%20boy.%20The%20boy%20shrugs.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99ll%20polish%20them%20up%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Between Irum’s Beauty Spot and Primetime Bakery, below a tall palm, a makeshift stall has appeared. It’s constructed from coarsely woven white plastic sheeting with “Save the Children” and a jumping jack printed on it in red. A boy, perhaps in his late teens, is sitting on an upturned crate in front of it, with a shoe, heel up, in his lap."],["p","“It’s a dying art,” Amer says to him, slamming and then reslamming the door of his battered Civic behind him."],["p","“It’s the glue,” the boy says. He wipes the excess from the welt of the shoe with a grubby, balled-up cloth. “With the right one, you’re set. None of this UHU superglue. The one like paste. Like flour and water.” The midday sun catches his eyelashes and the thick edge of his nose. He presses his fingers against the sole of the shoe and his nails flush white."],["p","The electricity cables overhead are slack and swaying. An electrician is perched in the crook of the tree, where the branches meet the trunk, holding a cable with one hand and balancing himself with the other."],["p","A rickshaw throttles past Amer. A man parks his sugarcane cart in the shade of a flowering jacaranda tree. He switches on the rattling motor of his juicer and sharpens a giant blade against a stone."],["p","Amer’s mother’s voice cuts through the clamor. Above him, he sees her wheelchair reverse from their balcony into the apartment. The sea air has filigreed the railings with rust."],["p","Upstairs, Amer finds her sitting in the dark, the ayah fanning her with a folded newspaper."],["p","“Small mercies,” she says. “What happened today?”"],["p","“They are making offices,” Amer says. “Where our house is.”"],["p","She gives a little shriek, like air squeaking from a balloon."],["p","“At the end of the month,” Amer says. “Let’s not talk about it again. There’s a shoe boy downstairs. Do you have anything for him?”"],["p","“I saw you talking from the balcony,” his mother says. “Dirty-looking.” She smooths the fabric of her housecoat against her lap."],["p","The ayah follows him out of the room and taps him on the elbow. “There was a trunk of your father’s shoes,” she says. “That boy could have sold them.”"],["p","Amer takes an old pair of shoes to be repaired. One has a hole in the sole. “The foot is the noblest part of the body,” the boy says. He slips a hand inside the shoe. “It is the body’s beast of burden. It is the foot soldier for the body’s army. Two hundred rupees at Maghrib.”"],["p","An electricity cable swishes alongside a pole, fuzzy at the end like an elephant’s tail."],["p","Amer returns to the apartment. What was in the plot opposite their block has been demolished. A pit has been dug and girders and pillars stacked. A mosque has appeared on the far corner of the plot with a minaret so tall and narrow it should topple. The shadows of tree branches lengthen across the ceiling of his bedroom. He hears the azaan as though the muezzin were at the foot of his bed."],["p","He goes down to collect the shoes. The boy asks him to sit. He rolls a steel cannister along its fine edge to Amer. Amer tries the shoes on."],["p","The boy watches him wedge his heel in with a finger. “You have wide, flat feet,” he says. “Not graceful but dependable.” He directs Amer to walk, and Amer strides to a Suzuki pickup parked a short distance away and back."],["p","“I have some shoes of my father’s,” Amer says. “Maybe you can sell them.”"],["p","“I don’t sell shoes,” the boy says. “But bring them.”"],["p","Upstairs, his mother and the ayah are arguing over his mother’s handbag. Each holds one side and it gapes between them. “There was,” his mother says. “I know there was.” A bulb in a lamp on a side table flickers and fizzes."],["p","“There wasn’t,” the ayah says. “I bought butter and flour and dal. What did I buy that with?”"],["p","“And you’ve broken every cup,” his mother says, letting go of the bag. She grabs a cup from the table and shakes it at the ayah. “Bring me the set. There are fifty-two pieces. I want to see every one.”"],["p","“We should put something up,” Amer says. There are dark squares on the wall where pictures used to hang. “It doesn’t look nice.”"],["p","“They’re tearing down the old house,” his mother tells the ayah. “Have you heard? That bastard his brother. They allowed us nothing of his. To come and take the pictures. As though we were thieves. And now the house.” She covers her eyes with crooked fingers. Amer thinks of his father, delighted but never happy. He thinks of the chowkidar’s son bursting through the back door of the house, shouting, “He’s fallen! He’s fallen like a bird in the street.”"],["p","From the balcony, Amer can see the boy packing up his stall. He unpins the sheeting from four metal rods, which are splayed against uneven paving stones, and folds it into a suitcase, along with several plastic bags of shoes. He ducks into the doorway of their building with the crate he sits on and then again with the steel cannister he offered to Amer. With the case balanced on his shoulder, the boy walks down the darkening street in the direction of Clifton. Amer imagines him tending goats on a green hillside."],["p","“We offered to send him to the best schools,” his mother tells the ayah, nodding toward Amer. “Oxford, Cambridge. People were begging their parents to go, but he wouldn’t. He wanted to stay. We were happy, of course. But now he could be making millions.” She fishes a dirty hundred-rupee note out of a pocket of her handbag and gives it triumphantly to the ayah."],["p","Amer finds a pair of alligator Gucci loafers that were his father’s at the back of his mother’s cupboard, with an empty bottle of Monsieur de Givenchy slotted inside one and a razor with a bone handle in the other. He takes the shoes to the boy in the morning. Someone has tied the loose electricity cable to the pole with a thick red cloth."],["p","“Good quality,” the boy says. He turns one shoe in his hands, sniffs inside it. “Foreign. Maybe China.” He brings the steel cannister for Amer to sit on. “I can’t sell them,” the boy says. They order tea from the seller up the road."],["p","A family on a motorbike swerves to avoid an S.U.V. coming the wrong way. Two beggar children kick an empty plastic bottle back and forth. The sugarcane seller sings, “Her body is like a perfumed song,” as he hacks long stalks of sugarcane in half and then in quarters. “Her body is a marble statue.”"],["p","The boy strokes the length of the shoe. “Narrow,” he says. “A precise man.” He turns it over. The sole has worn a little in the center. “Even,” he says. “Show me.” He points at Amer’s shoe, and Amer takes it off. The boy runs his finger along the edge of the sole. “Worn on the sides. Because you’re uncertain.” He shows Amer the wear on his father’s shoe again. “He knows what he wants. His foot is like this.” He arches his hand. “Yours.” He flattens the hand."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1c4ba2d2db9849ec9e43d0"}]],["p","“He stood very straight,” Amer agrees, and stands up to demonstrate. “Very”—he pushes his shoulders back—“impressive.” He sits down again."],["p","The boy turns to the sheeting of the stall behind him, where he has pinned up a page torn out of a magazine. It shows a marble foot on a plinth, jagged where the leg should continue. “The most beautiful,” he says to Amer, and traces the foot’s arch."],["p","Amer leans in and their knees touch. His head dips toward the boy’s. He smells hay and frying oil and dark corners. “How funny,” the boy says. “I don’t like shoes. In the village, I was barefoot. The foot should be free.”"],["p","Their tea arrives clattering on a tray. Amer asks him about his village. “There was fighting,” the boy says, blowing hard across the cup, wrinkling the tan skin that has formed on the surface of the tea. “And they moved us to a camp. An uncle called me here and gave me this.” He waves at the stall behind him. “First in Gizri, then Phase 5, now here.”"],["p","Amer leaves his father’s shoes with the boy. The boy shrugs. “I’ll polish them up,” he mother is watching reruns of last night’s Turkish soap. “You used to read,” he says."],["p","“Read? I can barely see.” She turns up the volume."],["p","“How tall was Dad?” he asks."],["p","“Ha,” she shouts over the TV. “He was so much older but we were head to head.” She taps her forehead with her knuckle. “If I was in heels I had to keep sitting.”"],["p","“There was a trunk of Dad’s stuff,” Amer says. “With his shoes and things.”"],["p","“What do you want with that?” she asks."],["p","“I just want to know where it is,” he says."],["p","“You don’t see anyone,” she says."],["p","“I’m too tired.” He pauses at the window, and the smell of jasmine and cigarettes winds in from the street below. He pulls the shutters closed. “It’s always the same talk. Old times. What about new times? What about the next forty years? I’d rather throw myself out of the window than think about what happened. And from here it wouldn’t fix a thing. I’d only break a leg. Both, at best.”"],["p","“What are you saying?” his mother says. She mutes the volume on the TV. “I thought of that friend of yours—why? What they did to him. Strangled him with the telephone wire. Dirty things he was up to. Picking up boys from the street. Pimping them to who? People we know, probably.”"],["p","“Sheikh Asad? He wasn’t doing that,” Amer says. “I hardly knew him.”"],["p","“Are you eating?” she says. “There’s packet soup and kebabs on the tray.”"],["p","He finds the ayah napping on the kitchen floor. He asks her about the trunk. She sits up and straightens her sari. “I saw it with my own eyes,” she says. “With his things. His shoes and books.” The fan turns lazily above her. “But we fled from the old house like refugees,” she says. “We didn’t take it. There was a cupboard under the stairs opposite your father’s study. You remember? The cupboard without a handle. You couldn’t see it, you had to feel for the edge and push. It was there.”"],["p","His father’s study had a key in the outside lock. The door handle didn’t turn, so you had to open it with the key. A wall of books faced you when you entered. es.%20Someone%20offered%20two%20thousand.%20I%20didn%E2%80%99t%20say%20yes%2C%20I%20didn%E2%80%99t%20say%20no.%20I%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98I%20will%20check.%E2%80%99%20But%20he%20gave%20a%20deposit.%E2%80%9D%20He%20removes%20a%20folded%20thousand-rupee%20note%20from%20his%20chest%20pocket.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20a%20good%20price%2C%E2%80%9D%20Amer%20says%2C%20looking%20at%20the%20palms%20of%20his%20hands.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CYou%20should%20have%20heard%20me.%20I%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98These%20shoes%2C%20these%20are%20the%20best%20shoes%2C%20made%20from%20the%20finest%20skin.%20Skin%20like%20a%20baby.%20To%20wear%20these%20shoes%20is%20to%20wear%20a%20glove%20made%20of%20skin.%E2%80%99%20He%20wanted%20them%20just%20like%20that.%20I%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98Come%20back%20in%20the%20afternoon.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EA%20rickshaw%20engine%20fires%20like%20a%20gun%20and%20startles%20crows%20from%20a%20thickly%20flowering%20gulmohar%20tree.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20thought%20you%E2%80%99d%20be%20happy%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20good%2C%E2%80%9D%20Amer%20says.%20%E2%80%9CWell%20done.%20Commission%20for%20you.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20boy%20takes%20a%20pair%20of%20burgundy%20sandals%20from%20the%20pile%20behind%20him%20and%20wipes%20them%20with%20a%20cloth.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%20can%E2%80%99t%20sell%20them%2C%E2%80%9D%20Amer%20says.%20%E2%80%9CThey%E2%80%99re%20my%20father%E2%80%99s%20shoes.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20boy%20nods.%20He%20fishes%20a%20green%20plastic%20bag%20out%20from%20under%20his%20crate.%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says.%20He%20takes%20one%20of%20Amer%E2%80%99s%20father%E2%80%99s%20loafers%20out.%20%E2%80%9CSee.%E2%80%9D%20He%20angles%20it%20toward%20Amer.%20On%20the%20inside%20there%E2%80%99s%20the%20faint%20imprint%20of%20a%20foot.%20%E2%80%9CWhat%20did%20I%20say%3F%20Narrow.%20Arched.%20The%20foot%20of%20a%20king.%20And%20the%20toes.%20See.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CA%20king%2C%E2%80%9D%20Amer%20says.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99ll%20tell%20you%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20boy%20says.%20He%20instructs%20Amer%20to%20take%20off%20his%20shoes.%20He%20props%20one%20of%20Amer%E2%80%99s%20feet%20in%20his%20lap%20and%20peels%20off%20his%20sock.%20%E2%80%9CNylon%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says%2C%20and%20holds%20it%20up%20to%20the%20light.%20He%20runs%20his%20thumb%20along%20the%20arch%20of%20Amer%E2%80%99s%20foot%20and%20the%20callused%20outside%20edge.%20%E2%80%9CA%20lot%20of%20tension%20today%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20boy%20says.%20He%20rubs%20a%20nub%20of%20bone%20that%20protrudes%20from%20the%20side%20of%20Amer%E2%80%99s%20toe.%20%E2%80%9CYou%20do%20too%20much%20for%20people%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20says.%20%E2%80%9CBut%2C%20see%2C%20you%20could%20never%20wear%20these.%E2%80%9D%20He%20puts%20Amer%E2%80%99s%20father%E2%80%99s%20shoe%20beside%20Amer%E2%80%99s%20foot%20to%20show%20him.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CO.K.%2C%E2%80%9D%20Amer%20says%2C%20and%20pulls%20his%20foot%20away.%20The%20salty%20sea%20breeze%20stings%20his%20eyes.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CListen%20to%20the%20foot%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20boy%20says.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20foot%20says%20go%20forward%2C%20go%20back%2C%20stand%20still.%20If%20you%20listen%20you%E2%80%99ll%20know.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Amer passes the stall a few times a day that week and, if there’s no customer there, he stops. He calls for tea, and he and the boy sip it together. They don’t quite look at each other, instead cocking their heads toward the car horns and the fruit sellers calling and the birds cawing and circling overhead and the tune the ice-gola cart plays."],["p","One morning Amer hears shouting on the street. An older man is arguing with the shoe boy in Pashto. Amer positions himself at the vegetable stall nearby and selects some aubergines, feeling them as though that could tell him something. The boy clenches and unclenches his hands at the hem of his kurta. People stop to watch. “Whatever he’s done, forgive him,” a legless beggar on a wheeled sled says as he paws himself into the shade. The man shouts a question at the boy. The boy doesn’t answer, and the man takes off a sandal and slaps the boy across the face with it. Then he climbs onto a motorbike and rides away."],["p","Amer pauses at the boy’s stall with his bags of groceries. “I could kill him,” the boy says. “My uncle.”"],["p","He gestures that Amer should sit, then busies himself with a box of tools at the back of his stall. He turns suddenly. “I sold your shoes,” he says. “Your father’s shoes. Someone offered two thousand. I didn’t say yes, I didn’t say no. I said, ‘I will check.’ But he gave a deposit.” He removes a folded thousand-rupee note from his chest pocket."],["p","“It’s a good price,” Amer says, looking at the palms of his hands."],["p","“You should have heard me. I said, ‘These shoes, these are the best shoes, made from the finest skin. Skin like a baby. To wear these shoes is to wear a glove made of skin.’ He wanted them just like that. I said, ‘Come back in the afternoon.’ ”"],["p","A rickshaw engine fires like a gun and startles crows from a thickly flowering gulmohar tree."],["p","“I thought you’d be happy,” he says."],["p","“It’s good,” Amer says. “Well done. Commission for you.”"],["p","The boy takes a pair of burgundy sandals from the pile behind him and wipes them with a cloth."],["p","“I can’t sell them,” Amer says. “They’re my father’s shoes.”"],["p","The boy nods. He fishes a green plastic bag out from under his crate. “Oh,” he says. He takes one of Amer’s father’s loafers out. “See.” He angles it toward Amer. On the inside there’s the faint imprint of a foot. “What did I say? Narrow. Arched. The foot of a king. And the toes. See.”"],["p","“A king,” Amer says."],["p","“I’ll tell you,” the boy says. He instructs Amer to take off his shoes. He props one of Amer’s feet in his lap and peels off his sock. “Nylon,” he says, and holds it up to the light. He runs his thumb along the arch of Amer’s foot and the callused outside edge. “A lot of tension today,” the boy says. He rubs a nub of bone that protrudes from the side of Amer’s toe. “You do too much for people,” he says. “But, see, you could never wear these.” He puts Amer’s father’s shoe beside Amer’s foot to show him."],["p","“O.K.,” Amer says, and pulls his foot away. The salty sea breeze stings his eyes."],["p","“Listen to the foot,” the boy says. “The foot says go forward, go back, stand still. If you listen you’ll leaves the vegetables upstairs with the ayah and goes to Aunty Park for a walk. On his way back, he picks up a pound cake from Primetime for his mother."],["p","She is tapping the arms of her chair when the ayah wheels her in for tea that afternoon. “I didn’t sleep at all,” she says. “I remembered something.” She pauses. “Why are you in the dark?” The ayah draws the curtains. Light filters into the room through the jacaranda outside, the vent of the air-conditioner that overhangs the balcony, and the shutters that aren’t quite pressed to the wall. “How could they say he gave it away?” she says. “Your father promised me the house. He would give it to a stranger sooner than his brother.” She takes a wedge of cake between her fingers. “And for that bastard to throw us out like common servants.” She bites it in half emphatically, then finishes it. “Your father would have kept a record. Written it down.” The ayah switches the overhead fan on. It buzzes but doesn’t turn. “He wouldn’t want us living like this. Waiting for my brother to send another check.”"],["p","“They haven’t fixed it,” Amer tells the ayah."],["p","“Are you listening? This will show everything. That the house is ours.” She reaches across and shakes him."],["p","“What are you talking about?” Amer says. “It’s all done. It’s finished.”"],["p","“Ayah thinks it will be in the trunk. He wrote and wrote. Lists and lists. It could be there. You remember you were asking.” She claps her hands and the rings on her fingers clack like castanets."],["p","“The trunk is gone,” he says. “Where is it?”"],["p","“We didn’t take it,” the ayah says. “It could only be there.”"],["p","“Where? At the house? There’s nothing there.”"],["p","“Everything is there,” his mother says. “What did we take? The clothes on our backs. And then they wouldn’t let us in. To our own house! Of course it’s there.”"],["p","“We took everything that wasn’t fixed to the floor,” he says. “Why didn’t we take that?”"],["p","“We didn’t,” his mother says. “Maybe we didn’t see it. She knows.” His mother nods at the ayah."],["p","“Then let her look,” Amer says."],["p","“Amer!” his mother says. “How can she, with her kidneys?”"],["p","“It makes no difference. You’re losing track of time. It’s all decided. It was decided long ago.”"],["p","“You tell them,” she says. “You never tell people. They know us. The Chief Justice was at my wedding.” She taps a pearly nail against the rim of her cup. “Did your father write?” she says. “Or was that my brother Ricky? It breaks my heart that Ricky died alone. Be thankful you have no siblings to see them die like that.”"],["p","Amer walks up the stairs to the top of the building. The uppermost flight ends at the roof and he hunches there on the steps with his chin on his fist and the ceiling against his head. Death is an opening door, he thinks. He remembers his father’s body wrapped in white gauze, balls of cotton wool in his nostrils and ears, and strangers crowding around him, carrying him away."],["p","He climbs down and finds his shoe seller on the street outside. “Sell them,” Amer says. “And I’ll take you for mithai.”"],["p","“Habshi halwa,” the boy says, laughing."],["p","“And barfi,” Amer says. “And rasmalai and
