\u003c/g>\u003c/svg>"}}},{"body":["div",["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":""}],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3ELike%20all%20dystopian%20narratives%2C%20the%20feminist%20variety%20uses%20stories%20about%20how%20bad%20the%20world%20might%20become%20to%20point%20out%20how%20bad%20it%20already%20is.%20Not%20surprisingly%2C%20feminist%20dystopian%20narratives%20are%20now%20enjoying%20a%20boom%2C%20from%20Hulu%E2%80%99s%20television%20adaptation%20of%20Margaret%20Atwood%E2%80%99s%201985%20novel%2C%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FHandmaids-Tale-Margaret-Atwood-ebook%2Fdp%2FB003JFJHTS%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416861%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DThe%2BHandmaid%25E2%2580%2599s%2BTale%5C%22%3EThe%20Handmaid%E2%80%99s%20Tale%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94Atwood%20recently%20announced%20that%20she%20is%20writing%20a%20sequel%E2%80%94to%20several%20books%20by%20both%20new%20and%20established%20novelists%2C%20including%20Louise%20Erdrich%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FFuture-Home-Living-God-Novel%2Fdp%2F0062694057%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416872%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DFuture%2BHome%2Bof%2Bthe%2BLiving%2BGod%5C%22%3EFuture%20Home%20of%20the%20Living%20God%3C%2Fa%3E%2C%E2%80%9D%20Christina%20Dalcher%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FVox-Christina-Dalcher%2Fdp%2F0440000785%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416884%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DVox%252C%5C%22%3EVox%2C%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20and%20Leni%20Zumas%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FRed-Clocks-Novel-Leni-Zumas%2Fdp%2F0316434787%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416897%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DRed%2BClocks%5C%22%3ERed%20Clocks%3C%2Fa%3E.%E2%80%9D%20These%20writers%20depict%20a%20range%20of%20inventively%20punitive%20societies%3A%20in%20one%2C%20women%20are%20punished%20for%20speaking%20more%20than%20a%20hundred%20words%20per%20day%3B%20in%20another%2C%20the%20government%20takes%20pregnant%20women%20into%20custody%20to%20manage%20a%20fertility%20crisis.%20The%20novels%20extrapolate%20from%20a%20very%20real%20prospect%20of%20curtailed%20rights%2C%20especially%20reproductive%20rights%2C%20to%20imagine%20what%20it%20would%20be%20like%20to%20live%20in%20a%20society%20of%20forced%20marriages%20and%20pregnancies.%20The%20typical%20dystopian%20novel%20is%20at%20least%20as%20much%20about%20the%20world%20it%E2%80%99s%20set%20in%20as%20it%20is%20about%20the%20characters%20who%20inhabit%20it.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ESophie%20Mackintosh%E2%80%99s%20clever%20and%20arresting%20d%C3%A9but%20novel%2C%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FWater-Cure-Novel-Sophie-Mackintosh%2Fdp%2F0385543875%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416910%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DThe%2BWater%2BCure%5C%22%3EThe%20Water%20Cure%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20(Doubleday)%2C%20although%20sometimes%20grouped%20with%20the%20new%20crop%20of%20feminist%20dystopias%2C%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20much%20resemble%20them%20in%20this%20respect.%20It%20constructs%20not%20a%20world%20but%20a%20bubble%20within%20a%20world%E2%80%94in%20other%20words%2C%20a%20family.%20Three%20young%20sisters%20live%20with%20their%20parents%20in%20a%20decommissioned%20seaside%20sanatorium%20that%20was%20once%20a%20grand%20hotel.%20They%20have%20no%20contact%20with%20the%20outside%3B%20their%20father%2C%20King%2C%20leaves%20in%20a%20motorboat%20every%20few%20months%20to%20bring%20back%20supplies%20from%20a%20mainland%20they%20believe%20to%20be%20dangerously%20contaminated.%20Men%20are%20the%20primary%20source%20of%20the%20toxins%2C%20and%20the%20two%20elder%20sisters%20can%20remember%20when%20their%20parents%20provided%20a%20sanctuary%20for%20%E2%80%9Cdamaged%20women%2C%E2%80%9D%20refugees%20who%20had%20been%20harmed%20by%20the%20male%20world.%20The%20therapies%20employed%20were%20harsh%20and%20primitive%3A%20patients%20were%20ordered%20to%20drink%20salt%20water%20until%20they%20vomited%2C%20and%20the%20titular%20%E2%80%9Cwater%20cure%E2%80%9D%20entailed%20a%20near-drowning.%20After%20the%20patients%20stop%20coming%2C%20King%20and%20his%20wife%2C%20Mother%2C%20administer%20the%20same%20cures%20to%20their%20daughters%2C%20observing%20elaborate%20purification%20measures%20whenever%20the%20girls%20come%20into%20contact%20with%20dead%20animals%20or%20a%20particularly%20noxious%20artifact%20from%20the%20greater%20world%2C%20such%20as%20a%20magazine.%20Other%20regular%20treatments%20include%20being%20shrouded%20or%20gagged%20with%20lots%20of%20muslin%3B%20the%20characters%20in%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Water%20Cure%E2%80%9D%20always%20seem%20to%20be%20running%20off%20to%20collect%20a%20bolt%20of%20the%20stuff.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20middle%20sister%2C%20Lia%2C%20narrates%20the%20novel%E2%80%99s%20long%20central%20section.%20It%20comes%20bracketed%20by%20clusters%20of%20short%20chapters%20narrated%20by%20the%20eldest%2C%20Grace%2C%20or%20by%20all%20three%20sisters%20collectively%2C%20but%20Lia%20relates%20most%20of%20what%20happens%20after%20a%20pivotal%20event%3A%20King%20fails%20to%20return%20from%20a%20supply%20run.%20Lia%20is%20the%20one%20who%20accepts%20Mother%E2%80%99s%20explanation%20for%20why%20her%20older%20sister%20is%20going%20to%20have%20a%20baby%20(%E2%80%9CGrace%20asked%20the%20sea%20for%20one%E2%80%9D)%2C%20and%20who%2C%20some%20indistinct%20period%20of%20time%20after%20King%E2%80%99s%20disappearance%2C%20describes%20how%20two%20strange%20men%20and%20a%20boy%20wash%20up%20on%20the%20beach%20after%20a%20storm.%20Lia%E2%80%99s%20age%20isn%E2%80%99t%20clear.%20She%20herself%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20seem%20to%20know%20it.%20Grace%20has%20few%20memories%20of%20the%20outside%20world%20and%20Lia%2C%20like%20her%20younger%20sister%2C%20Sky%2C%20has%20none.%20Most%20of%20what%20Lia%20knows%20comes%20from%20her%20parents.%20But%20the%20unreliability%20of%20King%20and%20Mother%20soon%20becomes%20unignorable%3B%20we%20learn%20from%20Grace%20that%20every%20year%20the%20family%20holds%20a%20lottery%20in%20which%20a%20member%20draws%20an%20iron%20marker%20assigning%20another%20member%20to%20be%20his%20or%20her%20%E2%80%9Cloved-most%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94and%2C%20since%20there%20are%20five%20of%20them%2C%20one%20person%20always%20gets%20left%20out.%20Among%20the%20cruellest%20tests%20the%20parents%20impose%20is%20to%20make%20one%20of%20the%20two%20elder%20sisters%20kill%20some%20small%20animal%20in%20order%20to%20spare%20the%20youngest%20from%20being%20forced%20to%20do%20it.%20It%E2%80%99s%20an%20exercise%20meant%20to%20harden%20their%20hearts%20to%20everything%20but%20each%20other.%20Throughout%20most%20of%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Water%20Cure%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20reader%20can%E2%80%99t%20tell%20whether%20the%20daughters%20really%20are%20refugees%20from%20a%20poisoned%20apocalyptic%20future%20or%20just%20the%20unwitting%20captives%20of%20a%20tiny%20crackpot%20separatist%20cult.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ELia%20is%20a%20narrator%20familiar%20from%20many%20coming-of-age%20novels%3A%20needy%2C%20solipsistic%2C%20obsessed%20with%20her%20own%20body%20and%20feelings%2C%20absorbed%20in%20a%20morbid%20form%20of%20femininity%20that%20prompts%20her%20to%20cut%20and%20burn%20herself.%20In%20another%20era%2C%20she%20would%20have%20been%20called%20a%20hysteric%20and%20sent%20away%20to%20a%20more%20overtly%20patriarchal%20version%20of%20the%20sanatorium%20her%20parents%20once%20operated.%20Some%20readers%20can%E2%80%99t%20get%20enough%20of%20characters%20like%20this%2C%20but%20I%20confess%20that%20Lia%20often%20exasperated%20me%20and%20even%20made%20me%20contemplate%20abandoning%20the%20novel%20once%20or%20twice.%20That%20would%20have%20been%20a%20lamentable%20mistake%2C%20for%20Mackintosh%20is%20up%20to%20something%20far%20more%20interesting%20than%20a%20celebration%20of%20female%20dysfunction.%20Still%2C%20I%20sometimes%20longed%20for%20the%20narrative%20reins%20to%20be%20returned%20to%20the%20more%20hardheaded%20and%20clear-eyed%20Grace.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHaving%20drawn%20the%20short%20straw%20in%20the%20family%E2%80%99s%20most%20recent%20lottery%2C%20Lia%20is%20nobody%E2%80%99s%20loved-most.%20She%20craves%20tenderness%20so%20desperately%20that%20it%20drives%20her%20and%20everyone%20around%20her%20half%20mad.%20%E2%80%9COften%20Grace%20is%20repelled%20by%20me%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20explains.%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20have%20the%20luxury%20of%20being%20repelled%20by%20her%2C%20even%20when%20her%20breath%20is%20sour%20and%20a%20gentle%20scum%20of%20dirt%20clings%20to%20her%20ankles.%20I%20take%20whatever%20contact%20I%20can%20get.%20Sometimes%20I%20harvest%20the%20hair%20from%20her%20brush%20and%20hide%20it%20under%20my%20pillow%2C%20when%20things%20get%20very%20bad.%E2%80%9D%20She%20can%20think%20of%20nothing%20else%2C%20even%20as%20she%E2%80%99s%20acutely%20aware%20of%20how%20dangerous%20her%20loneliness%20is.%20As%20her%20parents%20frame%20it%2C%20the%20sickness%20men%20cause%20in%20women%20takes%20the%20form%20of%20women%E2%80%99s%20emotions.%20%E2%80%9CPart%20of%20what%20made%20the%20old%20world%20so%20terrible%2C%E2%80%9D%20Lia%20explains%2C%20%E2%80%9Cso%20prone%20to%20destruction%2C%20was%20a%20total%20lack%20of%20preparation%20for%20the%20personal%20energies%20often%20called%20feelings.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20Especially%20dangerous%20for%20women%2C%20our%20bodies%20already%20so%20vulnerable%20in%20ways%20that%20the%20bodies%20of%20men%20are%20not.%E2%80%9D%20The%20%E2%80%9Ccures%E2%80%9D%20King%20and%20Mother%20administer%20are%20meant%20to%20purge%20their%20daughters%20of%20all%20but%20a%20narrow%20range%20of%20feeling%2C%20making%20their%20sanctuary%20uncomfortably%20similar%20to%20nineteenth-%20and%20twentieth-century%20institutions%20designed%20to%20render%20wayward%20girls%20and%20women%20mild%20and%20docile%20helpmeets.%20When%20Grace%E2%80%99s%20baby%20is%20born%20dead%2C%20Mother%20allows%20the%20girls%20to%20cry%20for%20only%20five%20minutes%2C%20covered%20in%20heavy%20sheets%2C%20%E2%80%9Cfor%20your%20grief.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Like all dystopian narratives, the feminist variety uses stories about how bad the world might become to point out how bad it already is. Not surprisingly, feminist dystopian narratives are now enjoying a boom, from Hulu’s television adaptation of Margaret Atwood’s 1985 novel, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Handmaids-Tale-Margaret-Atwood-ebook/dp/B003JFJHTS/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416861&sr=1-1&keywords=The+Handmaid%E2%80%99s+Tale"},"The Handmaid’s Tale"],"”—Atwood recently announced that she is writing a sequel—to several books by both new and established novelists, including Louise Erdrich’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Future-Home-Living-God-Novel/dp/0062694057/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416872&sr=1-1&keywords=Future+Home+of+the+Living+God"},"Future Home of the Living God"],",” Christina Dalcher’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Vox-Christina-Dalcher/dp/0440000785/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416884&sr=1-1&keywords=Vox%2C"},"Vox,"],"” and Leni Zumas’s “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Red-Clocks-Novel-Leni-Zumas/dp/0316434787/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416897&sr=1-1&keywords=Red+Clocks"},"Red Clocks"],".” These writers depict a range of inventively punitive societies: in one, women are punished for speaking more than a hundred words per day; in another, the government takes pregnant women into custody to manage a fertility crisis. The novels extrapolate from a very real prospect of curtailed rights, especially reproductive rights, to imagine what it would be like to live in a society of forced marriages and pregnancies. The typical dystopian novel is at least as much about the world it’s set in as it is about the characters who inhabit it."],["p","Sophie Mackintosh’s clever and arresting début novel, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Water-Cure-Novel-Sophie-Mackintosh/dp/0385543875/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416910&sr=1-1&keywords=The+Water+Cure"},"The Water Cure"],"” (Doubleday), although sometimes grouped with the new crop of feminist dystopias, doesn’t much resemble them in this respect. It constructs not a world but a bubble within a world—in other words, a family. Three young sisters live with their parents in a decommissioned seaside sanatorium that was once a grand hotel. They have no contact with the outside; their father, King, leaves in a motorboat every few months to bring back supplies from a mainland they believe to be dangerously contaminated. Men are the primary source of the toxins, and the two elder sisters can remember when their parents provided a sanctuary for “damaged women,” refugees who had been harmed by the male world. The therapies employed were harsh and primitive: patients were ordered to drink salt water until they vomited, and the titular “water cure” entailed a near-drowning. After the patients stop coming, King and his wife, Mother, administer the same cures to their daughters, observing elaborate purification measures whenever the girls come into contact with dead animals or a particularly noxious artifact from the greater world, such as a magazine. Other regular treatments include being shrouded or gagged with lots of muslin; the characters in “The Water Cure” always seem to be running off to collect a bolt of the stuff."],["p","The middle sister, Lia, narrates the novel’s long central section. It comes bracketed by clusters of short chapters narrated by the eldest, Grace, or by all three sisters collectively, but Lia relates most of what happens after a pivotal event: King fails to return from a supply run. Lia is the one who accepts Mother’s explanation for why her older sister is going to have a baby (“Grace asked the sea for one”), and who, some indistinct period of time after King’s disappearance, describes how two strange men and a boy wash up on the beach after a storm. Lia’s age isn’t clear. She herself doesn’t seem to know it. Grace has few memories of the outside world and Lia, like her younger sister, Sky, has none. Most of what Lia knows comes from her parents. But the unreliability of King and Mother soon becomes unignorable; we learn from Grace that every year the family holds a lottery in which a member draws an iron marker assigning another member to be his or her “loved-most”—and, since there are five of them, one person always gets left out. Among the cruellest tests the parents impose is to make one of the two elder sisters kill some small animal in order to spare the youngest from being forced to do it. It’s an exercise meant to harden their hearts to everything but each other. Throughout most of “The Water Cure,” the reader can’t tell whether the daughters really are refugees from a poisoned apocalyptic future or just the unwitting captives of a tiny crackpot separatist cult."],["p","Lia is a narrator familiar from many coming-of-age novels: needy, solipsistic, obsessed with her own body and feelings, absorbed in a morbid form of femininity that prompts her to cut and burn herself. In another era, she would have been called a hysteric and sent away to a more overtly patriarchal version of the sanatorium her parents once operated. Some readers can’t get enough of characters like this, but I confess that Lia often exasperated me and even made me contemplate abandoning the novel once or twice. That would have been a lamentable mistake, for Mackintosh is up to something far more interesting than a celebration of female dysfunction. Still, I sometimes longed for the narrative reins to be returned to the more hardheaded and clear-eyed Grace."],["p","Having drawn the short straw in the family’s most recent lottery, Lia is nobody’s loved-most. She craves tenderness so desperately that it drives her and everyone around her half mad. “Often Grace is repelled by me,” she explains. “I don’t have the luxury of being repelled by her, even when her breath is sour and a gentle scum of dirt clings to her ankles. I take whatever contact I can get. Sometimes I harvest the hair from her brush and hide it under my pillow, when things get very bad.” She can think of nothing else, even as she’s acutely aware of how dangerous her loneliness is. As her parents frame it, the sickness men cause in women takes the form of women’s emotions. “Part of what made the old world so terrible,” Lia explains, “so prone to destruction, was a total lack of preparation for the personal energies often called feelings. . . . Especially dangerous for women, our bodies already so vulnerable in ways that the bodies of men are not.” The “cures” King and Mother administer are meant to purge their daughters of all but a narrow range of feeling, making their sanctuary uncomfortably similar to nineteenth- and twentieth-century institutions designed to render wayward girls and women mild and docile helpmeets. When Grace’s baby is born dead, Mother allows the girls to cry for only five minutes, covered in heavy sheets, “for your grief.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20humid%20claustrophobia%20of%20Lia%E2%80%99s%20perspective%20shuts%20out%20any%20possibility%20of%20conventional%20political%20commentary%20about%2C%20for%20example%2C%20the%20perils%20of%20theocratic%20governments%20or%20the%20failure%20of%20previous%20generations%20to%20forestall%20an%20ecological%20disaster.%20This%20insularity%20gives%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Water%20Cure%E2%80%9D%20the%20cloistered%2C%20ahistorical%20atmosphere%20of%20a%20fairy%20tale%2C%20where%20elemental%20dramas%20play%20out%20much%20as%20they%20have%20since%20humanity%20first%20began%20telling%20stories.%20Salt%2C%20one%20of%20the%20family%E2%80%99s%20go-to%20remedies%2C%20was%20traditionally%20reputed%20to%20keep%20away%20malicious%20fairies%2C%20and%20the%20overgrown%20grounds%20Lia%20wanders%20through%2C%20with%20their%20perimeter%20of%20rusty%20barbed%20wire%20and%20shark-infested%20waters%2C%20resemble%20Sleeping%20Beauty%E2%80%99s%20castle.%20The%20Shakespearean%20allusions%E2%80%94Lear-like%20King%20with%20his%20three%20daughters%3B%20shipwrecked%20sailors%20delivered%2C%20%E2%80%9C%3Ca%20href%3D%5C%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2FTempest-Folger-Shakespeare-Library%2Fdp%2F0743482832%2Fref%3Dsr_1_1%3Fs%3Dbooks%26amp%3Bie%3DUTF8%26amp%3Bqid%3D1545416944%26amp%3Bsr%3D1-1%26amp%3Bkeywords%3DTempest%2Bshakespeare%5C%22%3ETempest%3C%2Fa%3E%E2%80%9D%20style%2C%20into%20a%20tiny%20fiefdom%E2%80%94and%20the%20absence%20of%20any%20modern%20technology%20contribute%20to%20the%20novel%E2%80%99s%20timeless%20languor.%20It%20could%20as%20easily%20be%20set%20fifty%20years%20ago%20as%20fifty%20years%20from%20now.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAt%20first%2C%20King%E2%80%99s%20women%20regard%20the%20castaways%20with%20alarm.%20Surely%20they%20must%20be%20carriers%20of%20contagion.%20A%20moldering%20volume%20called%20the%20Welcome%20Book%2C%20left%20over%20from%20the%20sanatorium%20days%2C%20serves%20to%20remind%20them%20of%20the%20threat%3B%20snippets%20of%20the%20volume%20are%20scattered%20through%20the%20novel.%20(%E2%80%9CEverybody%20knew%20and%20nobody%20helped.%20It%20was%20the%20secret%20that%20we%20were%20all%20choking%20on.%E2%80%9D)%20Yet%20the%20newcomers%20have%20an%20unself-conscious%20ease%20that%20fascinates%20Lia.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CThere%20is%20a%20fluidity%20to%20his%20movements%2C%20despite%20his%20size%2C%20that%20tells%20me%20he%20has%20never%20had%20to%20justify%20his%20existence%2C%20has%20never%20had%20to%20fold%20himself%20into%20a%20hidden%20thing%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20observes%20of%20one%20of%20the%20elder%20pair%2C%20Llew%2C%20%E2%80%9Cand%20I%20wonder%20what%20that%20must%20be%20like%2C%20to%20know%20that%20your%20body%20is%20irreproachable.%E2%80%9D%20He%20sizes%20her%20up%20as%20the%20likeliest%20candidate%20for%20seduction%2C%20and%2C%20of%20course%2C%20she%20succumbs%3A%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cblockquote%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EI%20know%20that%20without%20being%20touched%20I%20will%20die.%20I%20have%20known%20it%20for%20some%20time.%20It%20has%20always%20felt%20like%20I%20need%20more%20touch%20than%20the%20others%20anyway%2C%20my%20hands%20brushing%20over%20their%20shoulders%20or%20the%20tops%20of%20their%20heads%20as%20they%20shy%20away%2C%20because%20nobody%20is%20assigned%20to%20me.%20I%20am%20not%20anybody%E2%80%99s%20loved-most%2C%20have%20not%20been%20for%20some%20time.%20I%20have%20gone%20days%2C%20weeks%2C%20without%20touch%20and%20when%20that%20happens%20I%20can%20feel%20my%20skin%20thinning%2C%20I%20have%20to%20lay%20my%20body%20against%20grass%20and%20velvet%20and%20the%20corner%20of%20the%20sofa%20and%20rub%20my%20hands%20and%20elbows%20and%20thighs%20against%20anything%20until%20they%20are%20raw.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3C%2Fblockquote%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOne%20day%2C%20Mother%2C%20too%2C%20vanishes%2C%20and%20the%20old%20order%20and%20its%20barriers%20crumble%20further.%20The%20lovers%20sneak%20off%20into%20the%20woods%20for%20a%20tryst%2C%20Lia%20revelling%20in%20the%20vulnerability%20she%E2%80%99s%20been%20raised%20to%20conquer%3B%20she%20finds%20herself%20%E2%80%9Con%20my%20hands%20and%20knees%20and%20I%20know%20that%20bruises%20will%20come%20up%20almost%20immediately%2C%20that%20I%20am%20thin-skinned%20and%20woundable%2C%20and%20somewhere%20within%20me%20I%20like%20this%2C%20the%20proof%2C%20the%20map%20of%20this%20new%20joy.%E2%80%9D%20But%2C%20just%20as%20she%20is%20no%20Miranda%2C%20Llew%20is%20no%20Ferdinand%20and%20theirs%20is%20no%20brave%20new%20world.%20When%20he%20begins%20to%20pull%20away%2C%20the%20dreamy%2C%20primal%20language%20of%20the%20novel%20splits%20open%20on%20the%20prosaic%2C%20familiar%20edge%20of%20his%20evasions.%20He%20says%20things%20like%20%E2%80%9CI%20hate%20it%20when%20women%20cry.%20It%E2%80%99s%20manipulative%E2%80%9D%20and%20%E2%80%9CYou%E2%80%99re%20taking%20precautions%2C%20aren%E2%80%99t%20you%3F%E2%80%9D%20(She%20has%20no%20idea%20what%20this%20means%2C%20and%20he%E2%80%99s%20asking%20way%20too%20late.)%20Worst%20of%20all%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20thought%20you%20might%20not%20be%20like%20the%20rest%20of%20them.%E2%80%9D%20As%20Grace%20will%20later%20put%20it%2C%20%E2%80%9CRefrain%20of%20the%20man%2C%20universal%3A%20This%20is%20not%20my%20fault!%20See%20also%3A%20I%20absolve%20myself%20of%20responsibility.%20And%3A%20I%20never%20said%20that.%20You%20can%E2%80%99t%20take%20the%20actions%20of%20my%20body%20as%20words.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAfter%20the%20predictable%20ruination%20of%20Lia%E2%80%99s%20hopes%20comes%20an%20unexpected%20and%20thrilling%20turn.%20Wised-up%20Grace%20takes%20over%20the%20narration.%20She%20addresses%20her%20account%20directly%20to%20King%2C%20the%20architect%20of%20their%20lives%20and%20the%20father%20of%20her%20dead%20child.%20%E2%80%9CThere%20has%20never%20been%20anyone%20like%20you%20in%20the%20world%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20recalls%20him%20saying%20once%2C%20exulting%20in%20his%20own%20achievement%20in%20raising%20her%20and%20her%20sisters.%20%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20I%20wouldn%E2%80%99t%20know%20about%20that%2C%20would%20I%3F%E2%80%9D%20she%20replies.%20Unlike%20Lia%2C%20Grace%20is%20well%20equipped%20to%20discover%20the%20true%20nature%20of%20her%20family%E2%80%99s%20circumstances.%20But%20of%20all%20the%20revelations%20that%20follow%2C%20as%20the%20sisters%20prepare%20to%20dismantle%20the%20only%20life%20they%E2%80%99ve%20known%2C%20the%20most%20darkly%20gratifying%20concerns%20the%20terrible%20strength%20that%20lies%20at%20the%20heart%20of%20Lia%E2%80%99s%20weakness.%20Ingenious%20and%20incendiary%2C%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Water%20Cure%E2%80%9D%20is%20less%20a%20warning%20about%20the%20way%20we%20live%20now%2C%20the%20hazardous%20path%20society%20is%20careering%20down%2C%20than%20it%20is%20about%20the%20way%20we%20have%20always%20lived%2C%20parents%20and%20children%2C%20fathers%20and%20daughters%2C%20men%20and%20women.%20As%20the%20sisters%20put%20it%2C%20when%20they%20are%20again%20able%20to%20speak%20as%20one%2C%20%E2%80%9CThe%20safe%20place%20had%20been%20contaminated%20from%20the%20start.%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The humid claustrophobia of Lia’s perspective shuts out any possibility of conventional political commentary about, for example, the perils of theocratic governments or the failure of previous generations to forestall an ecological disaster. This insularity gives “The Water Cure” the cloistered, ahistorical atmosphere of a fairy tale, where elemental dramas play out much as they have since humanity first began telling stories. Salt, one of the family’s go-to remedies, was traditionally reputed to keep away malicious fairies, and the overgrown grounds Lia wanders through, with their perimeter of rusty barbed wire and shark-infested waters, resemble Sleeping Beauty’s castle. The Shakespearean allusions—Lear-like King with his three daughters; shipwrecked sailors delivered, “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Tempest-Folger-Shakespeare-Library/dp/0743482832/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1545416944&sr=1-1&keywords=Tempest+shakespeare"},"Tempest"],"” style, into a tiny fiefdom—and the absence of any modern technology contribute to the novel’s timeless languor. It could as easily be set fifty years ago as fifty years from now."],["p","At first, King’s women regard the castaways with alarm. Surely they must be carriers of contagion. A moldering volume called the Welcome Book, left over from the sanatorium days, serves to remind them of the threat; snippets of the volume are scattered through the novel. (“Everybody knew and nobody helped. It was the secret that we were all choking on.”) Yet the newcomers have an unself-conscious ease that fascinates Lia."],["p","“There is a fluidity to his movements, despite his size, that tells me he has never had to justify his existence, has never had to fold himself into a hidden thing,” she observes of one of the elder pair, Llew, “and I wonder what that must be like, to know that your body is irreproachable.” He sizes her up as the likeliest candidate for seduction, and, of course, she succumbs:"],["blockquote",["p","I know that without being touched I will die. I have known it for some time. It has always felt like I need more touch than the others anyway, my hands brushing over their shoulders or the tops of their heads as they shy away, because nobody is assigned to me. I am not anybody’s loved-most, have not been for some time. I have gone days, weeks, without touch and when that happens I can feel my skin thinning, I have to lay my body against grass and velvet and the corner of the sofa and rub my hands and elbows and thighs against anything until they are raw."]],["p","One day, Mother, too, vanishes, and the old order and its barriers crumble further. The lovers sneak off into the woods for a tryst, Lia revelling in the vulnerability she’s been raised to conquer; she finds herself “on my hands and knees and I know that bruises will come up almost immediately, that I am thin-skinned and woundable, and somewhere within me I like this, the proof, the map of this new joy.” But, just as she is no Miranda, Llew is no Ferdinand and theirs is no brave new world. When he begins to pull away, the dreamy, primal language of the novel splits open on the prosaic, familiar edge of his evasions. He says things like “I hate it when women cry. It’s manipulative” and “You’re taking precautions, aren’t you?” (She has no idea what this means, and he’s asking way too late.) Worst of all, “I thought you might not be like the rest of them.” As Grace will later put it, “Refrain of the man, universal: This is not my fault! See also: I absolve myself of responsibility. And: I never said that. You can’t take the actions of my body as words.”"],["p","After the predictable ruination of Lia’s hopes comes an unexpected and thrilling turn. Wised-up Grace takes over the narration. She addresses her account directly to King, the architect of their lives and the father of her dead child. “There has never been anyone like you in the world,” she recalls him saying once, exulting in his own achievement in raising her and her sisters. “Well, I wouldn’t know about that, would I?” she replies. Unlike Lia, Grace is well equipped to discover the true nature of her family’s circumstances. But of all the revelations that follow, as the sisters prepare to dismantle the only life they’ve known, the most darkly gratifying concerns the terrible strength that lies at the heart of Lia’s weakness. Ingenious and incendiary, “The Water Cure” is less a warning about the way we live now, the hazardous path society is careering down, than it is about the way we have always lived, parents and children, fathers and daughters, men and women. As the sisters put it, when they are again able to speak as one, “The safe place had been contaminated from the start.” ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59babd482af19b1403458545","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Books","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"books"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Books","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"books"},{"id":"5907ef77019dfc3494e9c911","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Books","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"books-tag"}]},"channel":"Magazine","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[],"contentType":"article","contributors":[{"name":"Laura %20(and%20thus%20fewer)%20trains%2C%20with%20only%20some%20cars%20(color-coded)%20opening%20at%20certain%20stations.%20It%20bears%20mentioning%20that%20Avedisian%E2%80%99s%20idea%20became%20a%20punching%20bag%20for%20many%20in%20the%20online%20mass-transit-nerd%20community.%20Also%2C%20that%20the%20check%2C%20for%20three%20hundred%20and%20thirty-three%20thousand%20dollars%2C%20cleared.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBack%20home%2C%20the%20mice%E2%80%94probably%20expats%20from%20a%20building%20renovation%20next%20door%E2%80%94became%20more%20brazen.%20Corroborating%20e-mails%20circulated%3A%20%E2%80%9CFirst%20of%20all%2C%20I%20find%20having%20to%20have%20this%20discussion%20repulsive.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20I%20have%20terminated%206%20mice%20this%20week.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20I%E2%80%99m%20really%20grossed%20out%2C%20fed%20up.%E2%80%9D%20A%20neighbor%20suggested%20investing%20in%20extra-long%20cats.%20Instead%2C%20Avedisian%20and%20van%20de%20Walle%20placed%20glue%20traps%20and%20spring%20traps%20all%20over%20the%20kitchen.%20The%20spring%20traps%20occasionally%20sprang.%20The%20building%20super%20patched%20openings%20behind%20the%20range%2C%20the%20dishwasher%2C%20and%20the%20cabinets%20with%20plaster%20and%20fine%20wire%20mesh.%20The%20problem%20persisted%E2%80%94June%2C%20July%2C%20August%2C%20September.%20An%20exterminating%20company%2C%20M.%C2%A0%26amp%3B%C2%A0M.%20Pest%20Control%2C%20sealed%20overlooked%20fissures%20in%20cabinet%20joints%20and%20along%20baseboards.%20By%20fall%2C%20Avedisian%20and%20Timothy%20Wong%2C%20of%20M.%20%26amp%3B%20M.%2C%20believed%20that%20landmark%20progress%20had%20been%20achieved%E2%80%94that%20from%20a%20mice%20situation%20they%20were%20down%20to%20a%20mouse%20situation.%20A%20single%20intruder%2C%20all%20avenues%20of%20egress%20sealed%2C%20was%20now%20trapped%20in%20the%20apartment%2C%20an%20accidental%20pet.%20Avedisian%20named%20him%20Horace%2C%20an%20homage%20to%20the%20building%E2%80%99s%20architect%2C%20Horace%20Ginsbern.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETo%20test%20the%20hypothesis%2C%20M.%20%26amp%3B%20M.%20built%20a%20two-foot-high%20cardboard%20divider%20that%20walled%20off%20the%20kitchen%20doorway%2C%20and%20Avedisian%20bought%20an%20infrared%20night-vision%20security%20camera%20that%20could%20be%20monitored%20from%20a%20smartphone.%20The%20night%20that%20he%20installed%20it%20in%20the%20kitchen%2C%20he%20and%20van%20de%20Walle%20sat%20up%20in%20bed%2C%20constantly%20checking%20Avedisian%E2%80%99s%20phone.%20Around%201%3A30%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EA.M.%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20Avedisian%20spotted%20Horace%20and%20knew%20that%20he%20was%20under-equipped.%20An%20intrepid%20interpreter%20of%20instruction%20manuals%2C%20he%20figured%20out%20how%20to%20make%20a%20cloud-based%20service%20send%20alerts%20to%20his%20phone%20whenever%20the%20camera%20captured%20a%20rodent%20in%20motion.%20Reviewing%20the%20footage%2C%20he%20identified%20the%20kitchen%20range%20as%20one%20of%20the%20off-camera%20portals%20of%20Horace%E2%80%99s%20entrances%20and%20exits.%20He%20arranged%20%E2%80%9Ca%20Maginot%20Line%20of%20glue%20traps%E2%80%9D%20and%20set%20out%20a%20pizza%20box%20with%20a%20mouse-size%20hole%20and%2C%20inside%2C%20pieces%20of%20mozzarella%20and%20pepperoni%20surrounded%20by%20glue%20traps.%20This%20yielded%20maddening%20footage%20of%20Horace%20entering%20the%20pizza%20box%20and%2C%20moments%20later%2C%20sauntering%20out.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20were%20pissed%2C%E2%80%9D%20Avedisian%20said%20recently.%20%E2%80%9CWe%E2%80%99d%20left%20a%20feast%20for%20him.%20He%20somehow%20avoided%20the%20glue.%20He%E2%80%99s%20walking%20around%20like%20he%20owns%20the%20place.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20October%2C%20Avedisian%20e-mailed%20Wong%2C%20embedding%20links%20to%20several%20videos%3A%20%E2%80%9CWe%20have%20had%20at%20least%20one%20mouse%20%5Bsighting%5D%20each%20night%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20Friday%20(35%20seconds%20in)%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20Saturday%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%203%3A41%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EA.M.%3C%2Fem%3E%20(1%20min%2023%20seconds%20in%2C%20from%20wall%20on%20right%20darting%20under%20range)%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%203%3A53%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EA.M.%3C%2Fem%3E%20(50%20seconds%20in%2C%20from%20bottom%20of%20screen)%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%204%3A09%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EA.M.%3C%2Fem%3E%20(25%20seconds%20in%2C%20in%20the%20middle%20of%20the%20screen%2C%20roams%2C%20approaches%20glue%20traps).%E2%80%9D%20M.%20%26amp%3B%20M.%20returned%20and%20deepened%20the%20Maginot%20Line%2C%20and%20two%20days%20later%20Avedisian%20wrote%20to%20the%20co-op%20board%3A%20%E2%80%9CWe%20finally%20caught%20%5BHorace%5D%20last%20night.%20A%20huge%20array%20of%20glue%20traps%20around%20the%20kitchen%20is%20what%20finally%20did%20the%20trick.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20Here%20is%20a%20link%20to%20the%20capture%20last%20night%20at%20about%2011%3A40%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EP.M.%3C%2Fem%3E%E2%80%9D%20%5BEditor%E2%80%99s%20note%3A%20%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3EPETA%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20if%20you%E2%80%99re%20reading%2C%20Horace%20has%20gone%20upstate%20to%20live%20on%20a%20farm%20with%20a%20nice%20family.%5D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20cardboard%20wall%20came%20down%2C%20and%20Avedisian%20is%20busy%20trying%20to%20collect%20on%20a%20large%20judgment%20he%20won%20in%20late%202017.%20If%20not%2C%20he%20has%20a%20fallback.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20holy%20grail%20of%20the%20M.T.A.%20is%20a%20single-seat%20ride%20to%20J.F.K.%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CYou%20get%20on%20the%20subway%20in%2C%20say%2C%20Manhattan%20and%20get%20off%20at%20your%20terminal%20at%20J.F.K.%20without%20changing%20trains.%20Nobody%E2%80%99s%20been%20able%20to%20figure%20out%20how%20to%20do%20it.%20I%20believe%20I%20have.%20Two%20different%20ways.%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Craig Avedisian, a litigator and situational genius, lives on an Upper East Side residential block with its share of wildlife. At some point, virtually every New York City building not recently constructed and exactingly sealed has—within the walls, or burrowing in the basement—mice. The co-op apartment that Avedisian occupies with his wife, Carla van de Walle, and their two children, in a six-story prewar building, is meticulously tidy. Still, mice. Last March, Avedisian sent the first in a series of e-mails to fellow-members of the co-op’s board, itemizing sightings (or droppings)—under the refrigerator, inside cupboards, in a knife drawer, sleeping it off in a garbage can, running free in daylight, drunk on the fragrance of sizzling bacon."],["p","The month had begun on a more propitious note, when Avedisian was announced as a winner of the Metropolitan Transit Authority’s “genius challenge,” a competition that solicited ideas for ways to render subway service less insane-making. The M.T.A. offered a million dollars in prize money in each of three categories, and Avedisian emerged from four hundred and thirty-eight entrants. The only winner with no ties to the transit industry, he proposed easing congestion and delays by deploying longer (and thus fewer) trains, with only some cars (color-coded) opening at certain stations. It bears mentioning that Avedisian’s idea became a punching bag for many in the online mass-transit-nerd community. Also, that the check, for three hundred and thirty-three thousand dollars, cleared."],["p","Back home, the mice—probably expats from a building renovation next door—became more brazen. Corroborating e-mails circulated: “First of all, I find having to have this discussion repulsive. . . . I have terminated 6 mice this week. . . . I’m really grossed out, fed up.” A neighbor suggested investing in extra-long cats. Instead, Avedisian and van de Walle placed glue traps and spring traps all over the kitchen. The spring traps occasionally sprang. The building super patched openings behind the range, the dishwasher, and the cabinets with plaster and fine wire mesh. The problem persisted—June, July, August, September. An exterminating company, M. & M. Pest Control, sealed overlooked fissures in cabinet joints and along baseboards. By fall, Avedisian and Timothy Wong, of M. & M., believed that landmark progress had been achieved—that from a mice situation they were down to a mouse situation. A single intruder, all avenues of egress sealed, was now trapped in the apartment, an accidental pet. Avedisian named him Horace, an homage to the building’s architect, Horace Ginsbern."],["p","To test the hypothesis, M. & M. built a two-foot-high cardboard divider that walled off the kitchen doorway, and Avedisian bought an infrared night-vision security camera that could be monitored from a smartphone. The night that he installed it in the kitchen, he and van de Walle sat up in bed, constantly checking Avedisian’s phone. Around 1:30 ",["em",{"class":"small"},"A.M."],", Avedisian spotted Horace and knew that he was under-equipped. An intrepid interpreter of instruction manuals, he figured out how to make a cloud-based service send alerts to his phone whenever the camera captured a rodent in motion. Reviewing the footage, he identified the kitchen range as one of the off-camera portals of Horace’s entrances and exits. He arranged “a Maginot Line of glue traps” and set out a pizza box with a mouse-size hole and, inside, pieces of mozzarella and pepperoni surrounded by glue traps. This yielded maddening footage of Horace entering the pizza box and, moments later, sauntering out. “We were pissed,” Avedisian said recently. “We’d left a feast for him. He somehow avoided the glue. He’s walking around like he owns the place.”"],["p","In October, Avedisian e-mailed Wong, embedding links to several videos: “We have had at least one mouse [sighting] each night . . . Friday (35 seconds in) . . . Saturday . . . 3:41 ",["em",{"class":"small"},"A.M."]," (1 min 23 seconds in, from wall on right darting under range) . . . 3:53 ",["em",{"class":"small"},"A.M."]," (50 seconds in, from bottom of screen) . . . 4:09 ",["em",{"class":"small"},"A.M."]," (25 seconds in, in the middle of the screen, roams, approaches glue traps).” M. & M. returned and deepened the Maginot Line, and two days later Avedisian wrote to the co-op board: “We finally caught [Horace] last night. A huge array of glue traps around the kitchen is what finally did the trick. . . . Here is a link to the capture last night at about 11:40 ",["em",{"class":"small"},"P.M."],"” [Editor’s note: ",["em",{"class":"small"},"PETA"],", if you’re reading, Horace has gone upstate to live on a farm with a nice family.]"],["p","The cardboard wall came down, and Avedisian is busy trying to collect on a large judgment he won in late 2017. If not, he has a fallback. “The holy grail of the M.T.A. is a single-seat ride to J.F.K.,” he said. “You get on the subway in, say, Manhattan and get off at your terminal at J.F.K. without changing trains. Nobody’s been able to figure out how to do it. I believe I have. Two different ways.” ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c7e81ab3335f580f176","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Mice","parent":[],"photos":{},"slug":"mice"},{"id":"5c2e1c7e2bfcc72cd92d0530","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Mousetraps","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"mousetraps"},{"id":"5c2e1c7e2bfcc72cd92d052f","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Craig Avedisian","url":"/tag/craig-avedisian"},{"name":"Subways","url":"/tag/subways"}],"contentType":"article","contributors":[{"name":"Mark Singer","type":"author","title":"Mark Singer, a longtime contributor to the magazine, is the author of several books, including “Character Studies.”","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Mark Singer has been a staff writer at ",["em","The New Yorker"]," since 1974. He has contributed hundreds of Talk of the Town stories and scores of Profiles and reporting pieces. In the fall of 2000, he revived the U.S. Journal column in the magazine, a monthly feature that was written by Calvin Trillin from 1967 to 1982."],["p","Singer’s account of the collapse of the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City appeared in ",["em","The New Yorker"]," in 1985 and was published as a book, “Funny Money,” that same year. In 1989, he published “Mr. Personality,” a collection of his reporting from ",["em","The New Yorker"],". In 1996, Singer published “Citizen K: The Deeply Weird American Journey of Brett Kimberlin,” which originated as an article in the magazine. His other books include “Somewhere in America” (2004) and “Character Studies” (2005), both collections of articles that originally appeared in ",["em","The New Yorker"],". His most recent book is %20based%20on%20such%20merciless%20competition%20was%20%E2%80%9Cfascist%20television.%E2%80%9D%20But%20everyone%20watched%20the%20show%20anyway%2C%20and%20Savija%20was%20soon%20forgotten.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20had%20never%20seen%20anything%20like%20it%2C%E2%80%9D%20Svante%20Stockselius%2C%20the%20chief%20of%20the%20network%20that%20produced%20the%20program%2C%20told%20the%20Los%20Angeles%20%3Cem%3ETimes%3C%2Fem%3E%2C%20in%202000.%20%E2%80%9CExpedition%3A%20Robinson%E2%80%9D%20offered%20a%20potent%20cocktail%20of%20repulsion%20and%20attraction.%20You%20felt%20embarrassed%20watching%20it%2C%20Stockselius%20said%2C%20but%20%E2%80%9Cyou%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20stop.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%201998%2C%20a%20thirty-eight-year-old%20former%20British%20paratrooper%20named%20Mark%20Burnett%20was%20living%20in%20Los%20Angeles%2C%20producing%20television.%20%E2%80%9CLord%20of%20the%20Flies%E2%80%9D%20was%20one%20of%20his%20favorite%20books%2C%20and%20after%20he%20heard%20about%20%E2%80%9CExpedition%3A%20Robinson%E2%80%9D%20he%20secured%20the%20rights%20to%20make%20an%20American%20version.%20Burnett%20had%20previously%20worked%20in%20sales%20and%20had%20a%20knack%20for%20branding.%20He%20renamed%20the%20show%20%E2%80%9CSurvivor.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20first%20season%20was%20set%20in%20Borneo%2C%20and%20from%20the%20moment%20it%20aired%2C%20on%20CBS%2C%20in%202000%2C%20%E2%80%9CSurvivor%E2%80%9D%20was%20a%20ratings%20juggernaut%3A%20according%20to%20the%20network%2C%20a%20hundred%20and%20twenty-five%20million%20Americans%E2%80%94more%20than%20a%20third%20of%20the%20population%E2%80%94tuned%20in%20for%20some%20portion%20of%20the%20season%20finale.%20The%20catchphrase%20delivered%20by%20the%20host%2C%20Jeff%20Probst%2C%20at%20the%20end%20of%20each%20elimination%20ceremony%2C%20%E2%80%9CThe%20tribe%20has%20spoken%2C%E2%80%9D%20entered%20the%20lexicon.%20Burnett%20had%20been%20a%20marginal%20figure%20in%20Hollywood%2C%20but%20after%20this%20triumph%20he%2C%20too%2C%20was%2
