ett.%20Soon%20afterward%2C%20Roma%20Downey%20tweeted%20a%20photograph%20of%20the%20back%20of%20her%20hand%2C%20writing%2C%20%E2%80%9CGot%20this%20bruise%20tonight%20when%20Tom%20Arnold%20tried%20to%20ambush%20my%20husband%20Mark%20and%20me%20at%20a%20charity%20event.%20Is%20your%20TV%20show%20worth%20it%20Tom%3F%20Please%20stop.%E2%80%9D%20Some%20observers%20wondered%20whether%20a%20bruise%20could%20have%20emerged%20that%20quickly.%20Arnold%20himself%20offered%20a%20very%20different%20account%20on%20Twitter%3A%20%E2%80%9CMark%20Burnett%20just%20went%20apeshit%20%26amp%3B%20choked%20me%20at%20this%20huge%20Emmy%20party%20then%20he%20ran%20away%20with%20his%20torn%20Pink%20shirt%20%26amp%3B%20missing%20gold%20chain.%20I%E2%80%99m%20waiting%20for%20LAPD.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIt%20might%20seem%20improbable%20that%20Burnett%2C%20the%20smiling%20glad-hander%2C%20would%20physically%20attack%20someone.%20But%20it%20would%20not%20be%20unprecedented.%20His%20second%20wife%2C%20Dianne%20Burnett%2C%20told%20me%20that%20one%20day%2C%20in%20Santa%20Monica%2C%20Mark%20left%20her%20and%20one%20of%20their%20sons%20in%20the%20car%20in%20order%20to%20fetch%20frozen%20yogurt.%20While%20he%20was%20gone%2C%20a%20vagrant%20began%20aggressively%20banging%20on%20the%20car%20window%2C%20presumably%20in%20search%20of%20a%20donation.%20When%20Burnett%20returned%2C%20Dianne%20recalled%2C%20he%20punched%20the%20man%20in%20the%20face%2C%20knocking%20him%20down%2C%20then%20drove%20away.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHours%20after%20the%20Century%20City%20event%2C%20TMZ%20published%20an%20account%20by%20an%20eyewitness%2C%20who%20said%20that%20%E2%80%9CMark%20had%20his%20hands%20on%20Tom%E2%80%99s%20throat%2C%20and%20Tom%20was%20tearing%20at%20Mark%E2%80%99s%20shirt%20and%20ripping%20off%20his%20crucifix.%E2%80%9D%20The%20authorities%20have%20declined%20to%20press%20charges%20against%20Burnett%2C%20and%20several%20people%20close%20to%20him%20characterized%20Arnold%20as%20a%20puerile%20stunt%20artist%20who%20cornered%20Burnett%20in%20a%20bit%20of%20performance%20art%20in%20order%20to%20promote%20his%20lousy%20show.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThat%20may%20well%20be%20true%2C%20but%20there%20is%20a%20certain%20cosmic%20poetry%20in%20the%20notion%20that%20the%20only%20person%20in%20Hollywood%20willing%20to%20antagonize%20Burnett%20about%20his%20relationship%20with%20Trump%20is%20a%20figure%20like%20Tom%20Arnold.%20Someone%20who%20has%20worked%20with%20Burnett%20told%20me%2C%20%E2%80%9CMark%20created%20the%20%3Cem%3Eworld%3C%2Fem%3E%20in%20which%20Tom%20Arnold%20is%20the%20only%20guy%20who%20can%20go%20after%20him.%20Tom%20Arnold%20is%20trolling%20Mark%20Burnett%20just%20like%20Donald%20Trump%20trolled%20all%20his%20opponents.%20And%20he%E2%80%99s%20doing%20it%20for%20a%20reality%20show!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","A recent piece in the Ankler, a widely read online newsletter about Hollywood, noted that Burnett “has spent the past couple years reigning over his corner of resistance territory with nary the slightest hint of backlash.” Donald Trump was a folk devil in Hollywood, and everyone in the industry knew about Burnett’s close association with the President, yet no prominent liberals were refusing to work with Mark Burnett. It’s one thing to “take brave stands on the red carpet,” the article observed. “But you wouldn’t want to go so crazy as to . . . get on the wrong side of a mid-sized mini-studio.”"],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1c4c5a36cecf401921326a%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1c4c5a36cecf401921326a%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1c4c5a36cecf401921326a%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1c4c5a36cecf401921326a"}]],["p","Burnett was recruited to the television arm of M-G-M in 2015, by Gary Barber, the company’s chairman and C.E.O. Barber, a former accountant, had brought the studio back from bankruptcy, slashing costs and shepherding profitable titles like the James Bond franchise. In his effort to build up M-G-M, Barber wanted to augment the studio’s television business. So he bought Burnett’s company and enlisted him to oversee television production."],["p","Ostensibly, Barber and Burnett got along. But, whereas Mark Burnett Productions had been characterized by profligate dazzle, Barber was thrifty, and monitored every expense. The chairman of M-G-M’s board is Kevin Ulrich, a financier whose private-equity fund holds a controlling stake in the company. People who know Ulrich describe him as someone who relishes the flashy perquisites of Hollywood moguldom. Whereas Barber liked to spend weekends quietly tending to the racehorses he owns, Ulrich liked going to parties and premières."],["p","Barber was interested in selling the studio—a move that Ulrich opposed. According to several sources, Burnett began cultivating Ulrich, inviting him to events and introducing him to celebrities. Then, last March, M-G-M’s board informed Barber that he had been fired; he had just signed a contract extension, so the studio would pay him two hundred and sixty million dollars to leave. Despite this payment, he was incensed. Three months after Barber’s ouster, Burnett was promoted to chairman of television at M-G-M. Barber declined to speak with me, but a friend of his said that he was “blindsided” by his ouster: Burnett had made an alliance with Ulrich and got Barber kicked off the island."],["p","As a younger man, Burnett made it known that he wasn’t content to be the producer of a few hit shows—he wanted to run a television studio one day. According to someone who has worked closely with him, Burnett had always felt like an outsider, “because in the reality-TV business, you’re never part of the true Hollywood.” He had long aspired to transition to scripted television and films but did not have much talent for such storytelling. At M-G-M, he would oversee both scripted and unscripted shows, including the acclaimed series “Fargo” and “The Handmaid’s Tale.”"],["p","He had now achieved such a level of power that, even in reflexively liberal Hollywood, his association with Trump was discussed mostly in whispers. Many people who spoke to me for this piece would not do so on the record, citing fears of being blacklisted. Nevertheless, “The Apprentice” continues to dog Burnett. In 2017, when he took the stage at the Producers Guild of America Awards to accept the award for Outstanding Producer of Competition Television, there were boos in the audience. In September, he skipped the Emmy Awards, though “The Voice” and “Shark Tank” were nominated; the night before the ceremony, however, he and Downey attended the annual gala for the Motion Picture & Television Fund, at a hotel in Century City. Walking into the event, they had a confrontation with the actor Tom Arnold."],["p","Arnold, a wild-eyed industry veteran best known for his role in the 1994 film “True Lies” and for a former marriage to Roseanne Barr, had been on a quest to uncover damaging “Apprentice” outtakes of Donald Trump. He had even launched a gonzo TV show, produced by Vice, called “The Hunt for the Trump Tapes.” As Arnold relates on the show, he and Trump knew each other for years, because they had occupied “the same level of Hollywood.” Indeed, in 2010, Burnett had e-mailed Arnold, “Is there any way I can get you to do Celeb Apprentice? . . . I do think that Celeb Apprentice has an awesome brand. Trump really wants you. I ",["em",{"class":"small"},"REALLY"]," want you.” Arnold was, in his own estimation, a prankster and a marginal celebrity. And it disturbed him to think that someone just like him might be entrusted with managing the country."],["p","What precisely happened in Century City is a matter of dispute, but there was a scuffle between Arnold and Burnett. Soon afterward, Roma Downey tweeted a photograph of the back of her hand, writing, “Got this bruise tonight when Tom Arnold tried to ambush my husband Mark and me at a charity event. Is your TV show worth it Tom? Please stop.” Some observers wondered whether a bruise could have emerged that quickly. Arnold himself offered a very different account on Twitter: “Mark Burnett just went apeshit & choked me at this huge Emmy party then he ran away with his torn Pink shirt & missing gold chain. I’m waiting for LAPD.”"],["p","It might seem improbable that Burnett, the smiling glad-hander, would physically attack someone. But it would not be unprecedented. His second wife, Dianne Burnett, told me that one day, in Santa Monica, Mark left her and one of their sons in the car in order to fetch frozen yogurt. While he was gone, a vagrant began aggressively banging on the car window, presumably in search of a donation. When Burnett returned, Dianne recalled, he punched the man in the face, knocking him down, then drove away."],["p","Hours after the Century City event, TMZ published an account by an eyewitness, who said that “Mark had his hands on Tom’s throat, and Tom was tearing at Mark’s shirt and ripping off his crucifix.” The authorities have declined to press charges against Burnett, and several people close to him characterized Arnold as a puerile stunt artist who cornered Burnett in a bit of performance art in order to promote his lousy show."],["p","That may well be true, but there is a certain cosmic poetry in the notion that the only person in Hollywood willing to antagonize Burnett about his relationship with Trump is a figure like Tom Arnold. Someone who has worked with Burnett told me, “Mark created the ",["em","world"]," in which Tom Arnold is the only guy who can go after him. Tom Arnold is trolling Mark Burnett just like Donald Trump trolled all his opponents. And he’s doing it for a reality show!”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EAfter%20Season%201%20of%20%E2%80%9CSurvivor%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20contestant%20named%20Stacey%20Stillman%20sued%20CBS%20and%20Burnett%2C%20claiming%20that%20he%20had%20improperly%20shaped%20the%20competition%20by%20whispering%20to%20contestants%20about%20whom%20they%20should%20vote%20to%20eliminate.%20In%20a%20deposition%2C%20another%20cast%20member%20said%20that%20Burnett%20%E2%80%9Cbelieved%20that%20certain%20people%20would%20make%20a%20better%20TV%20show%20than%20others%2C%20and%20he%20did%20what%20he%20could%20to%20have%20influence%20over%20those%20people%20staying%20on%20the%20island.%E2%80%9D%20Burnett%20denied%20any%20wrongdoing%2C%20and%20the%20suit%20was%20ultimately%20settled.%20One%20consequence%20of%20the%20lawsuit%20was%20that%2C%20when%20it%20came%20time%20to%20make%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Apprentice%2C%E2%80%9D%20producers%20tried%20to%20have%20cameras%20on%20Donald%20Trump%20from%20the%20moment%20he%20walked%20onto%20the%20set%20until%20the%20moment%20he%20left%E2%80%94and%20all%20that%20footage%20was%20preserved.%20When%20M-G-M%20bought%20Burnett%E2%80%99s%20company%2C%20it%20assumed%20ownership%20of%20those%20outtakes%20and%2C%20after%20the%20%E2%80%9CAccess%20Hollywood%E2%80%9D%20tape%20leaked%2C%20it%20had%20to%20contend%20with%20public%20demands%20to%20unseal%20the%20%E2%80%9CApprentice%E2%80%9D%20tapes.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMarvin%20Putnam%2C%20a%20lawyer%20who%20represents%20M-G-M%2C%20told%20me%2C%20%E2%80%9CMark%20Burnett%20cannot%20release%20the%20tapes.%20Period.%20Even%20if%20Mark%20Burnett%20%3Cem%3Ewanted%3C%2Fem%3E%20to%20release%20the%20tapes%2C%20Mark%20Burnett%20cannot%20release%20the%20tapes.%E2%80%9D%20Putnam%20explained%20that%20the%20contracts%20that%20Trump%20and%20other%20cast%20members%20signed%20contained%20standard%20industry%20stipulations%20limiting%20the%20manner%20in%20which%20outtakes%20and%20other%20footage%20could%20be%20used.%20These%20are%20binding%20obligations%2C%20which%20means%20that%20if%20M-G-M%20were%20to%20violate%20them%E2%80%94by%20releasing%20footage%20not%20just%20of%20Trump%20but%20of%20anyone%20who%20appeared%20with%20him%20onscreen%E2%80%94the%20studio%20could%20be%20sued.%20Brian%20Edwards%2C%20the%20president%20of%20television%20operations%20at%20M-G-M%2C%20who%20has%20worked%20with%20Burnett%20for%20more%20than%20a%20decade%2C%20pointed%20out%20that%2C%20even%20without%20such%20legal%20constraints%2C%20Burnett%20couldn%E2%80%99t%20release%20the%20tapes%E2%80%94if%20he%20did%2C%20talent%20would%20refuse%20to%20work%20with%20him%20in%20the%20future.%20%E2%80%9CIf%20everybody%20in%20reality%20television%20knew%20that%20their%20outtakes%20were%20going%20to%20be%20made%20public%20at%20the%20first%20sign%20of%20pressure%2C%20what%20do%20you%20think%20would%20happen%20to%20the%20business%3F%E2%80%9D%20Edwards%20asked.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ENeither%20Putnam%20nor%20Edwards%20would%20comment%20on%20whether%20M-G-M%20possesses%20tapes%20in%20which%20Trump%20says%20something%20offensive%3B%20nor%20would%20they%20say%20how%20much%2C%20if%20any%2C%20of%20the%20archive%20has%20been%20reviewed.%20Over%20the%20fourteen%20seasons%20hosted%20by%20Trump%2C%20nearly%20two%20hundred%20hours%20of%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Apprentice%E2%80%9D%20aired%20on%20NBC.%20If%20Burnett%20indeed%20shot%20three%20hundred%20hours%20of%20footage%20for%20each%20episode%2C%20there%20could%20be%20some%20sixty%20thousand%20hours%20of%20outtakes%20to%20sift%20through.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EMost%20of%20the%20former%20%E2%80%9CApprentice%E2%80%9D%20staffers%20I%20spoke%20to%20recalled%20hearing%20Trump%20speak%20coarsely%20about%20women.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20wasn%E2%80%99t%20going%20around%20saying%20%E2%80%98pussy%2C%20pussy%2C%20pussy%E2%80%99%20all%20the%20time%2C%E2%80%9D%20Walker%20said.%20But%20he%20regularly%20made%20comments%20about%20the%20bodies%20of%20female%20contestants%20and%20female%20staffers.%20One%20%E2%80%9CApprentice%E2%80%9D%20employee%20told%20me%2C%20%E2%80%9CHe%E2%80%99d%20say%2C%20%E2%80%98How%20about%20those%20boobs%3F%20Wouldn%E2%80%99t%20you%20like%20to%20fuck%20her%3F%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EEven%20so%2C%20Braun%20said%20he%20doubted%20that%20there%20was%20any%20%E2%80%9CApprentice%E2%80%9D%20tape%20in%20which%20Trump%20uses%20the%20N-word.%20%E2%80%9CI%20was%20the%20supervising%20editor%20on%20the%20first%20six%20seasons%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CI%20didn%E2%80%99t%20watch%20every%20frame%2C%20but%20in%20everything%20I%20saw%20I%20didn%E2%80%99t%20hear%20him%20saying%20anything%20so%20horrible.%E2%80%9D%20Braun%20noted%20that%20editors%20on%20reality%20shows%20often%20amuse%20themselves%20by%20compiling%20%E2%80%9Cgag%E2%80%9D%20reels%20of%20a%20cast%20member%E2%80%99s%20most%20off-color%20or%20embarrassing%20moments.%20The%20producers%20may%20be%20barred%2C%20legally%2C%20from%20airing%20such%20outtakes%2C%20but%20that%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20stop%20editors%20from%20sharing%20them%20internally.%20Tom%20Arnold%20told%20me%20that%20he%20has%20seen%20one%20such%20reel%20from%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Apprentice%2C%E2%80%9D%20in%20which%20Trump%20uses%20the%20N-word.%20But%20Braun%2C%20who%20is%20dismayed%20that%20Trump%20is%20President%2C%20is%20dubious.%20%E2%80%9CIf%20there%20%3Cem%3Ewas%3C%2Fem%3E%20a%20tape%2C%20it%20would%20have%20spread%20like%20wildfire%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20Another%20%E2%80%9CApprentice%E2%80%9D%20staffer%20made%20the%20same%20point%3A%20%E2%80%9CIf%20somebody%20had%20the%20goods%2C%20it%20would%20have%20leaked%20long%20ago.%20There%20were%20no%20Trump%20fans%20on%20the%20set.%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20know%20a%20single%20person%20who%20worked%20on%20the%20show%20who%20voted%20for%20Trump.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhenever%20Trump%20appeared%20on%20the%20show%2C%20the%20staffer%20explained%2C%20there%20were%20%E2%80%9Cat%20least%20a%20hundred%20people%20watching%20him%2C%E2%80%9D%20with%20a%20dozen%20cameras%20capturing%20every%20angle.%20Live%20feeds%20were%20transmitted%20to%20executives%20not%20just%20at%20NBC%20but%20at%20corporations%20sponsoring%20the%20episode.%20The%20staffer%20continued%2C%20%E2%80%9CIn%20the%20%E2%80%98Access%20Hollywood%E2%80%99%20tape%2C%20Donald%20was%20on%20a%20bus.%20He%20thought%20he%20was%20alone.%20He%20never%20thought%20he%20was%20alone%20in%20the%20boardroom.%20It%20was%20a%20%3Cem%3Eset%3C%2Fem%3E.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETo%20Braun%2C%20the%20hunt%20for%20the%20tapes%20feels%20like%20a%20distraction.%20%E2%80%9CWe%E2%80%99ve%20seen%20that%20it%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20matter%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20now%20says%20plenty%20of%20things%20that%20are%20%3Cem%3Eoutwardly%3C%2Fem%3E%20racist%2C%20misogynist%2C%20and%20fascist.%20It%20just%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20hurt%20him.%E2%80%9D%20After%20Manigault%20Newman%20made%20her%20claims%20about%20the%20%E2%80%9CApprentice%E2%80%9D%20tapes%2C%20%3Cem%3EThe%20Economist%3C%2Fem%3E%20conducted%20a%20survey%2C%20and%20found%20that%20seventy-seven%20per%20cent%20of%20white%20Trump%20voters%20felt%20that%20%E2%80%9Cit%20is%20possible%20that%20a%20person%20who%20uses%20the%20%E2%80%98N-word%E2%80%99%20while%20in%20office%20can%20still%20be%20a%20good%20President.%E2%80%9D%20More%20than%20a%20third%20of%20white%20Trump%20voters%20admitted%20to%20using%20the%20word%20themselves.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22callout%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522callout%2522%252C%2522name%2522%253A%2522inset-left%2522%252C%2522body%2522%253A%2522%253Cinline-embed%2520type%253D%255C%2522cartoon%255C%2522%2520meta%253D%255C%2522%25257B%252522type%252522%25253A%252522cartoon%252522%25252C%252522url%252522%25253A%252522%25252Fcartoon%25252F5c1af2937e716b4545919c7c%252522%25252C%252522width%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522height%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25252C%252522caption%252522%25253A%252522%252522%25257D%255C%2522%2520ref%253D%255C%25225c1af2937e716b4545919c7c%255C%2522%253E%253C%252Finline-embed%253E%2522%252C%2522attrs%2522%253A%257B%257D%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%22%5C%22%3E%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1af2937e716b4545919c7c%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1af2937e716b4545919c7c%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%7D","ref":""},["p","After Season 1 of “Survivor,” a contestant named Stacey Stillman sued CBS and Burnett, claiming that he had improperly shaped the competition by whispering to contestants about whom they should vote to eliminate. In a deposition, another cast member said that Burnett “believed that certain people would make a better TV show than others, and he did what he could to have influence over those people staying on the island.” Burnett denied any wrongdoing, and the suit was ultimately settled. One consequence of the lawsuit was that, when it came time to make “The Apprentice,” producers tried to have cameras on Donald Trump from the moment he walked onto the set until the moment he left—and all that footage was preserved. When M-G-M bought Burnett’s company, it assumed ownership of those outtakes and, after the “Access Hollywood” tape leaked, it had to contend with public demands to unseal the “Apprentice” tapes."],["p","Marvin Putnam, a lawyer who represents M-G-M, told me, “Mark Burnett cannot release the tapes. Period. Even if Mark Burnett ",["em","wanted"]," to release the tapes, Mark Burnett cannot release the tapes.” Putnam explained that the contracts that Trump and other cast members signed contained standard industry stipulations limiting the manner in which outtakes and other footage could be used. These are binding obligations, which means that if M-G-M were to violate them—by releasing footage not just of Trump but of anyone who appeared with him onscreen—the studio could be sued. Brian Edwards, the president of television operations at M-G-M, who has worked with Burnett for more than a decade, pointed out that, even without such legal constraints, Burnett couldn’t release the tapes—if he did, talent would refuse to work with him in the future. “If everybody in reality television knew that their outtakes were going to be made public at the first sign of pressure, what do you think would happen to the business?” Edwards asked."],["p","Neither Putnam nor Edwards would comment on whether M-G-M possesses tapes in which Trump says something offensive; nor would they say how much, if any, of the archive has been reviewed. Over the fourteen seasons hosted by Trump, nearly two hundred hours of “The Apprentice” aired on NBC. If Burnett indeed shot three hundred hours of footage for each episode, there could be some sixty thousand hours of outtakes to sift through."],["p","Most of the former “Apprentice” staffers I spoke to recalled hearing Trump speak coarsely about women. “He wasn’t going around saying ‘pussy, pussy, pussy’ all the time,” Walker said. But he regularly made comments about the bodies of female contestants and female staffers. One “Apprentice” employee told me, “He’d say, ‘How about those boobs? Wouldn’t you like to fuck her?’ ”"],["p","Even so, Braun said he doubted that there was any “Apprentice” tape in which Trump uses the N-word. “I was the supervising editor on the first six seasons,” he said. “I didn’t watch every frame, but in everything I saw I didn’t hear him saying anything so horrible.” Braun noted that editors on reality shows often amuse themselves by compiling “gag” reels of a cast member’s most off-color or embarrassing moments. The producers may be barred, legally, from airing such outtakes, but that doesn’t stop editors from sharing them internally. Tom Arnold told me that he has seen one such reel from “The Apprentice,” in which Trump uses the N-word. But Braun, who is dismayed that Trump is President, is dubious. “If there ",["em","was"]," a tape, it would have spread like wildfire,” he said. Another “Apprentice” staffer made the same point: “If somebody had the goods, it would have leaked long ago. There were no Trump fans on the set. I don’t know a single person who worked on the show who voted for Trump.”"],["p","Whenever Trump appeared on the show, the staffer explained, there were “at least a hundred people watching him,” with a dozen cameras capturing every angle. Live feeds were transmitted to executives not just at NBC but at corporations sponsoring the episode. The staffer continued, “In the ‘Access Hollywood’ tape, Donald was on a bus. He thought he was alone. He never thought he was alone in the boardroom. It was a ",["em","set"],".”"],["p","To Braun, the hunt for the tapes feels like a distraction. “We’ve seen that it doesn’t matter,” he said. “He now says plenty of things that are ",["em","outwardly"]," racist, misogynist, and fascist. It just doesn’t hurt him.” After Manigault Newman made her claims about the “Apprentice” tapes, ",["em","The Economist"]," conducted a survey, and found that seventy-seven per cent of white Trump voters felt that “it is possible that a person who uses the ‘N-word’ while in office can still be a good President.” More than a third of white Trump voters admitted to using the word themselves."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22inset-left%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22cartoon%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522cartoon%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fcartoon%252F5c1af2937e716b4545919c7c%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1af2937e716b4545919c7c%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"cartoon","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22cartoon%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fcartoon%2F5c1af2937e716b4545919c7c%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1af2937e716b4545919c7c"}]]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EOne%20day%20this%20past%20fall%2C%20Burnett%20got%20a%20call%20from%20his%20first%20wife%2C%20Kym%20Gold%2C%20with%20whom%20he%20remains%20friendly.%20Gold%20was%20upset%20about%20what%20was%20happening%20in%20the%20country%2C%20and%20asked%20Burnett%20to%20intervene%20with%20Trump.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20had%20it%20out%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CI%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98You%E2%80%99ve%20got%20to%20help%20our%20children%2C%20for%20the%20future%20and%20safety%20of%20this%20country.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20Gold%20implored%20Burnett%2C%20%E2%80%9CTell%20him%20this%20is%20not%20a%20reality%20show.%20This%20is%20real%20life.%20You%E2%80%99re%20the%20President.%20You%E2%80%99re%20saying%20things%20you%20cannot%20say%E2%80%94to%20reporters%2C%20to%20other%20world%20leaders.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBurnett%20heard%20her%20out.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20not%20into%20politics%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20told%20her.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20not%20even%20on%20Twitter.%E2%80%9D%20But%20he%20said%20that%20he%20had%20no%20intention%20of%20speaking%20out%20against%20Trump%20or%20of%20releasing%20any%20tapes.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20just%20a%20guy%20who%20produces%20shows%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20insisted.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBurnett%20may%20not%20be%20a%20policy%20maven%2C%20but%20he%20has%20long%20been%20fascinated%20with%20political%20star%20power.%20In%202010%2C%20he%20launched%20%E2%80%9CSarah%20Palin%E2%80%99s%20Alaska%2C%E2%80%9D%20on%20TLC%2C%20announcing%2C%20%E2%80%9CWith%20a%20dynamic%20personality%20that%20has%20captivated%20millions%2C%20I%20can%E2%80%99t%20think%20of%20anyone%20more%20compelling%20than%20Sarah%20Palin%20to%20tell%20the%20story%20of%20Alaska.%E2%80%9D%20At%20the%20time%2C%20Burnett%20contended%20that%20the%20show%20was%20%E2%80%9Ccompletely%20nonpolitical.%E2%80%9D%20The%20Daily%20Beast%20disagreed%2C%20suggesting%20that%20it%20%E2%80%9Cmay%20qualify%20as%20the%20earliest%2C%20most%20expensive%20Presidential%20campaign%20ad%20ever%20made.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBurnett%20and%20Trump%20have%20licensed%20the%20%E2%80%9CApprentice%E2%80%9D%20format%20to%20dozens%20of%20other%20countries%2C%20and%20Burnett%20once%20noted%20that%2C%20increasingly%2C%20tycoons%20cast%20in%20the%20Trump%20role%20are%20%E2%80%9Cpeople%20with%20political%20aspirations.%E2%80%9D%20At%20least%20half%20a%20dozen%20hosts%20have%20held%20political%20office%2C%20including%20Jo%C3%A3o%20Doria%2C%20the%20governor-elect%20of%20S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20State%2C%20who%20is%20an%20ally%20of%20Jair%20Bolsonaro%2C%20Brazil%E2%80%99s%20strongman%20President-elect.%20Last%20year%2C%20Kevin%20O%E2%80%99Leary%2C%20one%20of%20the%20hosts%20of%20%E2%80%9CShark%20Tank%2C%E2%80%9D%20announced%20his%20intention%20of%20running%20for%20Prime%20Minister%20of%20Canada%2C%20as%20a%20member%20of%20the%20Conservative%20Party%2C%20noting%20that%20he%20and%20Trump%20had%20%E2%80%9Cboth%20worked%20for%20Mark%20Burnett%2C%20and%20we%20both%20got%20famous%20on%20reality%20television.%E2%80%9D%20Burnett%20joked%20to%20more%20than%20one%20person%20that%20he%20was%20no%20longer%20simply%20a%20TV%20producer%20but%20a%20producer%20of%20political%20leaders.%20(Four%20months%20later%2C%20O%E2%80%99Leary%20dropped%20out%20of%20the%20race%20and%20returned%20to%20the%20show.)%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFor%20nearly%20two%20decades%2C%20Burnett%20has%20also%20spoken%20about%20his%20desire%20to%20make%20a%20television%20show%20with%20Vladimir%20Putin.%20In%202001%2C%20he%20sought%20to%20enlist%20Putin%20in%20a%20project%20called%20%E2%80%9CDestination%3A%20Mir%2C%E2%80%9D%20a%20reality%20competition%20in%20which%20the%20winner%20would%20be%20sent%20into%20space.%20The%20idea%20was%20scuttled%20after%20Russia%20decommissioned%20the%20Mir%20space%20station.%20In%202015%2C%20Burnett%20expressed%20an%20interest%20in%20building%20a%20reality%20show%20featuring%20Putin%E2%80%94not%20so%20much%20a%20program%20about%20politics%2C%20Burnett%20suggested%2C%20as%20a%20hymn%20to%20the%20glory%20of%20Russia%2C%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20humans%2C%20the%20nature%2C%20the%20animals%20of%20the%20nation.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBurnett%E2%80%99s%20myopia%20about%20politics%20may%20be%20selective%2C%20but%20that%20does%20not%20mean%20it%20is%20feigned.%20He%20would%20hardly%20be%20the%20first%20Hollywood%20chieftain%20with%20a%20dim%20grasp%20of%20current%20events%20beyond%20Los%20Angeles%2C%20but%20even%20by%20industry%20standards%20he%20can%20seem%20remarkably%20disconnected.%20Shortly%20after%20the%20mass%20shooting%20at%20Marjory%20Stoneman%20Douglas%20High%20School%2C%20in%20Parkland%2C%20Florida%2C%20this%20past%20February%2C%20Burnett%20attended%20a%20regular%20meeting%20of%20television%20executives%20at%20M-G-M.%20At%20one%20point%2C%20someone%20mentioned%20the%20marketing%20plan%20for%20a%20project%20in%20the%20studio%E2%80%99s%20film%20division%3A%20a%20remake%20of%20%E2%80%9CDeath%20Wish%2C%E2%80%9D%20starring%20Bruce%20Willis.%20The%20movie%2C%20about%20an%20armed%20vigilante%2C%20was%20unabashedly%20pro-gun%E2%80%94Breitbart%20eventually%20hailed%20it%20as%20an%20%E2%80%9CN.R.A.%20Public%20Service%20Announcement.%E2%80%9D%20Someone%20asked%20whether%20M-G-M%20would%20be%20altering%20the%20rollout%20of%20the%20film%2C%20in%20light%20of%20the%20shooting.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CWhat%20shooting%3F%E2%80%9D%20Burnett%20said%2C%20according%20to%20someone%20outside%20M-G-M%20who%20was%20briefed%20on%20the%20meeting.%20When%20his%20incredulous%20colleagues%20wondered%20how%20he%20could%20not%20have%20been%20aware%20of%20the%20Parkland%20massacre%2C%20Burnett%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20don%E2%80%99t%20know%20what%20you%E2%80%99re%20talking%20about%2C%E2%80%9D%20adding%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20not%20on%20social%20media.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EFor%20all%20Burnett%E2%80%99s%20talk%20about%20being%20nonpolitical%2C%20his%20reluctance%20to%20disavow%20the%20President%20may%20stem%2C%20in%20part%2C%20from%20a%20fear%20of%20alienating%20Trump%E2%80%99s%20constituents.%20Like%20Republican%20lawmakers%20or%20evangelical%20pastors%2C%20Burnett%20is%20beholden%20to%20a%20faction%20of%20the%20public%20that%2C%20in%20many%20instances%2C%20thinks%20the%20President%20can%20do%20no%20wrong.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20moment%20you%20go%20political%2C%20you%20turn%20half%20of%20the%20nation%20against%20you%2C%E2%80%9D%20Rick%20Warren%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CAnd%2C%20when%20you%E2%80%99re%20trying%20to%20reach%20as%20many%20people%20as%20you%20can%2C%20you%20don%E2%80%99t%20want%20to%20do%20that.%E2%80%9D%20The%20dilemma%20is%20compounded%2C%20Warren%20pointed%20out%2C%20when%20the%20occupant%20of%20the%20White%20House%20is%20so%20vindictive.%20%E2%80%9CYou%20know%20the%20way%20this%20President%20chews%20up%20people%3F%E2%80%9D%20Warren%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThere%E2%80%99s%20a%20fine%20line%20in%20what%20you%20can%20say.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EKatherine%20Walker%20suggested%20that%20part%20of%20the%20reason%20Burnett%20seems%20so%20unfazed%20by%20the%20role%20he%20has%20played%20in%20the%20Trump%20saga%20may%20be%20that%20he%20is%20British.%20%E2%80%9CThere%20is%20something%20to%20being%20American%20and%20having%20these%20visceral%20reactions%20that%20Mark%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20have%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20%E2%80%9CHe%20just%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20get%20it%20on%20that%20level.%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20think%20he%20has%20the%20same%20sense%20of%20Oh%2C%20my%20God%2C%20what%20have%20I%20done%3F%E2%80%9D%20For%20many%20Americans%2C%20the%20Trump%20Presidency%20evokes%20a%20painful%20feeling%20of%20dispossession%2C%20as%20cherished%20norms%20and%20national%20institutions%20are%20eviscerated.%20%E2%80%9CPeople%20are%20making%20it%20seem%20like%20Mark%E2%80%99s%20ignoring%20evil%2C%E2%80%9D%20Walker%20continued.%20%E2%80%9CBut%20I%20think%20it%E2%80%99s%20more%20benign%20than%20that%E2%80%94and%20scarier%2C%20in%20a%20way.%20He%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20care.%20He%20just%20wants%20to%20stay%20out%20of%20it.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","One day this past fall, Burnett got a call from his first wife, Kym Gold, with whom he remains friendly. Gold was upset about what was happening in the country, and asked Burnett to intervene with Trump. “We had it out,” she told me. “I said, ‘You’ve got to help our children, for the future and safety of this country.’ ” Gold implored Burnett, “Tell him this is not a reality show. This is real life. You’re the President. You’re saying things you cannot say—to reporters, to other world leaders.”"],["p","Burnett heard her out. “I’m not into politics,” he told her. “I’m not even on Twitter.” But he said that he had no intention of speaking out against Trump or of releasing any tapes. “I’m just a guy who produces shows,” he insisted."],["p","Burnett may not be a policy maven, but he has long been fascinated with political star power. In 2010, he launched “Sarah Palin’s Alaska,” on TLC, announcing, “With a dynamic personality that has captivated millions, I can’t think of anyone more compelling than Sarah Palin to tell the story of Alaska.” At the time, Burnett contended that the show was “completely nonpolitical.” The Daily Beast disagreed, suggesting that it “may qualify as the earliest, most expensive Presidential campaign ad ever made.”"],["p","Burnett and Trump have licensed the “Apprentice” format to dozens of other countries, and Burnett once noted that, increasingly, tycoons cast in the Trump role are “people with political aspirations.” At least half a dozen hosts have held political office, including João Doria, the governor-elect of São Paulo State, who is an ally of Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s strongman President-elect. Last year, Kevin O’Leary, one of the hosts of “Shark Tank,” announced his intention of running for Prime Minister of Canada, as a member of the Conservative Party, noting that he and Trump had “both worked for Mark Burnett, and we both got famous on reality television.” Burnett joked to more than one person that he was no longer simply a TV producer but a producer of political leaders. (Four months later, O’Leary dropped out of the race and returned to the show.)"],["p","For nearly two decades, Burnett has also spoken about his desire to make a television show with Vladimir Putin. In 2001, he sought to enlist Putin in a project called “Destination: Mir,” a reality competition in which the winner would be sent into space. The idea was scuttled after Russia decommissioned the Mir space station. In 2015, Burnett expressed an interest in building a reality show featuring Putin—not so much a program about politics, Burnett suggested, as a hymn to the glory of Russia, “the humans, the nature, the animals of the nation.”"],["p","Burnett’s myopia about politics may be selective, but that does not mean it is feigned. He would hardly be the first Hollywood chieftain with a dim grasp of current events beyond Los Angeles, but even by industry standards he can seem remarkably disconnected. Shortly after the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, in Parkland, Florida, this past February, Burnett attended a regular meeting of television executives at M-G-M. At one point, someone mentioned the marketing plan for a project in the studio’s film division: a remake of “Death Wish,” starring Bruce Willis. The movie, about an armed vigilante, was unabashedly pro-gun—Breitbart eventually hailed it as an “N.R.A. Public Service Announcement.” Someone asked whether M-G-M would be altering the rollout of the film, in light of the shooting."],["p","“What shooting?” Burnett said, according to someone outside M-G-M who was briefed on the meeting. When his incredulous colleagues wondered how he could not have been aware of the Parkland massacre, Burnett said, “I don’t know what you’re talking about,” adding, “I’m not on social media.”"],["p","For all Burnett’s talk about being nonpolitical, his reluctance to disavow the President may stem, in part, from a fear of alienating Trump’s constituents. Like Republican lawmakers or evangelical pastors, Burnett is beholden to a faction of the public that, in many instances, thinks the President can do no wrong. “The moment you go political, you turn half of the nation against you,” Rick Warren told me. “And, when you’re trying to reach as many people as you can, you don’t want to do that.” The dilemma is compounded, Warren pointed out, when the occupant of the White House is so vindictive. “You know the way this President chews up people?” Warren said. “There’s a fine line in what you can say.”"],["p","Katherine Walker suggested that part of the reason Burnett seems so unfazed by the role he has played in the Trump saga may be that he is British. “There is something to being American and having these visceral reactions that Mark doesn’t have,” she said. “He just doesn’t get it on that level. I don’t think he has the same sense of Oh, my God, what have I done?” For many Americans, the Trump Presidency evokes a painful feeling of dispossession, as cherished norms and national institutions are eviscerated. “People are making it seem like Mark’s ignoring evil,” Walker continued. “But I think it’s more benign than that—and scarier, in a way. He doesn’t care. He just wants to stay out of it.”"]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CMark%20is%20extremely%20smart%2C%E2%80%9D%20Richard%20Levak%2C%20the%20psychologist%20who%20consulted%20for%20Burnett%20on%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Apprentice%2C%E2%80%9D%20told%20me.%20%E2%80%9CMark%20has%20an%20eye%20for%20casting%2C%20and%20he%20cast%20Donald%20Trump.%E2%80%9D%20I%20asked%20Levak%20what%20kind%20of%20personality%20profile%20he%20might%20have%20prepared%20for%20Trump%20as%20a%20candidate%20for%20the%20show.%20He%20said%20he%20would%20have%20noted%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20energy%2C%20the%20impulsiveness%2C%20the%20inability%20to%20articulate%20a%20complete%20thought%20because%20he%20gets%20interrupted%20by%20emotions%2C%20so%20when%20he%20speaks%20it%E2%80%99s%20all%20adjectives%E2%80%94%E2%80%98great%2C%E2%80%99%20%E2%80%98huge%2C%E2%80%99%20%E2%80%98horrible.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20What%20made%20Trump%20so%20magnetic%20as%20a%20reality-television%20star%20was%20his%20impulse%20to%20transgress%2C%20Levak%20continued%2C%20and%20it%20is%20the%20same%20quality%20that%20has%20made%20a%20captive%20audience%20of%20the%20world.%20%E2%80%9CThat%20somebody%20can%20become%20that%20successful%20while%20also%20being%20that%20emotionally%20undisciplined%E2%80%94it%E2%80%99s%20so%20macabre%20that%20you%20%3Cem%3Ehave%3C%2Fem%3E%20to%20watch%20it%2C%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20%E2%80%9CAnd%20you%20keep%20waiting%20for%20the%20comeuppance.%20But%20it%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20come.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThere%20has%20likely%20never%20been%20a%20man%20who%2C%20in%20his%20own%20lifetime%2C%20has%20been%20as%20widely%20spoken%20and%20written%20about%20as%20Donald%20Trump.%20Politics%20has%20never%20been%20so%20spellbinding.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20the%20reason%20people%20watch%20a%20schoolyard%20fight%2C%E2%80%9D%20Levak%20said.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20vicariously%20watching%20someone%20act%20out%20and%20get%20away%20with%20it.%E2%80%9D%20Burnett%20once%20remarked%20that%20%E2%80%9CLord%20of%20the%20Flies%E2%80%9D%20is%20so%20absorbing%20because%20all%20the%20characters%20are%20suddenly%20transported%20into%20a%20world%20in%20which%20%E2%80%9Cthe%20rules%20are%20changed%2C%20and%20convention%2C%20law%2C%20and%20morality%20are%20suspended.%E2%80%9D%20It%E2%80%99s%20an%20apt%20paraphrase%20of%20the%20Trump%20Presidency.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EOn%20Sunday%20afternoons%2C%20Burnett%20likes%20to%20pour%20himself%20a%20generous%20glass%20of%20wine%20and%20stroll%20out%20onto%20the%20balcony%20of%20his%20seven-thousand-square-foot%20home%2C%20off%20the%20Pacific%20Coast%20Highway%20in%20Malibu.%20He%20and%20Downey%20refer%20to%20the%20property%2C%20which%20was%20undamaged%20by%20the%20recent%20wildfires%2C%20as%20the%20Sanctuary.%20It%20is%20an%20exquisite%20spot%2C%20with%20white%20couches%20facing%20an%20unbroken%20view%20of%20the%20ocean.%20Burnett%20likes%20to%20reflect%20on%20the%20fact%20that%20his%20mansion%20is%20not%20far%20from%20one%20of%20the%20homes%20where%2C%20as%20a%20young%20immigrant%2C%20he%20worked%20as%20a%20nanny.%20He%20%3Cem%3Eis%3C%2Fem%3E%20on%20social%20media%2C%20as%20it%20happens.%20He%20seldom%20tweets%2C%20but%20he%E2%80%99s%20active%20on%20Instagram.%20Along%20with%20family%20snapshots%20and%20photographs%20of%20Burnett%20palling%20around%20with%20celebrities%20and%20religious%20figures%2C%20there%20are%20a%20couple%20of%20videos%20he%20has%20taken%20of%20himself%20relaxing%20on%20the%20balcony.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CLazy%20Sunday%20afternoon%2C%E2%80%9D%20Burnett%20says%20in%20one%20of%20them.%20He%20is%20barefoot%2C%20wearing%20a%20T-shirt%20that%20says%20%E2%80%9C%3Cem%20class%3D%5C%22small%5C%22%3ESPIRITUAL%20GANGSTER%3C%2Fem%3E.%E2%80%9D%20He%20gestures%20at%20his%20expansive%20view%2C%20with%20undisguised%20satisfaction%2C%20and%20says%2C%20%E2%80%9CLook%20at%20this.%20Wow.%E2%80%9D%20He%20pans%20the%20camera%20across%20the%20sky%2C%20which%20is%20just%20starting%20to%20bruise%20red%20and%20violet%20in%20the%20twilight.%20%E2%80%9CSo%20grateful%2C%E2%80%9D%20Burnett%20says.%20He%20often%20expresses%20wonderment%20at%20how%20blessed%20he%20is%2C%20and%20at%20the%20magnitude%20of%20his%20success%E2%80%94which%2C%20these%20days%2C%20he%20ascribes%20to%20%E2%80%9CGod%E2%80%99s%20favor.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWhen%20I%20remarked%20to%20Jonathon%20Braun%20that%20Burnett%20seems%20eerily%20untroubled%20by%20the%20legacy%20of%20his%20own%20creation%2C%20he%20said%20that%2C%20for%20Burnett%2C%20the%20Presidency%20was%20just%20another%20game.%20He%20went%20on%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20think%20it%E2%80%99s%20a%20game%20for%20Trump%2C%20too.%20It%E2%80%99s%20a%20game%20for%20the%20audience.%20I%20think%20the%20voters%20like%20it.%20They%E2%80%99re%20enjoying%20the%20spectacle.%20It%E2%80%99s%20in%20the%20soul%20of%20who%20Mark%20is.%20They%E2%80%99re%20kindred%20spirits.%20There%20are%20no%20major%20causes%20driving%20them%E2%80%94it%E2%80%99s%20just%20about%20playing%20a%20game%20and%20winning%20it.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EYears%20ago%2C%20when%20Burnett%20did%20publicity%20for%20%E2%80%9CSurvivor%2C%E2%80%9D%20interviewers%20tried%20to%20figure%20out%20how%20the%20contestants%20had%20fared%20that%20season.%20Of%20course%2C%20he%20could%20not%20reveal%20such%20secrets.%20So%20when%20they%20asked%20Burnett%20who%20would%20win%20the%20game%2C%20he%20told%20them%2C%20%E2%80%9CMe.%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","“Mark is extremely smart,” Richard Levak, the psychologist who consulted for Burnett on “The Apprentice,” told me. “Mark has an eye for casting, and he cast Donald Trump.” I asked Levak what kind of personality profile he might have prepared for Trump as a candidate for the show. He said he would have noted “the energy, the impulsiveness, the inability to articulate a complete thought because he gets interrupted by emotions, so when he speaks it’s all adjectives—‘great,’ ‘huge,’ ‘horrible.’ ” What made Trump so magnetic as a reality-television star was his impulse to transgress, Levak continued, and it is the same quality that has made a captive audience of the world. “That somebody can become that successful while also being that emotionally undisciplined—it’s so macabre that you ",["em","have"]," to watch it,” he said. “And you keep waiting for the comeuppance. But it doesn’t come.”"],["p","There has likely never been a man who, in his own lifetime, has been as widely spoken and written about as Donald Trump. Politics has never been so spellbinding. “It’s the reason people watch a schoolyard fight,” Levak said. “It’s vicariously watching someone act out and get away with it.” Burnett once remarked that “Lord of the Flies” is so absorbing because all the characters are suddenly transported into a world in which “the rules are changed, and convention, law, and morality are suspended.” It’s an apt paraphrase of the Trump Presidency."],["p","On Sunday afternoons, Burnett likes to pour himself a generous glass of wine and stroll out onto the balcony of his seven-thousand-square-foot home, off the Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu. He and Downey refer to the property, which was undamaged by the recent wildfires, as the Sanctuary. It is an exquisite spot, with white couches facing an unbroken view of the ocean. Burnett likes to reflect on the fact that his mansion is not far from one of the homes where, as a young immigrant, he worked as a nanny. He ",["em","is"]," on social media, as it happens. He seldom tweets, but he’s active on Instagram. Along with family snapshots and photographs of Burnett palling around with celebrities and religious figures, there are a couple of videos he has taken of himself relaxing on the balcony."],["p","“Lazy Sunday afternoon,” Burnett says in one of them. He is barefoot, wearing a T-shirt that says “",["em",{"class":"small"},"SPIRITUAL GANGSTER"],".” He gestures at his expansive view, with undisguised satisfaction, and says, “Look at this. Wow.” He pans the camera across the sky, which is just starting to bruise red and violet in the twilight. “So grateful,” Burnett says. He often expresses wonderment at how blessed he is, and at the magnitude of his success—which, these days, he ascribes to “God’s favor.”"],["p","When I remarked to Jonathon Braun that Burnett seems eerily untroubled by the legacy of his own creation, he said that, for Burnett, the Presidency was just another game. He went on, “I think it’s a game for Trump, too. It’s a game for the audience. I think the voters like it. They’re enjoying the spectacle. It’s in the soul of who Mark is. They’re kindred spirits. There are no major causes driving them—it’s just about playing a game and winning it.”"],["p","Years ago, when Burnett did publicity for “Survivor,” interviewers tried to figure out how the contestants had fared that season. Of course, he could not reveal such secrets. So when they asked Burnett who would win the game, he told them, “Me.” ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"590a18798b51cf59fc42477f","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"590a18798b51cf59fc42477f","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Profiles","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"profiles"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Profiles","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"profiles"}]}]},"channel":"Magazine","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[],"contentType":"article","contributors":[{"name":"Patrick Radden Keefe","type":"author","title":"Patrick Radden Keefe, a staff writer, has been contributing to The New Yorker since 2006. His new book, “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Say-Nothing-Murder-Northern-Ireland/dp/0385521316\">Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland\u003c/a>,” will be published in the U.S. in February.","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Patrick Radden Keefe, a staff writer, has been contributing to ",["em","The New Yorker"]," since 2006. He has written about the chef turned world traveller Anthony Bourdain, the capture of the Mexican drug baron Joaquín (El Chapo) Guzmán Loera, and allegations of corruption against the tycoon Beny Steinmetz over a lucrative mining concession in Guinea. His story “",["a",{"href":"http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/02/11/130211fa_fact_keefe?currentPage=all"},"A Loaded Gun,"],"” about the troubled history of the mass shooter Amy Bishop, received the National Magazine Award for Feature Writing in 2014; he was also a finalist for the National Magazine Award for Reporting in 2015 and 2016. He is the author of three books: “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/0307279278/"},"The Snakehead: An Epic Tale of the Chinatown Underworld and the American Dream"],",” which grew out of an article published in the magazine; “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/dp/0812968271/"},"Chatter: Uncovering the Echelon Surveillance Network and the Secret World of Global Eavesdropping"],"”; and “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Say-Nothing-Murder-Northern-Ireland/dp/0385521316"},"Say Nothing: A True Story of Murder and Memory in Northern Ireland"],",” which will be published in the U.S. in February. He is the recipient of a Guggenheim Fellowship and fellowships at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, the New America Foundation, and the Cullman Center for Scholars and Writers at the New York Public Library."]],"social":[{"network":"Twitter","handle":"praddenkeefe"}],"url":"/contributors/patrick-radden-keefe","image":null}],"dek":"How Mark Burnett, the king of reality television, helped turn a floundering D-lister into President Trump.","formatting":{},"hed":"Winning","id":"5c1abb8836cecf4019212e16","inlineEmbeds":{},"issueDate":"January 7, 2019","modifiedAt":"2019-01-08T22:55:47.355Z","photos":{"tout":[{"id":"5c1ad8cd81ab3335f580def0","modelName":"photo","collection":"photos","aspectRatios":{"2:2":{"width":694,"height":694,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":956,"y":379,"height":694,"width":694}},"duration":null},"16:9":{"width":1839,"height":1034,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":339,"height":1034,"width":1839}},"duration":null},"4:3":{"width":1838,"height":1379,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":1,"y":346,"height":1379,"width":1838}},"duration":null},"1:1":{"width":1839,"height":1839,"override":false,"modifications":{"crop":{"x":0,"y":127,"height":1839,"width":1839}},"duration":null},"master":{"format":"JPEG","url":"https://cn-copilot-media.s3.amazonaws.com/public/tny-services/production/2018/12/19/5c1ad8cd81ab3335f580deef_190107_r33509.jpg","width":1840,"height":2560,"duration":null}},"caption":["div",["p","Burnett, like Trump, feels like an outsider, an associate says: “In the reality-TV business, you’re never part of the true Hollywood.”"]],"altText":"Illustration of Donald Trump and Mark Burnett","credit":"Illustration by Christian Northeast. %20Herrera%20of%20its%20title%3A%20Carmen%20Herrera%2C%20a%20Cuban-born%20painter%2C%20now%20a%20hundred%20and%20three%20years%20old%20and%20living%20in%20New%20York%2C%20who%20only%20recently%20has%20gained%20the%20recognition%20that%20she%20deserves%20for%20her%20rigorously%20spare%20hard-edged%20abstractions.%20(In%202016%2C%20a%20show%20at%20the%20Whitney%20was%20her%20first%20in%20two%20decades%20at%20any%20institution.)%20On%20hand%20is%20a%20single%20smallish%2C%20modestly%20appealing%20painting%2C%20%E2%80%9CEquilibrio%E2%80%9D%20(2012)%2C%20that%20pictures%20a%20stack%20of%20three%20downward-pointing%20black%20triangles.%20From%20Pollock%20to%20%3Cem%3Ethis%3C%2Fem%3E%3F%20Without%20contextual%20reference%20to%20generations%20of%20preceding%20and%20contemporary%20geometric%20stylizers%3F%20(One%20stately%20shaped%20canvas%20by%20the%20American%20Robert%20Mangold%20and%20one%20so-so%20example%20by%20the%20Argentinian%20Alejandro%20Puente%20do%20not%20suffice.)%20Herrera%E2%80%99s%20eponymous%20presence%20is%20a%20gesture%20broadcasting%20the%20show%E2%80%99s%20character%20as%20an%20exercise%20in%20feel-good%20inclusion%E2%80%94the%20museum%20congratulating%20itself%20on%20liberal%20virtuousness%2C%20with%20its%20responsibility%20to%20draw%20distinctions%20of%20quality%20and%20significance%20politely%20on%20hold.%20A%20desire%20to%20shake%20up%20received%20art%20history%20is%20more%20than%20admirable%20today%E2%80%94it%E2%80%99s%20urgent%20for%20a%20future%20of%20pluralist%20values.%20But%20this%20show%20effectively%20reinforces%20the%20old%20status%20quo.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EHere%E2%80%99s%20a%20suggestion%3A%20reframe%20the%20undoubted%20greatness%20of%20Abstract%20Expressionism%20in%20terms%20of%20the%20risks%20of%20abject%20failure%20that%20its%20proponents%20ran.%20(I%20think%20of%20the%20oft-told%20anecdote%20of%20Pollock%20asking%20Lee%20Krasner%2C%20of%20a%20drip%20work%20that%20he%20had%20just%20made%2C%20%E2%80%9CIs%20this%20a%20painting%3F%E2%80%9D)%20The%20drama%20is%20not%20inherent%20in%20the%20forms%20that%20they%20created%2C%20which%20may%20or%20may%20not%20prove%20lastingly%20influential.%20All%20artists%20must%20rise%20or%20fall%20by%20braving%20perils%20and%20finding%20opportunities%20specific%20to%20themselves%20and%20to%20their%20own%20times%2C%20the%20canon%20be%20damned.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The first room of “Epic Abstraction: Pollock to Herrera,” a wishfully canon-expanding show of painting and sculpture from the past eight decades, at the Metropolitan Museum, affects like a mighty organ chord. It contains the museum’s two best paintings by Jackson Pollock: “Pasiphaë” (1943), a quaking compaction of mythological elements named for the accursed mother of the Minotaur, and “Autumn Rhythm (Number 30)” (1950), a singing orchestration of drips in black, white, brown, and teal enamel—bluntly material and, inextricably, sublime. There are six Pollock drawings, too, and “Number 7” (1952), one of his late, return-to-figuration paintings in mostly black on white, of an indistinct but hieratic head. The adjective “epic” does little enough to honor Pollock’s mid-century glory, which anchors the standard art-historical saga of Abstract Expressionism—“The Triumph of American Painting,” per the title of a 1976 book on the subject by Irving Sandler—as a revolution that stole the former thunder of Paris and set a stratospheric benchmark for subsequent artists. The movement has generated both awe and discomfort, like a pet whale, among makers, students, and lovers of art ever since."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1d1b611fa04b334bab0816%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1b611fa04b334bab0816%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1d1b611fa04b334bab0816%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d1b611fa04b334bab0816"}]],["p","Advance notice of this show, which features abundant work by women and African-Americans and a few pieces from Europe, Latin America, and Japan, seemed to bode challenges to the heroic myth. This made me a bit nervous—I was weaned on Abstract Expressionism—but I was also game, as one must be now, for democratizing revisions of art history. I need not have fretted—or hoped. The show, curated by Randall Griffey, takes the old valuation as a given without mentioning its vulnerabilities: rhetorical inflation, often, and macho entitlement, always. (Zooming in on the dazzling annals of the movement’s historic struggles, you discover tacky barroom cockfights.) This perspective casts artists whose works reacted against or shrugged off Abstract Expressionism as little fish around the Leviathan. Why and how did the prestige of Abstract Expressionism collapse at the end of the nineteen-fifties? Ignored entirely are movements—French ",["em","tachisme"],", Northern European ",["em",{"class":"small"},"COBRA"],"—that contested New York supremacy at the time and seem ripe, now, for reconsideration. It would be hard to overstate the embarrassment that the show visits on independent-minded artists whom it shoehorns into a common genealogy."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1d1b611fa04b334bab0815%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1b611fa04b334bab0815%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1d1b611fa04b334bab0815%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d1b611fa04b334bab0815"}]],["p","Unhappily displayed amid the Pollocks, an untitled painting on paper, mounted on canvas, by Kazuo Shiraga, from 1958, represents a movement in Japan that took the American innovation in a ferociously performative direction. It consists of frenzied smearings, by hands and feet, of oils in browns and reds. It is dramatic as a deed but, as a painting, slack, with no formal tension. The paint just sits there: evidence rather than expression. In this context, the work suggests a misunderstanding of the firmly disciplined Pollock as a wild man. Shiraga comes off as a callow provincial. That’s unfair. He and his peers in the Gutai group meaningfully responded to the disarray of their nation after the disasters of the Second World War. These artists weren’t concerned with either the epic or, although their work was nonfigurative, the abstract in any pointed way, and pitting the Shiraga against masterpieces that supremely embody both feels beyond maladroit: cruel. One of the show’s verbose wall texts acknowledges the stylistic and historical character of the Gutai group, but being told what to think hardly balances what one is given to see."],["p","The show’s oppressive effect intensifies in its magnificent second room, which gathers ten works by Mark Rothko that vary widely in quality but feature a gem in plangent red-orange and an ungraspable cream color, “No. 3,” from 1953, his peak year of aesthetic miracles. This hammers home the majesty of the New York School—and almost exhausts, by the way, the major strength of the Met’s holdings of art since the nineteen-forties. (But for a few loans, the show draws on the museum’s collection.) The Met is justly infamous for softheaded, miscellaneous acquisitions of contemporary art—a minor failing of the greatest museum in the Western Hemisphere, but a fact that casts a shadow on a plan for a refurbished wing devoted to such work."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1d1b6141e4c73c088d6af8%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1b6141e4c73c088d6af8%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1d1b6141e4c73c088d6af8%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d1b6141e4c73c088d6af8"}]],["p","After the Rothko room, the exhibition goes to pieces. With exceptions including Willem de Kooning’s “Easter Monday” (1955-56), an abstraction at once hyperactive and serene that can seem both to summarize and to kiss off the history of modern art, cogency becomes scarce. There are excellent sculptures by Isamu Noguchi and David Smith, and sculptures that make no sense at all, in this context, by Alexander Calder, Jean Tinguely, and, at the show’s entrance, Dan Flavin. Several good-to-O.K. works by Clyfford Still, Barnett Newman, and Franz Kline maintain the main line of Abstract Expressionism, from which paintings by Ellsworth Kelly and Cy Twombly sharply, but without affirmed notice, depart. Some later artists revive keynotes of the epoch—Joan Snyder with a lively smatter of drifting brushwork, from 1971, and, recently, Mark Bradford with grand splurges of jittery marks—at a cost of inviting comparison with their powerful precedents. “Mrs. N’s Palace” (1964-77), by the sometimes winning sculptor Louise Nevelson, goes all in for Abstract Expressionism’s tendency toward grandiosity. Crowding the middle of the show, it’s a hut—or perhaps a shrine—made of black-painted wood scraps, almost twelve feet high, nearly twenty feet wide, and fifteen feet deep. Beyond the staggering first impression that it makes, the work affords next to no visual engagement. A fussily decorative painting on four panels, “La Vie en Rose” (1979), likewise betrays Joan Mitchell. You wouldn’t guess from it, if you didn’t already know, that Mitchell is easily the premier second-generation Abstract Expressionist, and the most reliably thrilling."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1d1b603e17f81da2a3b6be%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1b603e17f81da2a3b6be%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1d1b603e17f81da2a3b6be%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d1b603e17f81da2a3b6be"}]],["p","Were this a more thoughtful show, it would not have installed “New York #2,” by Hedda Sterne (the only woman in the famous 1951 ",["em","Life"]," group photograph of the era’s new artists), so inconspicuously, or “Red Roses Sonata” (1972), by Alma Thomas, the once neglected but increasingly celebrated Washington, D.C., color-field painter. Sterne’s work is a tall, abstracted cityscape in grisaille that looks, from a distance, drawn or somehow printed but, up close, reveals itself to be tenderly brushed. One could argue that it’s an important dissent from the prevailing art of its time. Thomas’s painting, justifying its title, is a truly musical composition of red and green strokes. She was an astonishing colorist, more than equal in that respect to others in her stylistic cohort, like Helen Frankenthaler, Morris Louis, and Kenneth Noland, who are also represented in the show. But “Red Roses” is more directly juxtaposed with a painting and two drawings by the superb British artist Bridget Riley, whose optically buzzy vertical stripes relate to it only by trivial analogy between intellectually opposed chromatic intensities."],["inline-embed",{"type":"callout","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22callout%22%2C%22name%22%3A%22feature-small%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cinline-embed%20type%3D%5C%22image%5C%22%20meta%3D%5C%22%257B%2522type%2522%253A%2522image%2522%252C%2522url%2522%253A%2522%252Fphotos%252F5c1d1b616e94e94091467112%2522%252C%2522width%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522height%2522%253A%2522%2522%252C%2522caption%2522%253A%2522%2522%257D%5C%22%20ref%3D%5C%225c1d1b616e94e94091467112%5C%22%3E%3C%2Finline-embed%3E%22%2C%22attrs%22%3A%7B%7D%7D","ref":""},["inline-embed",{"type":"image","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22image%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22%2Fphotos%2F5c1d1b616e94e94091467112%22%2C%22width%22%3A%22%22%2C%22height%22%3A%22%22%2C%22caption%22%3A%22%22%7D","ref":"5c1d1b616e94e94091467112"}]],["p","Clinching the gaucherie of the show is the use of the Herrera of its title: Carmen Herrera, a Cuban-born painter, now a hundred and three years old and living in New York, who only recently has gained the recognition that she deserves for her rigorously spare hard-edged abstractions. (In 2016, a show at the Whitney was her first in two decades at any institution.) On hand is a single smallish, modestly appealing painting, “Equilibrio” (2012), that pictures a stack of three downward-pointing black triangles. From Pollock to ",["em","this"],"? Without contextual reference to generations of preceding and contemporary geometric stylizers? (One stately shaped canvas by the American Robert Mangold and one so-so example by the Argentinian Alejandro Puente do not suffice.) Herrera’s eponymous presence is a gesture broadcasting the show’s character as an exercise in feel-good inclusion—the museum congratulating itself on liberal virtuousness, with its responsibility to draw distinctions of quality and significance politely on hold. A desire to shake up received art history is more than admirable today—it’s urgent for a future of pluralist values. But this show effectively reinforces the old status quo."],["p","Here’s a suggestion: reframe the undoubted greatness of Abstract Expressionism in terms of the risks of abject failure that its proponents ran. (I think of the oft-told anecdote of Pollock asking Lee Krasner, of a drip work that he had just made, “Is this a painting?”) The drama is not inherent in the forms that they created, which may or may not prove lastingly influential. All artists must rise or fall by braving perils and finding opportunities specific to themselves and to their own times, the canon be damned. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"590a11e68b51cf59fc42475c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"590a11e68b51cf59fc42475c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"The Schjeldahl","type":"author","title":"Peter Schjeldahl has been a staff writer at \u003cem>The New Yorker\u003c/em> since 1998 and is the magazine’s art critic. He is the author of “\u003ca href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/0520082826/?tag=thneyo0f-20\">The Hydrogen Jukebox\u003c/a>.”","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Peter Schjeldahl has been a staff writer at ",["em","The New Yorker"]," since 1998 and is the magazine’s art critic. He came to the magazine from ",["em","The Village Voice"],", where he was the art critic from 1990 to 1998. Previously, he had written frequently for the New York ",["em","Times’s"]," Arts and Leisure section. His writing has also appeared in ",["em","Artforum"],", ",["em","Art in America"],", the New York ",["em","Times Magazine"],", ",["em","Vogue"],", and ",["em","Vanity Fair"],". He has received the Clark Prize for Excellence in Arts Writing from the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute; the Frank Jewett Mather Award from the College Art Association, for excellence in art criticism; the Howard Vursell Memorial Award from the American Academy of Arts and Letters, for “recent prose that merits recognition for the quality of its style”; and a Guggenheim Fellowship. He is the author of four books of criticism, including “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Hydrogen-Jukebox-Selected-Schjeldahl-1978-1990/dp/0520082826/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1489606639&sr=1-1&keywords=The+Hydrogen+Jukebox%3A+Selected+Writings"},"The Hydrogen Jukebox: Selected Writings"],",” and
