of%20them%20showed%20up%20on%20the%20Lower%20East%20Side%2C%20to%20sample%20the%20food%20of%20some%20two%20dozen%20venders%20in%20white%20tents.%20Mike%20stood%20by%20a%20Chau-family%20tent%2C%20receiving%20visitors.%20The%20%E2%80%9Cbaby%E2%80%9D%20portion%20of%20%40foodbabyny%20was%20temporarily%20unavailable%3A%20Alex%20had%20taken%20Matty%2C%20now%20five%2C%20to%20warm%20up%20in%20the%20car%2C%20and%20Sammy%2C%20three%2C%20had%20taken%20refuge%20behind%20a%20vender%E2%80%99s%20table%2C%20where%20she%20was%20snuggling%20in%20her%20grandfather%E2%80%99s%20lap.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ELooking%20around%20at%20the%20offerings%E2%80%94Supermoon%20Bakehouse%2C%20Destination%20Dumplings%2C%20Mama%E2%80%99s%20Too!%E2%80%94Mike%20noted%20that%20he%E2%80%99d%20chosen%20restaurants%20that%20deserved%20%E2%80%9Cmore%20exposure.%E2%80%9D%20He%20was%20holding%20yuca%20fries%20from%20Millie%E2%80%99s%20Cuban%20Caf%C3%A9%2C%20but%20so%20many%20people%20were%20trying%20to%20talk%20to%20him%20that%20he%20didn%E2%80%99t%20have%20time%20to%20eat.%20Do%20all%20your%20posts%20involve%20your%20kids%3F%20(Most%20do%2C%20yes!)%20Where%E2%80%99s%20a%20good%20place%20around%20here%20for%20brunch%3F%20(Kiki%E2%80%99s!)%20Can%20we%20get%20a%20picture%3F%20(Absolutely!)%20After%20getting%20her%20selfie%2C%20Janice%20Wang%2C%20a%20young%20foodie%20from%20the%20Upper%20East%20Side%2C%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20a%20bit%20of%20a%20food%20snob%2C%20and%20I%20want%20to%20know%20what%E2%80%99s%20out%20there.%E2%80%9D%20Diana%20Nguyen%20and%20Cham%20Keat%2C%20who%20run%20the%20Instagram%20account%20%40hypefoodies%2C%20had%20driven%20from%20Washington%2C%20D.C.%20Nguyen%20was%20holding%20an%20Ice%20%26amp%3B%20Vice%20cone%20piled%20with%20scoops%20of%20Pickled%20Cherry%20and%20FoodBaby%2C%20a%20special%20flavor%20(Concord-grape%20ice%20cream%2C%20raspberry%20coulis%2C%20doughnut%20soil%2C%20rainbow%20sprinkles).%20Of%20the%20Chaus%2C%20Nguyen%20said%2C%20%E2%80%9CWe%20really%20love%20watching%20them%20live%20their%20life%20with%20food.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EKevin%20Hernandez%2C%20a%20guidance%20counsellor%2C%20introduced%20Mike%20to%20his%20wife%2C%20Ilana%2C%20who%20was%20pregnant.%20%E2%80%9CWe%E2%80%99re%20obsessed%20with%20you%20guys%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hernandez%20told%20him.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20love%20that%20your%20kids%20eat%20whatever%20you%20give%20them.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CDid%20you%20see%20the%20video%20of%20us%20giving%20them%20grasshoppers%3F%E2%80%9D%20Mike%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3E%E2%80%9CIt%20was%20amazing%2C%E2%80%9D%20Hernandez%20said.%20%E2%80%9CThey%20were%20eating%20them%20like%20they%20were%20chips.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAfter%20a%20teen-age%20boy%20asked%20Mike%20for%20advice%20on%20breaking%20out%20of%20an%20Instagram%20rut%E2%80%94%E2%80%9CI%20feel%20like%20everything%20is%20starting%20to%20look%20the%20same%E2%80%9D%E2%80%94Sammy%20wandered%20out%2C%20wearing%20a%20leopard-print%20jacket%20and%20sparkly%20pink%20sneakers.%20The%20crowd%20swarmed%2C%20cell%20phones%20aloft.%20A%20woman%20said%20to%20her%20husband%2C%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%20there%E2%80%99s%20the%20little%20girl!%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EWill%20%40foodbabyny%20lose%20its%20appeal%20as%20the%20children%20grow%20up%3F%20The%20question%20is%20irrelevant%2C%20for%20now.%20A%20couple%20of%20weeks%20after%20the%20festival%2C%20Alex%20gave%20birth%20to%20a%20daughter%2C%20Nicky%E2%80%94Chau%20baby%20No.%203.%20Within%20weeks%2C%20Nicky%20was%20rolling%20her%20eyes%20on%20Instagram%2C%20backdropping%20a%20Gooey%20Everything%20Bar%20from%20the%20Good%20Batch.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","Mike and Alexandra Chau got married in 2012, when they were twenty-eight years old. Mike works in tech, Alex in finance. As they thought about expanding their family, they moved from Manhattan to Mike’s childhood neighborhood of Forest Hills, Queens. An enthusiastic eater, Mike considered himself “one of those people who posted too many pictures of food” on Instagram. One night in 2013, he took a picture of a newborn baby, red and scowling, alongside an open takeout container of chicken and brown rice: the Chaus’ son, Matty, was sixty-seven hours old."],["p","A meatball shot followed. Then red velvet cake. Then, as the days passed, sushi and pad Thai. Matty was not yet consuming solid food, but his newborn expressions—lolling tongue, grimace—seemed to convey a gastronomic opinion. When paired with a cider doughnut, he rolled his eyes, as if in disdain. His father discovered that a bitten cookie resembled a bib when held beneath his son’s chin. The food was a fun accessory to the baby—or was it the other way around? “I thought, Oh, this is interesting,” Mike said."],["p","The star power of the Instagram feed that became @foodbabyny doubled in 2015, when the Chaus’ daughter, Sammy, was born. She made her social-media début with a box of pastries from the Doughnut Project. Mike liked visiting buzzy new restaurants on opening day, and, as the children grew, so did @foodbabyny’s repertoire. The kids posed with pizza, tofu, kimchi, kale, bagels, burgers, spring rolls, shakshuka, crêpes, noodles, ramen, falafel, waffles, bao, and pie. They were caught sleeping, laughing, thumbs-upping, pouting, and squalling, often while wearing entertaining outfits—a trucker cap that said “",["em",{"class":"small"},"RIBS"],",” a T-shirt that said “",["em",{"class":"small"},"NEW YORK OR NOWHERE"],".”"],["p","Mike name-checked businesses with a friendly hashtag (#foodbabylovesottostacos), which endeared him to restaurateurs. Foodies began asking him where to eat. He disliked the term “influencer,” but that’s what he became. Inevitably, there was backlash: after Sammy was shown shredding an enormous leg of turkey at Disneyland, a commenter complained, “You’re literally giving SHIT to your kid.” Mike later said, “Just because the kids are ",["em","next"]," to the food doesn’t mean they’re eating all of it.”"],["p","By the time the Hester Street Fair asked Mike to curate the inaugural FoodBabyNY Food Fest, this past October, more than three hundred thousand Instagrammers were following the Chaus. On a cold, blustery day, hundreds of them showed up on the Lower East Side, to sample the food of some two dozen venders in white tents. Mike stood by a Chau-family tent, receiving visitors. The “baby” portion of @foodbabyny was temporarily unavailable: Alex had taken Matty, now five, to warm up in the car, and Sammy, three, had taken refuge behind a vender’s table, where she was snuggling in her grandfather’s lap."],["p","Looking around at the offerings—Supermoon Bakehouse, Destination Dumplings, Mama’s Too!—Mike noted that he’d chosen restaurants that deserved “more exposure.” He was holding yuca fries from Millie’s Cuban Café, but so many people were trying to talk to him that he didn’t have time to eat. Do all your posts involve your kids? (Most do, yes!) Where’s a good place around here for brunch? (Kiki’s!) Can we get a picture? (Absolutely!) After getting her selfie, Janice Wang, a young foodie from the Upper East Side, said, “I’m a bit of a food snob, and I want to know what’s out there.” Diana Nguyen and Cham Keat, who run the Instagram account @hypefoodies, had driven from Washington, D.C. Nguyen was holding an Ice & Vice cone piled with scoops of Pickled Cherry and FoodBaby, a special flavor (Concord-grape ice cream, raspberry coulis, doughnut soil, rainbow sprinkles). Of the Chaus, Nguyen said, “We really love watching them live their life with food.”"],["p","Kevin Hernandez, a guidance counsellor, introduced Mike to his wife, Ilana, who was pregnant. “We’re obsessed with you guys,” Hernandez told him. “We love that your kids eat whatever you give them.”"],["p","“Did you see the video of us giving them grasshoppers?” Mike said."],["p","“It was amazing,” Hernandez said. “They were eating them like they were chips.”"],["p","After a teen-age boy asked Mike for advice on breaking out of an Instagram rut—“I feel like everything is starting to look the same”—Sammy wandered out, wearing a leopard-print jacket and sparkly pink sneakers. The crowd swarmed, cell phones aloft. A woman said to her husband, “Oh, there’s the little girl!”"],["p","Will @foodbabyny lose its appeal as the children grow up? The question is irrelevant, for now. A couple of weeks after the festival, Alex gave birth to a daughter, Nicky—Chau baby No. 3. Within weeks, Nicky was rolling her eyes on Instagram, backdropping a Gooey Everything Bar from the Good Batch. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"5c1d36046e94e940914671c9","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"5c1d36046e94e940914671c9","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Influencers","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"influencers"},{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"},{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"name":"Influencers","parent":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"magazine"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"influencers"}]}]},"channel":"Magazine","contentSource":"magazine","contentTags":[],"contentType":"article","contributors":[{"name":"Paige Williams","type":"author","title":"Paige Williams, the Laventhol/Newsday Visiting Professor at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism, became a staff writer at \u003cem>The New Yorker\u003c/em> in 2015.","email":"","bio":["div",["p","Paige Williams began writing for ",["em","The New Yorker"]," in 2013 and became a staff writer in 2015. Her subjects have included suburban politics in Detroit, the death penalty in Alabama, paleoanthropology in South Africa, and the misappropriated cultural patrimony of the Tlingit peoples of Alaska. She won the National Magazine Award for feature writing, in 2008, and was a finalist, in another category, in 2011. Her work has appeared in anthologies including “The Best American Magazine Writing” and “The Best American Crime Writing.” Williams is the Laventhol/Newsday Visiting Professor at Columbia University’s Graduate School of Journalism, and she has taught at universities including Ole Miss, N.Y.U., and M.I.T., in the Knight Science Journalism program. She has been a fellow of the MacDowell Colony and was a Nieman Fellow at Harvard. In 2013, she wrote for the magazine about a ",["a",{"href":"https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/01/28/bones-of-contention-2"},"smuggled dinosaur skeleton"]," from the Gobi Desert of Mongolia; the story became the book “",["a",{"href":"https://www.amazon.com/Dinosaur-Artist-Obsession-Betrayal-Ultimate/dp/0316382531"},"The Dinosaur Artist"],",” published in September, 2018."]],"social":[{"network":"Twitter","handle":"Williams_Paige"},{"network":"Facebook","handle":"https://www.facebook.com/paigewilliams1"}],"url":"/contributors/paige-williams","image":null}],"dek":"","formatting":{},"hed":"Say 20to%20the%20outbreak%20of%20war%2C%20though%20diehard%20devotees%20would%20stretch%20it%20out%20longer%E2%80%94and%20chooses%20to%20focus%2C%20instead%2C%20on%20its%20plaintive%20dusk.%20The%20bulk%20of%20the%20story%20is%20set%20in%20the%20years%201953-54%2C%20as%20Laurel%20(Steve%20Coogan)%20and%20Hardy%20(John%C2%A0C.%20Reilly)%20travel%20around%20Britain%2C%20rehashing%20their%20old%20routines%20in%20a%20stage%20show.%20The%20plan%20is%20to%20end%20the%20tour%20triumphantly%20in%20London%2C%20and%20to%20secure%20financing%20for%20a%20Robin%20Hood%20movie%2C%20entitled%20%E2%80%9CRob%20%E2%80%99Em%20Good.%E2%80%9D%20We%20know%2C%20as%20Laurel%20knows%2C%20that%20it%20may%20never%20get%20made%2C%20yet%20still%20he%20sits%20at%20his%20typewriter%2C%20in%20rented%20rooms%2C%20tapping%20out%20dialogue%20and%20dreaming%20up%20fresh%20follies%20for%20him%20and%20his%20partner%20to%20enact.%20They%20may%20have%20been%20two%20peas%20in%20a%20pod%2C%20but%2C%20as%20everybody%20in%20the%20business%20was%20aware%2C%20if%20you%20wanted%20to%20thrash%20out%20the%20details%20of%20the%20pod%E2%80%99s%20adventures%2C%20Stan%20was%20the%20man.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EThe%20plot%20of%20%E2%80%9CStan%20%26amp%3B%20Ollie%E2%80%9D%20is%20so%20slight%20as%20to%20be%20spoiler-proof.%20Though%20the%20tour%20goes%20feebly%20at%20first%2C%20it%20gathers%20strength%20once%20the%20boys%20agree%20to%20publicity%20appearances%2C%20on%20the%20advice%20of%20the%20British%20impresario%20Bernard%20Delfont%E2%80%94smoothly%20played%20by%20Rufus%20Jones%2C%20with%20an%20indestructible%20grin%20and%20the%20charm%20applied%20like%20hair%20oil.%20Other%20major%20events%20include%20the%20arrival%20of%20Lucille%20(Shirley%20Henderson)%2C%20the%20third%20Mrs.%20Hardy%2C%20and%20Ida%20(Nina%20Arianda)%2C%20the%20fourth%20Mrs.%20Laurel%2C%20who%20spar%20a%20little%2C%20but%20not%20much.%20Our%20heroes%2C%20likewise%2C%20get%20into%20an%20argument%2C%20at%20a%20reception%20held%20in%20their%20honor%2C%20whereu le%20souls.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%201955%2C%20Kenneth%20Tynan%20reviewed%20the%20London%20premi%C3%A8re%20of%20%E2%80%9CWaiting%20for%20Godot%E2%80%9D%20and%20proposed%20that%20Laurel%20and%20Hardy%20would%20be%20%E2%80%9Cideal%20casting%E2%80%9D%20as%20Lucky%20and%20Pozzo.%20But%20those%20two%20are%20slave%20and%20master%2C%20closer%20to%20the%20discomforting%20duo%20of%20Peter%20Lorre%20and%20Sydney%20Greenstreet%2C%20whereas%20Stan%20and%20Ollie%2C%20despite%20their%20physical%20differences%2C%20are%20interlocked%2C%20for%20all%20eternity%2C%20like%20Vladimir%20and%20Estragon.%20There%E2%80%99s%20a%20hint%20of%20that%20purgatory%20in%20Baird%E2%80%99s%20film%2C%20as%20the%20two%20legends%20find%20themselves%20repeating%20the%20same%20setups%2C%20over%20and%20over%2C%20to%20half-empty%20halls.%20More%20than%20once%2C%20for%20instance%2C%20we%20watch%20Laurel%20shell%20and%20eat%20a%20hard-boiled%20egg%20beside%20Hardy%E2%80%99s%20hospital%20bed%2C%20reaching%20into%20a%20breast%20pocket%20for%20a%20convenient%20salt%20shaker%20and%20exasperating%20the%20patient.%20Though%20Coogan%20has%20the%20gestures%20down%20pat%2C%20you%20really%20need%20to%20see%20the%20egg%20in%20its%20rightful%20place%E2%80%94in%20%E2%80%9CCounty%20Hospital%E2%80%9D%20(1932)%2C%20where%20Stan%E2%80%99s%20visit%20hatches%20a%20furor%20of%20unintended%20chaos%20that%20ends%20outside%2C%20on%20the%20streets%20of%20Los%20Angeles%2C%20with%20his%20automobile%20almost%20split%20in%20half.%20Laurel%20and%20Hardy%E2%80%99s%20gags%2C%20viewed%20in%20isolation%2C%20rarely%20amount%20to%20much%3B%20they%20turn%20funny%20only%20when%20one%20gag%20falls%20on%20the%20heels%20of%20another%2C%20and%20the%20canter%20of%20mishaps%20becomes%20impossible%20to%20stop.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ENothing%20is%20more%20well%20worn%2C%20among%20theatrical%20tropes%2C%20than%20the%20pathos%20of%20the%20faded%20clown.%20(Chaplin%E2%80%99s%20%E2%80%9CLimelight%E2%80%9D%20relies%20on%20little%20else.)%20If%20the%20fading%20is%20to%20hit%20home%2C%20though%2C%20you%20need%20to%20remember%20the%20glory%20that%20blazed%20before%2C%20and%20what%E2%80%99s%20at%20stake%2C%20in%20%E2%80%9CStan%20%26amp%3B%20Ollie%2C%E2%80%9D%20is%20not%20how%20loudly%20purists%20will%20object%20to%20its%20inaccuracies%20but%20how%20many%20Laurel%20and%20Hardy%20fans%2C%20even%20of%20the%20impure%20kind%2C%20still%20exist%2C%20and%20whether%20any%20new%20ones%20will%20arise%20as%20a%20result.%20In%20addition%2C%20Stan%20and%20Ollie%20were%2C%20by%20all%20accounts%2C%20decent%20folk%2C%20industrious%20in%20their%20craft%2C%20courteous%20to%20their%20supporters%2C%20and%20especially%20appealing%20to%20children%2C%20who%20relished%20the%20revelation%20that%20adults%20could%20be%20idiots%2C%20too.%20So%2C%20where%E2%80%99s%20the%20mystery%3F%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EIn%20Chaplin%E2%80%99s%20case%2C%20there%20will%20always%20be%20plenty%20to%20unearth%2C%20such%20was%20the%20monstrous%20majesty%20of%20his%20egotism%3B%20Buster%20Keaton%20grows%20ever%20more%20unfathomable%3B%20but%20%E2%80%9CStan%20%26amp%3B%20Ollie%E2%80%9D%20delves%20in%20search%20of%20hidden%20wellsprings%20that%20aren%E2%80%99t%20there.%20%E2%80%9CYou%20loved%20Laurel%20and%20Hardy%2C%20but%20you%20never%20loved%20me%2C%E2%80%9D%20Ollie%20says%20to%20his%20partner%2C%20at%20one%20point%2C%20yet%20the%20complaint%20doesn%E2%80%99t%20really%20ring%20true.%20If%20it%20means%20anything%2C%20it%20means%20simply%20that%20both%20of%20them%20were%20pros.%20That%20is%20why%20their%20pairing%2C%20more%20fusion%20than%20double%20act%2C%20has%20endured%20as%20a%20byword%20for%20togetherness.%20Even%20if%20you%E2%80%99ve%20never%20seen%20a%20minute%20of%20their%20movies%2C%20and%20even%20though%20the%20two%20men%20spend%20most%20of%20those%20movies%20squabbling%20and%20getting%20on%20each%20other%E2%80%99s%20nerves%2C%20you%20sense%20that%20Stan%20and%20Ollie%20wouldn%E2%80%99t%20have%20it%20any%20other%20way.%20They%20swelter%20in%20the%20summer%20of%20their%20discontent.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","It seems only proper that when Laurel met Hardy for the first time, on film, the meeting should have been not face to face but butt to butt. In “The Lucky Dog,” released in 1921, Oliver Hardy, in the role of a thief who has just grabbed a fistful of cash at gunpoint, tucks it into the back pocket of his pants; or, rather, by mistake, into the pants of a complete stranger, played by Stan Laurel, who is bending over and facing the other way. For a moment, they’re together, cheek to cheek, and, as with all good slapstick, the motion is hard to describe but easy to watch. Their personae are not yet fixed (Hardy, though heavy, is far too poised a gent to be ",["em","a"]," heavy), and their joint career has yet to bloom, but already they seem bound to the principle that human error, in its infinite variety, is the most natural thing in the world. We should feel disappointed when things go right."],["p","Some of that fluency lingers in “Stan & Ollie,” a new film about Laurel and Hardy, written by Jeff Pope and directed by Jon S. Baird. For reasons that I fail to grasp, the movie skips over the high noon of the couple’s fame—which ran roughly from the late nineteen-twenties to the outbreak of war, though diehard devotees would stretch it out longer—and chooses to focus, instead, on its plaintive dusk. The bulk of the story is set in the years 1953-54, as Laurel (Steve Coogan) and Hardy (John C. Reilly) travel around Britain, rehashing their old routines in a stage show. The plan is to end the tour triumphantly in London, and to secure financing for a Robin Hood movie, entitled “Rob ’Em Good.” We know, as Laurel knows, that it may never get made, yet still he sits at his typewriter, in rented rooms, tapping out dialogue and dreaming up fresh follies for him and his partner to enact. They may have been two peas in a pod, but, as everybody in the business was aware, if you wanted to thrash out the details of the pod’s adventures, Stan was the man."],["p","The plot of “Stan & Ollie” is so slight as to be spoiler-proof. Though the tour goes feebly at first, it gathers strength once the boys agree to publicity appearances, on the advice of the British impresario Bernard Delfont—smoothly played by Rufus Jones, with an indestructible grin and the charm applied like hair oil. Other major events include the arrival of Lucille (Shirley Henderson), the third Mrs. Hardy, and Ida (Nina Arianda), the fourth Mrs. Laurel, who spar a little, but not much. Our heroes, likewise, get into an argument, at a reception held in their honor, whereupon, in the movie’s happiest touch, the guests around them politely applaud, unable to imagine that the contretemps is anything but an act. Later, of course, Laurel and Hardy patch it up. Ollie gets sick at a beauty pageant, but he survives. And that’s it."],["p","The film depends, in other words, on its stars. Both, you can tell, have studied their respective masters with scrupulous care, and the results of their pupillage are plain to see. Coogan does ample justice to Stan’s eyebrows, which, in their rise and fall, are a more sensitive guide to the utterness of his bewilderment than the celebrated scratching of his scalp. Reilly, for his part, is sweetly attuned to the music of Ollie’s fatalism—less in his line readings, or in the occasional songs, than in the symphony of sighs with which he greets the inevitable wrecking of his peace. As for the grace notes of his grunts, has anyone packed more meaning into a single “Hmph”? (Marlon Brando, an admirer, said that what he liked best was Ollie “doing dead takes into the camera and shaking his head.”) The fact that Laurel and Hardy remained a joy to witness, for so long, is extraordinary, given that what they explored, with inordinate patience, was the largely joyless theme of resignation. Look at the downturned mouth of the big guy and the weakling’s helpless burst of tears. Hark to the slump of their inseparable souls."],["p","In 1955, Kenneth Tynan reviewed the London première of “Waiting for Godot” and proposed that Laurel and Hardy would be “ideal casting” as Lucky and Pozzo. But those two are slave and master, closer to the discomforting duo of Peter Lorre and Sydney Greenstreet, whereas Stan and Ollie, despite their physical differences, are interlocked, for all eternity, like Vladimir and Estragon. There’s a hint of that purgatory in Baird’s film, as the two legends find themselves repeating the same setups, over and over, to half-empty halls. More than once, for instance, we watch Laurel shell and eat a hard-boiled egg beside Hardy’s hospital bed, reaching into a breast pocket for a convenient salt shaker and exasperating the patient. Though Coogan has the gestures down pat, you really need to see the egg in its rightful place—in “County Hospital” (1932), where Stan’s visit hatches a furor of unintended chaos that ends outside, on the streets of Los Angeles, with his automobile almost split in half. Laurel and Hardy’s gags, viewed in isolation, rarely amount to much; they turn funny only when one gag falls on the heels of another, and the canter of mishaps becomes impossible to stop."],["p","Nothing is more well worn, among theatrical tropes, than the pathos of the faded clown. (Chaplin’s “Limelight” relies on little else.) If the fading is to hit home, though, you need to remember the glory that blazed before, and what’s at stake, in “Stan & Ollie,” is not how loudly purists will object to its inaccuracies but how many Laurel and Hardy fans, even of the impure kind, still exist, and whether any new ones will arise as a result. In addition, Stan and Ollie were, by all accounts, decent folk, industrious in their craft, courteous to their supporters, and especially appealing to children, who relished the revelation that adults could be idiots, too. So, where’s the mystery?"],["p","In Chaplin’s case, there will always be plenty to unearth, such was the monstrous majesty of his egotism; Buster Keaton grows ever more unfathomable; but “Stan & Ollie” delves in search of hidden wellsprings that aren’t there. “You loved Laurel and Hardy, but you never loved me,” Ollie says to his partner, at one point, yet the complaint doesn’t really ring true. If it means anything, it means simply that both of them were pros. That is why their pairing, more fusion than double act, has endured as a byword for togetherness. Even if you’ve never seen a minute of their movies, and even though the two men spend most of those movies squabbling and getting on each other’s nerves, you sense that Stan and Ollie wouldn’t have it any other way. They swelter in the summer of their discontent."]],["inline-embed",{"type":"section","meta":"%7B%22type%22%3A%22section%22%2C%22body%22%3A%22%3Cp%3EThe%20first%20shot%20of%20Nicole%20Kidman%2C%20in%20%E2%80%9CDestroyer%2C%E2%80%9D%20is%20a%20closeup%20of%20her%20eyes.%20Bleary%20and%20darkly%20ringed%2C%20they%20make%20you%20wonder%20what%20horrors%20they%20have%20seen.%20The%20rest%20of%20her%20is%20barely%20in%20better%20shape.%20Her%20walk%20is%20a%20staggering%20shuffle%2C%20and%20her%20face%20is%20so%20lined%20that%20the%20marketing%20department%20at%20Neutrogena%2C%20for%20whom%20Kidman%20has%20fronted%20eager%20commercials%20(%E2%80%9CWrinkles%2C%20your%20time%20is%20up!%E2%80%9D)%2C%20may%20conceivably%20launch%20a%20legal%20challenge%20to%20have%20the%20movie%20banned.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EShe%20plays%20Erin%20Bell%2C%20a%20detective%20in%20the%20L.A.P.D.%2C%20and%20clearly%20the%20lonest%20of%20wolves.%20Despite%20having%20a%20sidekick%2C%20Antonio%20(Shamier%20Anderson)%2C%20she%20spurns%20his%20assistance.%20At%20the%20start%20of%20Karyn%20Kusama%E2%80%99s%20movie%2C%20Erin%20inspects%20a%20corpse.%20Three%20roundels%20are%20tattooed%20on%20its%20nape%3B%20beside%20it%20lie%20a%20hundred-dollar%20bill%2C%20stained%20with%20purple%20dye%2C%20and%20a%20%E2%80%9Cghost%20gun%2C%E2%80%9D%20shorn%20of%20identifying%20marks.%20All%20of%20which%20is%20evidence%2C%20apparently%2C%20that%20someone%20named%20Silas%20(Toby%20Kebbell)%2C%20a%20fearsome%20figure%20from%20Erin%E2%80%99s%20past%2C%20is%20back%20in%20the%20criminal%20game.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ENow%20and%20then%2C%20we%20get%20flashbacks%20to%20that%20past%E2%80%94to%20a%20period%20when%20Erin%20and%20a%20colleague%2C%20Chris%20(Sebastian%20Stan)%2C%20went%20undercover%20with%20Silas%20and%20his%20gang%2C%20who%20were%20carrying%20out%20armed%20robberies.%20If%20you%E2%80%99re%20slow%2C%20like%20me%2C%20and%20find%20yourself%20bemused%20by%20the%20chronology%2C%20don%E2%80%99t%20worry%3B%20your%20reward%20will%20be%20a%20topnotch%20twist%20toward%20the%20end.%20By%20rights%2C%20that%20should%20make%20you%20want%20to%20watch%20the%20movie%20all%20over%20again%2C%20in%20order%20to%20sort%20out%20what%20belongs%20where%2C%20except%20that%20everything%20about%20it%20is%20so%20scummy%E2%80%94even%20the%20sight%20of%20creamer%20being%20stirred%20into%20coffee%20makes%20you%20gag%E2%80%94that%20a%20second%20viewing%20would%20feel%20like%20the%20grimmest%20of%20grinds.%20%E2%80%9CDestroyer%E2%80%9D%20is%20a%20thriller%2C%20but%20only%20just.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EKidman%20is%20indeed%20remarkable%20here%2C%20as%20rumor%20suggests%2C%20but%20mainly%20because%20you%20can%E2%80%99t%20stop%20remarking%20her.%20It%E2%80%99s%20an%20over-cover%20performance%20in%20an%20undercover%20role.%20Though%20aiming%20to%20blend%20in%2C%20she%E2%80%99s%20so%20dramatically%20busy%20that%20she%20ends%20up%20sticking%20out%2C%20like%20a%20chameleon%20who%E2%80%99s%20praying%20for%20an%20Oscar%20nod.%20The%20rule%20seems%20to%20be%20that%20the%20more%20makeup%20and%20prosthetics%20she%20piles%20on%20the%20more%20likely%20we%20are%20to%20cry%20out%2C%20in%20unison%2C%20%E2%80%9COh%2C%20look%2C%20it%E2%80%99s%20Nicole%20Kidman!%E2%80%9D%20Still%2C%20to%20be%20fair%2C%20she%20does%20lunge%20without%20demur%20into%20the%20action%2C%20toting%20an%20automatic%20rifle%20sufficiently%20massive%20to%20foil%20a%20bank%20job.%20I%20don%E2%80%99t%20%3Cem%3Ethink%3C%2Fem%3E%20that%20Kidman%20did%20that%20when%20she%20played%20Virginia%20Woolf%2C%20in%20%E2%80%9CThe%20Hours%E2%80%9D%20(2002)%2C%20but%20I%20can%E2%80%99t%20help%20wishing%20she%20had.%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","The first shot of Nicole Kidman, in “Destroyer,” is a closeup of her eyes. Bleary and darkly ringed, they make you wonder what horrors they have seen. The rest of her is barely in better shape. Her walk is a staggering shuffle, and her face is so lined that the marketing department at Neutrogena, for whom Kidman has fronted eager commercials (“Wrinkles, your time is up!”), may conceivably launch a legal challenge to have the movie banned."],["p","She plays Erin Bell, a detective in the L.A.P.D., and clearly the lonest of wolves. Despite having a sidekick, Antonio (Shamier Anderson), she spurns his assistance. At the start of Karyn Kusama’s movie, Erin inspects a corpse. Three roundels are tattooed on its nape; beside it lie a hundred-dollar bill, stained with purple dye, and a “ghost gun,” shorn of identifying marks. All of which is evidence, apparently, that someone named Silas (Toby Kebbell), a fearsome figure from Erin’s past, is back in the criminal game."],["p","Now and then, we get flashbacks to that past—to a period when Erin and a colleague, Chris (Sebastian Stan), went undercover with Silas and his gang, who were carrying out armed robberies. If you’re slow, like me, and find yourself bemused by the chronology, don’t worry; your reward will be a topnotch twist toward the end. By rights, that should make you want to watch the movie all over again, in order to sort out what belongs where, except that everything about it is so scummy—even the sight of creamer being stirred into coffee makes you gag—that a second viewing would feel like the grimmest of grinds. “Destroyer” is a thriller, but only just."],["p","Kidman is indeed remarkable here, as rumor suggests, but mainly because you can’t stop remarking her. It’s an over-cover performance in an undercover role. Though aiming to blend in, she’s so dramatically busy that she ends up sticking out, like a chameleon who’s praying for an Oscar nod. The rule seems to be that the more makeup and prosthetics she piles on the more likely we are to cry out, in unison, “Oh, look, it’s Nicole Kidman!” Still, to be fair, she does lunge without demur into the action, toting an automatic rifle sufficiently massive to foil a bank job. I don’t ",["em","think"]," that Kidman did that when she played Virginia Woolf, in “The Hours” (2002), but I can’t help wishing she had. ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"sections":[{"id":"59040e521048cc5ce9e6a56c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Magazine","parent":[{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"}],"photos":{},"root":{"id":"5afc81ab371770228fe7e770","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Channels","parent":[],"photos":{},"root":[],"slug":"channels"},"slug":"magazine","children":[{"id":"59b9bf9c66a5ca32dcef1772","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[{"id":"59b9bf9c66a5ca32dcef1772","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"The Before coming to the magazine, he worked at the ",["em","Independent"],", in London, where he was appointed deputy literary editor in 1989 and, a year later, a film critic for the ",["em","Independent on Sunday"],". 2C%20and%20Garc%C3%ADa%2C%20twenty-four%2C%20are%20of%20Mixtec%20descent.%20On%20the%20second%20floor%2C%20the%20group%20examined%20a%20wall%20with%20snapshots%20of%20famous%20visitors.%20Aparicio%20recognized%20Susan%20Sarandon%2C%20whom%20she%E2%80%99d%20seen%20at%20a%20photo%20shoot%20in%20Toronto.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3ETwo%20elevators%20later%2C%20they%20emerged%20on%20the%20eighty-sixth%20floor%2C%20and%20stepped%20out%20onto%20the%20observation%20deck.%20%E2%80%9CI%20was%20not%20expecting%20it%20to%20be%20so%20windy%2C%E2%80%9D%20Aparicio%20said%2C%20her%20long%20black%20hair%20whipping%20her%20face.%20She%20and%20Garc%C3%ADa%20took%20a%20selfie%3B%20they%20were%20bundled%20in%20scarves%20and%20winter%20coats.%20(Garc%C3%ADa%E2%80%99s%20had%20been%20provided%20by%20the%20film%E2%80%99s%20producers.)%20%E2%80%9CThere%20it%20is%2C%20the%20statue%2C%E2%80%9D%20Aparicio%20remarked%2C%20spotting%20the%20Statue%20of%20Liberty.%20Circling%20north%2C%20Su%C3%A1rez%20pointed%20out%20St.%20Patrick%E2%80%99s%20Cathedral%20and%20the%20Bronx.%20%E2%80%9CSpanish%20Harlem%20is%20now%20highly%20Mexican%2C%20but%20they%20are%20leaving%20because%20the%20rents%20are%20very%20high%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAparicio%20nodded.%20%E2%80%9CThe%20last%20time%20I%20was%20here%2C%20the%20park%20was%20still%20green%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20noted%2C%20pointing%20at%20a%20bare-limbed%20Central%20Park.%20(That%20was%20in%20October%2C%20for%20the%20New%20York%20Film%20Festival.)%20Torres%2C%20who%20wore%20a%20Mickey%20Mouse%20sweatshirt%2C%20motioned%20her%20next%20to%20Garc%C3%ADa%20for%20a%20picture.%20%E2%80%9CTwo%20Oaxacan%20Women%20Take%20Manhattan!%E2%80%9D%20he%20said.%20A%20visit%20to%20the%20western%20edge%20of%20the%20building%20was%20short-lived%3A%20too%20windy.%20The%20women%20huddled%2C%20laughing.%20%E2%80%9CNow%20I%20understand%20how%20they%20did%20%E2%80%98Mary%20Poppins%2C%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20Aparicio%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EAparicio%20is%20from%20the%20city%20of%20Tlaxiaco%2C%20in%20Oaxaca.%20She%20was%20home%20from%20her%20school%20in%20Putla%2C%20two%20hours%20away%2C%20when%20she%20heard%20about%20the%20%E2%80%9CRoma%E2%80%9D%20auditions%20from%20her%20sister%20Edith.%20At%20first%2C%20she%20was%20suspicious.%20%E2%80%9CI%20thought%20that%20it%20could%20be%20related%20to%20human%20trafficking%2C%20because%20they%20never%20do%20castings%20in%20Oaxaca%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20But%20she%20accompanied%20her%20sister%2C%20who%20was%20pregnant%20and%20got%20cold%20feet%20once%20they%20were%20there.%20At%20the%20first%20audition%2C%20she%20was%20asked%20questions%20such%20as%20%E2%80%9CHave%20you%20ever%20been%20in%20love%3F%E2%80%9D%3B%20the%20next%20time%2C%20she%20had%20to%20improvise%20a%20scene%20and%20read%20a%20story%20about%20a%20%3Cem%3Etorteria%3C%2Fem%3E.%20After%20she%20got%20the%20part%2C%20she%20brought%20in%20Garc%C3%ADa%2C%20her%20classmate%2C%20to%20help%20her%20translate%20a%20scene%20that%20was%20written%20in%20Mixtec.%20(Aparicio%20speaks%20mostly%20Spanish.)%20%E2%80%9CAlfonso%20said%20it%20would%20be%20great%20if%20the%20person%20that%20plays%20my%20friend%20is%20a%20real%20friend%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said%2C%20and%20so%20Garc%C3%ADa%20was%20cast%2C%20too.%20Aparicio%20is%20unsure%20if%20she%20will%20go%20back%20to%20teaching.%20%E2%80%9CWe%E2%80%99ll%20see%20what%20happens.%E2%80%9D%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EDownstairs%20in%20the%20gift%20shop%2C%20Aparicio%20considered%20a%20snow%20globe%20with%20a%20King%20Kong%20figurine.%20%E2%80%9CIt%E2%80%99s%20thanks%20to%20%E2%80%98King%20Kong%E2%80%99%20that%20I%20was%20aware%20this%20building%20existed%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20Garc%C3%ADa%20recalled%20that%2C%20at%20the%20final%20dubbing%20session%2C%20%E2%80%9CI%20hugged%20Alfonso%20and%20I%20told%20him%2C%20%E2%80%98I%20think%20this%20is%20the%20last%20time%20we%E2%80%99ll%20see%20each%20other.%E2%80%99%20He%20said%2C%20%E2%80%98No%2C%20wait%E2%80%94the%20best%20part%20is%20coming.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%20Months%20later%2C%20the%20two%20women%20embarked%20on%20the%20film%E2%80%99s%20promotional%20blitz%3A%20Venice%2C%20London%2C%20Telluride%2C%20Toronto.%20%E2%80%9CWe%20saw%20a%20street%20in%20San%20Francisco%20called%20Nancy%20Street%2C%E2%80%9D%20Garc%C3%ADa%2C%20whose%20parents%20named%20her%20Nancy%20after%20seeing%20the%20name%20on%20television%2C%20said%20with%20excitement.%20(She%20was%20likely%20referring%20to%20Nancy%20Pelosi%20Drive.)%20They%20had%20vowed%20not%20to%20watch%20the%20finished%20film%20until%20its%20premi%C3%A8re%20in%20Venice.%20%E2%80%9CWhen%20they%20turned%20on%20the%20lights%2C%20we%20were%20crying%2C%E2%80%9D%20Aparicio%20said.%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%3Cp%3EBefore%20leaving%20the%20gift%20shop%2C%20Aparicio%20inspected%20a%20display%20of%20personalized%20license-plate%20magnets%2C%20alphabetized%20by%20first%20name.%20%E2%80%9CI%E2%80%99m%20looking%20for%20my%20name%2C%E2%80%9D%20she%20said.%20Victoria%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20William%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20Xavier%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%C2%A0.%20no%20Yalitza.%20Oh%2C%20well.%20She%20added%2C%20%E2%80%9CMy%20name%20means%20%E2%80%98sunrise%20of%20life.%E2%80%99%C2%A0%E2%80%9D%C2%A0%E2%99%A6%3C%2Fp%3E%5Cn%22%7D","ref":""},["p","One recent morning, as tourists and office workers streamed into and out of the Empire State Building lobby, the arrival of a freshly minted movie star went unnoticed. Yalitza Aparicio plays the lead role in “Roma,” Alfonso Cuarón’s lauded Netflix film, about a live-in housekeeper for a middle-class family in Mexico City; the character, Cleo, is based on Cuarón’s childhood nanny, Libo, to whom the movie is dedicated. When Aparicio got the part, just after completing her degree in preschool education, she had never acted before and had never been outside Mexico. Now she has walked red carpets around the world, appears on the cover of Mexican ",["em","Vogue"],", and is an unlikely awards-season contender in a field that includes Glenn Close, Melissa McCarthy, and Lady Gaga."],["p","But she had never been to the top of the Empire State Building. “I’m going to be able to see the whole city from above,” she said through a translator, Juana Suárez, a film scholar at N.Y.U. Her entourage also included Carlos Torres, the manager of the Mexican actress Marina de Tavira, who plays Cleo’s employer; and Nancy García, Aparicio’s friend from school, who plays her fellow-maid. Both Aparicio, twenty-five, and García, twenty-four, are of Mixtec descent. On the second floor, the group examined a wall with snapshots of famous visitors. Aparicio recognized Susan Sarandon, whom she’d seen at a photo shoot in Toronto."],["p","Two elevators later, they emerged on the eighty-sixth floor, and stepped out onto the observation deck. “I was not expecting it to be so windy,” Aparicio said, her long black hair whipping her face. She and García took a selfie; they were bundled in scarves and winter coats. (García’s had been provided by the film’s producers.) “There it is, the statue,” Aparicio remarked, spotting the Statue of Liberty. Circling north, Suárez pointed out St. Patrick’s Cathedral and the Bronx. “Spanish Harlem is now highly Mexican, but they are leaving because the rents are very high,” she said."],["p","Aparicio nodded. “The last time I was here, the park was still green,” she noted, pointing at a bare-limbed Central Park. (That was in October, for the New York Film Festival.) Torres, who wore a Mickey Mouse sweatshirt, motioned her next to García for a picture. “Two Oaxacan Women Take Manhattan!” he said. A visit to the western edge of the building was short-lived: too windy. The women huddled, laughing. “Now I understand how they did ‘Mary Poppins,’ ” Aparicio said."],["p","Aparicio is from the city of Tlaxiaco, in Oaxaca. She was home from her school in Putla, two hours away, when she heard about the “Roma” auditions from her sister Edith. At first, she was suspicious. “I thought that it could be related to human trafficking, because they never do castings in Oaxaca,” she said. But she accompanied her sister, who was pregnant and got cold feet once they were there. At the first audition, she was asked questions such as “Have you ever been in love?”; the next time, she had to improvise a scene and read a story about a ",["em","torteria"],". After she got the part, she brought in García, her classmate, to help her translate a scene that was written in Mixtec. (Aparicio speaks mostly Spanish.) “Alfonso said it would be great if the person that plays my friend is a real friend,” she said, and so García was cast, too. Aparicio is unsure if she will go back to teaching. “We’ll see what happens.”"],["p","Downstairs in the gift shop, Aparicio considered a snow globe with a King Kong figurine. “It’s thanks to ‘King Kong’ that I was aware this building existed,” she said. García recalled that, at the final dubbing session, “I hugged Alfonso and I told him, ‘I think this is the last time we’ll see each other.’ He said, ‘No, wait—the best part is coming.’ ” Months later, the two women embarked on the film’s promotional blitz: Venice, London, Telluride, Toronto. “We saw a street in San Francisco called Nancy Street,” García, whose parents named her Nancy after seeing the name on television, said with excitement. (She was likely referring to Nancy Pelosi Drive.) They had vowed not to watch the finished film until its première in Venice. “When they turned on the lights, we were crying,” Aparicio said."],["p","Before leaving the gift shop, Aparicio inspected a display of personalized license-plate magnets, alphabetized by first name. “I’m looking for my name,” she said. Victoria . . . William . . . Xavier . . . no Yalitza. Oh, well. She added, “My name means ‘sunrise of life.’ ” ♦"]]],"canonicalUrl":"","categories":{"tags":[{"id":"5c2e1c7c2bfcc72cd92d052c","modelName":"category","collection":"categories","contributors":{},"hierarchy":[],"name":"Yalitza
